STATEMENT BY THE TREASURER, THE HON. JOHN HOWARD, MP
COMMENTS ON THE McCABE/LAFRANCHI REPORT
A INTRODUCTION

I have now had the opportunity of studying in greater detail the report of Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi tabled in the Victorian Parliament on 27 May 1982 ( hereafter referred to as the ''Report''). I have also had the benefit of lengthy comments on aspects of that report from the Commissioner of Taxation.

This detailed statement contains particulars in defence of the Australian Taxation Office, against the unwarranted criticisms that have been levelled in the Report and by the Premier of Victoria when he presented the Report to the Victorian Parliament and in subsequent comments.
The Report has made a valuable contribution to the debate on tax evasion and tax avoidance.

To the extent that it has increased public awareness of the nature of certain tax avoidance practices, and the unsavoury actions so often involved in such practices, it has heightened the sense of public outrage at tax evasion and avoidance.

As a result it has served to emphasise the significance of this Government's legislative and administrative effort directed against such practices in the past four years which had as the highlights the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and the new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

That having been said, however, I believe the Report has been used in an unfair and unwarranted way in three main respects: to create the general impression that this Government and the Australian Taxation Office just stood by and let certain tax avoidance and evasion practices grow unhindered; to create the impression that the so-called ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' schemes continued to a significant extent beyond the passage of the remedial legislation; and finally, to make a number of criticisms of the Australian Taxation Office.

Before dealing in some detail with the specific allegations there are a number of preliminary comments which I should make and which are in my view essential to a proper understanding of the relevance of this Report and some of the things contained in it.
B PERSPECTIVE

It is important in considering the Report to recall the nature of the environment at the time the practices were entered into, especially the prevailing public attitudes and the priorities of the Government, the Australian Taxation Office and others at that time.
1 Sudden Proliferation of Schemes in 1977-78

To begin with, it should be noted that the schemes which are focussed on in the Report were largely entered into before the end of 1978. Although there is evidence of some of these schemes in existence earlier in the 1970s, they really did not become widely used until 1977 and 1978, ie, until after the High Court decision in the Slutzkin case.

Hence, as a consequence of certain High Court decisions there was a sudden proliferation of these and other schemes. Those decisions were seen as providing something of a green light to the development of such schemes.

Although the Australian Taxation Office had been active in documenting and seeking to counteract schemes to strip companies of untaxed profits, it was not until 1979 or 1980 that the full extent of such schemes really became apparent to the Australian Taxation Office and the Government.

When the Commissioner of Taxation first raised with me in May 1978 the prospect that criminal penalties might need to be introduced in order to deal with these practices, they were still being documented and the full extent of their use was not yet known. Priority was then being given to dealing with other established and damaging schemes, both by the Taxation Office in its administrative responses and advice to me and by the Government in its own legislative processes and response.
2 Public Attitudes to Tax Avoidance
Moreover, strong public attitudes towards tax avoidance were not yet evident at that time.

In fact, the issue of tax avoidance really only started to gain public attention as a result of the publicity surrounding the Government's clamp down on paper schemes of avoidance, such as the so-called ''Curran Scheme''.

Public awareness grew as the very damaging revenue impacts of such schemes became more generally recognised and as the Government intensified its campaign against tax avoidance by making such schemes the subject of remedial legislation .
Legislation against the Curran Scheme was followed by a series of further measures against other schemes as their threat to revenue and to the fairness of the tax system became apparent.

The point is that public attitudes against tax avoidance were only in their formative stages at the time the schemes described in the Report were reaching their peak in 1977 and 1978 and were, therefore, nowhere near as pronounced as they are today.

These attitudes have, of course, hardened considerably in recent years. Public hostility has grown, as tax avoidance practices have received considerable publicity and as the Government has intensified its campaign against them.

Hence, without wanting to downplay in any sense the significance of the schemes covered in the Report, it is clearly important to recognise the considerably different state of public opinion towards tax avoidance that existed at that time.
3 The Approach of the Australian Taxation Office
In considering the response of the Australian Taxation Office, it is also important to recognise the administrative procedures and priorities characteristic of their activities at that time.

Essentially, the Australian Taxation Office had until the end of 1977 been trying to make Section 260 work as a general anti-avoidance provision. Their strategy until then had been to take test cases on Section 260 to the High Court , to get a ruling, and then to apply that ruling as a basis of assessment.

The decision in Cridland's case in November 1977 essentially represented the final death knell for this approach. If that decision were to hold, Section 260 could no longer be relied upon as a general anti-avoidance provision and it would be necessary to find some alternative.
Hence, in early 1978, and with my strong support and encouragement, the Australian Taxation Office began work towards the development of what became Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

At about the same time, the Australian Taxation Office, having been unsuccessful in efforts to have prosecutions launched, put to me and I readily accepted that there ought to be moves towards measures of the kind which were ultimately embodied in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

It should also be recognised that in dealing with the sort of allegations made in the Report against the Australian Taxation Office, it is not possible to outline every step that was taken by the Commissioner.
In what follows, therefore, an attempt has been made to simply highlight the most important steps taken by the Commissioner in relation to these schemes.
4 What's New in the Report?

Perhaps one of the most unfortunate aspects of the publication of the Report is that it was used to create the false impression that this was 'new' information, on 'new' schemes, with dramatic 'new' revenue losses.

This clearly was not the case. In fact, the only 'new' feature of the Report was that, for the first time, tax avoidance and evasion of this kind was personalised as individuals and companies were identified by name.

Although as I said the Australian Taxation Office and the Government developed detailed knowledge of the extent of the arrangements in the last couple of years of the 1970s, the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act meant that the names of those involved in such schemes were totally unknown to me and other members of the Government, prior to publication of the Report.

It is a matter of note that the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act are such that even now the Commissioner of Taxation is unable to confirm or deny possible correlations between the activities of promoters, unnamed in minutes addressed to me, but named and described in practices set out in the Report.

Without wanting to labour the fact that neither details of the schemes nor the revenue losses involved came as a surprise to us, it is worth recalling some of the things that I said at the time of introducing our remedial legislation. I gave then some figures just as startling as those in the Report.

As I have so frequently said in recent weeks, the practices described and the schemes outlined in this Report, were the target of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in December 1980.
In my Second Reading Speech of 26 November 1980, when introducing the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Bill, I said:

'As the task of artificial avoidance has become more difficult, the less scrupulous have added a new and I think most would agree, unacceptable dimension to endeavours to ensure that payment of tax is escaped . . .

The seriousness of the position cannot be overstated. For example, one promoter is known to have stripped some 2,086 companies during a recent period. In 733 of these cases, the result has been that the Commissioner of Taxation will be unable to collect tax on taxable incomes aggregating over $128 million.'
This was in fact quoted directly in the Report (pages 27 and 28).
5 Evasion or Avoidance

Finally, to conclude our consideration of perspective, it is important to recognise that although the Report appears to concentrate on evasion, it is in fact referring to a mixture of avoidance and evasion practices.

The Report focuses on some 923 companies and it notes that they fall into three categories-companies with profits that had not borne company tax (current year profit companies), companies with accumulated profits from previous years ( revenue reserve companies) and non-operating companies with little or no assets (redundant companies). Concern attaches particularly to the first two categories .

Stripping of current year profit companies had the effect of evading payment of company tax and of avoiding tax payable by shareholders when the profits were ultimately distributed to them as dividends.

On the other hand, stripping of revenue reserve companies had only the latter effect, i.e., avoidance of tax in shareholders' hands on amounts which, if there had been no strip, presumably would eventually have been distributed as dividends.

While the Report recognises the existence of these categories, the essential discussion in it is about evasion by current year profit companies. One would tend to think from the discussion that the 923 companies cited in the report were mostly current year profit cases.

That is not the case. Examination of the cases identified in volumes 2 to 5 of the Report indicates that some 365 of the 923 companies were current year profit cases. Information available to the Australian Taxation Office indicates that, in addition to these 365 companies, some of the remaining companies were stripped of profits before company tax payable by them had been paid.

Taking those cases into account, the position is that more than half of the 923 strips did not involve any stripping of untaxed company profits. The tax evaded by stripping untaxed company profits amounts to some $34 million.

It is to that area of evasion that my statement, like the basic discussion in the Report, primarily relates. It is to the question of prosecution of persons connected with this evasion that the strictures in the report against the Australian Taxation Office are directed.
C THE POSITION IN DETAIL-UP TO 1978
The initial question concerns what action the Australian Taxation Office took when it heard of cases of stripping of untaxed company profits.

Before answering this question, however, the point should be made that the activities that are described in this section were essentially those undertaken by the Commissioner in the normal course of his administrative duties and as such were unknown to me until early 1978.

These are cases in which shareholders of companies were selling their shares in circumstances where there were associated arrangements under which the target companies were stripped of funds and left in a position where the companies could not pay the income tax that would in the normal course of events be assessed to them. The shareholders received the profits of the companies in a tax-free capital form, not diminished in any way by either company tax or tax on dividends but only by the fee charged by the promoter for his services.

As noted earlier, these ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' cases are to be distinguished from those, now known by the description ''dry Slutzkins'', in which shareholders sell their shares for a capital sum that reflects accumulated company profits that have borne company tax.

A case of company stripping came to the attention of a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation early in 1973. Following an extensive investigation by Taxation officers the matter was reported to the Commissioner's Head Office in Juy 1974.

It was decided there that section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act applied and that assessments should be made against the vendor shareholders, to include in their assessable incomes the proceeds of the sale of their shares. (The basis for this assessment action was subsequently ruled to be untenable by the High Court in Slutzkin & Ors v F C of T, 1977 ATC 4076).

In addition, in August/September 1974, the Commissioner, through his Deputy, sought legal advice from the local Deputy Crown Solicitor as to whether the facts available would support a prosecution against any person under income tax legislation, the Commonwealth Crimes Act or the Companies Act.

The Deputy Commissioner received this opinion in January 1975, and it was to the effect that on the material presented by the Commissioner to counsel, grounds existed for prosecution under Section 67 of the Companies Act and under Section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that proceedings could be instituted under Section 367B of the Companies Act.

Having checked that secrecy provisions would not operate as a barrier to prosecution, in August 1975, the Commissioner authorised the Deputy Crown Solicitor to take the necessary steps towards action under the indicated sections of the Crimes Act and the Companies Act.

Following this reference to the Deputy Crown Solicitor, there were further taxation inquiries and a formal investigation by the police. The police having in November 1976 reported in favour of action under the nominated Crimes Act and Companies Act provisions, it was found necessary in the course of ensuing discussions and contacts between taxation and legal officers for further information to be sought, and information obtained was put under examination.

In the light of the then apparent proliferation of ''straw'' companies and his concern about it, the Commissioner in March 1978 took the matter to the Crown Solicitor himself, using as a particular instance the then unresolved case of the company whose situtation had been before the Deputy Crown Solicitor. Discussions and correspondence ensued and in April 1979 the Commissioner received Crown Law advice to the effect that there was insufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case of ''conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth''.
With the benefit of hindsight, of course, such a period seems inordinately long .

However, it is important to recognise that the collection of appropriate evidence and the preparation of legal opinion can be a very labour-intensive exercise, particularly in circumstances as existed at that time, where the financial details of these schemes were still being determined and where both the Crown Solicitor and the Australian Taxation Office, of course, had numerous other priorities.
It is especially relevant to recognise that what was principally involved was endeavouring to establish a charge of conspiracy. Conspriacy cases are notoriously difficult to estabish and sustain.

Throughout the pre-1978 period, the Taxation Office had been seeking to initiate action in relation to other stripped companies. Particular companies were selected as representative of those that had come under notice.

For example, in one case, reported to the Taxation Head Office in April 1976, it was proposed that the stripped company's past or present officers or directors be prosecuted. Again legal opinions were sought as to whether actions would lie against appropriate persons under section 231 of the Assessment Act, the Crimes Act or the Companies Act.

However, following an extended series of discussions and taxation enquiries, conferences between taxation and legal officers and counsel, advice was received from counsel, along with comments from the Deputy Crown Solicitor, to the effect that proposed assessment action against the vendor shareholders would be unlikely to be upheld, that prosecution action would not lie against any person, that Section 367B of the Companies Act could not be successfully invoked and that further enquiries would be of no avail.

In another case, legal advice from counsel, received by the company's liquidator in July 1978, was to the effect that actions might lie against directors of the relevant company for the common law tort of negligence but that actions under Sections 124, 374C and 374D of the Companies Act were unlikely to succeed. The issues were never tested because action instituted against the directors resulted in securing the recovery of a substantial amount of tax.

To conclude this section, in each of the cases taken to the Commonwealth's legal authorities for advice, it turned out that the advice was to the effect that prosecutions could not, with sufficient prospects of success be launched.
It is important at this point to recall the essence of the approach of the Australian Taxation Office.

The cases selected to be put to the legal authorities with a view to formal prosecution action by them were representative cases. These were cases which had been fully investigated and were regarded as the best prospects for sucessful prosecution out of all those that had come to the notice of the Australian Taxation Office.
I believe the record shows that the Taxation Office was active in obtaining appropriate legal advice and in doing what it could do to facilitate prosecution action by the appropriate authorities.
D THE MOVE TO CRIMINAL PENALTIES
I believe it is important to understand why we finally resorted to criminal penalties and to emphasise the significance of that step.

It was because the Government believed, on the basis of legal advice provided to it, that the then existing law was an insufficient response to these practices, that it was decided to enact the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

That legislation was presented to the Parliament as a result of advice initially received from the Australian Taxation Office. It was the Australian Taxation Office which in May 1978 first advised the Government that criminal penalties of unprecedented severity for practices of this kind in Australia should be inserted in the law.

It put proposals to me once it heard that stripping of untaxed company profits was occurring on a wide scale. During the processes leading up to the passage of the legislation it passed on further reports about such practices and was active in seeking completion of the legislation.

In deciding to present this legislation to the Parliament the Government also had the benefit of advice from its Taxation Advisory Committee which is comprised of private sector practitioners in the taxation field.
By any test, that legislation represented a strong and determined response by the Government to the practices against which it was directed.

It should not be forgotten, however, that criminal penalties were introduced against practices of this kind only after very lengthy and painstaking consideration and notwithstanding considerable misgivings felt by some at that time as to whether such penalties were not perhaps an over-reaction to the practices in question.

Although the work on preparing what ultimately became the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act commenced in 1978, there was considerable reserve and caution within the Government as to whether criminal penalties were really appropriate and as a consequence further effort was devoted to establishing whether or not some method of coping with the problem could be found without resort to the criminal law.
In the final analysis, the Government came to the conclusion that there was really no alternative but to bring in criminal penalties.

However, it is essential to keep this issue in proper perspective and, for example, to recall that even in December 1980, when the legislation was being considered by the Parliament there were many prepared to allege that the Government might be going too far.
At that time I received many representations stating that the introduction of criminal penalties was an over-reaction on the Government's part.
These representations included some from the Law Institute of Victoria, the Law Institute of Western Australia and the Law Society of New South Wales.
To cite one example, the Law Institute of Victoria said:

'This Bill makes far reaching changes to the criminal law which will affect all members of the business community including lawyers and accountants. Accordingly it should not be allowed to proceed until all the changes to the existing law have been fully considered and understood, not only by the lawyers and accountants who have to advise members of the business community on the subject of sales tax and income tax, but also by the business community who will have to bear the cost and suffer the inconvenience which will inevitably arise as a result of imposing draconian criminal sanctions on the normal professional relationship between solicitor and client and accountant and client.'

A common theme of many of these representations was that the Bill I had introduced should be allowed to lie on the table of the House during the subsequent Christmas recess so that its provisions might be critically analysed with a view to eliminating any unintended consequences. The Parliament, at the Government's urging, rejected this advice, the acceptance of which would have provided the tax avoidance industry with a last and wholly undeserved opportunity to rape the Exchequer.

It can be seen that the period between when the Commissioner proposed to me action of the kind, and the time of introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill 1980, was a lengthy one. I have never sought to hide this fact and I said as much in my address on 6 March 1981 at a seminar conducted under the auspices of the Australian Society of Accountants.
I quote from my speech on that occasion:

'Turning now to the main topic today, the discussion of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980, I would like to assure you that it was only after a long and careful examination that I was convinced of the necessity of the legislation.

I was, and remain, convinced that no effective alternative course was open if the quite outrageous activities of those who were engaging in straw company and straw trust tax evasion were to be brought up short.
I was also concerned to ensure-as was the Attorney-General and other members of the Government-that the terms of the new legislation were scrupulously fair to anyone who was accused of breaching it.

In other words, that no one would have his liberty put at risk except on proof beyond reasonable doubt that he had deliberately engaged in, or aided and abetted someone else to engage in, acts fraudulently intended to evade payment of tax by a company or trustee.
Both during the preparation of the Bill and when considering amendments while the legislation was before the Parliament, such concerns were very much in my mind.

After becoming aware that certain evasion methods were being used, and indeed escalating, I had an examination carried out by officers of the Taxation Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Attorney- General's Department.
Their advice to me was that the schemes could not effectively be countered by the application of existing laws which they found to be deficient for the purpose for one reason or another.
It was put to me that specific legislation carrying penal sanctions was the only viable option to deal with the problem.

The Government subsequently gave very careful consideration to the form that the new legislation might take before agreeing to the drafting of the Bill. There followed extensive consultations between Parliamentary Counsel and officers of the Taxation Department and the Attorney-General's Department as drafting progressed.
I also asked the Taxation Advisory Committee to examine and advise on the proposals.
The Government's response was then reflected in further changes to the draft before the Bill was finally agreed to by the Government.

While not all of the parties who had a hand in the preparation of or review of the Bill through these processes may necessarily have been in complete agreement on all the details of the Bill as introduced, I think it should be clear from what I have said that it had a very thorough preparation which took account of very wide-ranging views and there was certainly very broad agreement on the thrust of the Bill.''

From my own point of view and that of the Government, I consider that there was no avoidable delay. The period was one when, just in the tax field alone, there was a very large volume of remedial and other legislation.

For example, in the 4 years to 31 December 1980 there were 112 Taxation Bills considered and enacted by the Parliament consisting of 710 pages of substantive legislation. Much of this legislation was complex and was heavily weighted to the anti-avoidance area. The legislation could, of course, only have been framed once Taxation investigation staff had completed the difficult and time consuming task of investigating and analysing the schemes concerned. An attachment to this statement provides more details on the nature of legislation of recent years ( Attachment A).

Those officers of the Australian Taxation Office who had responsibility for advising the Government on the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill, and instructing Parliamentary Counsel on its drafting, also carried out corresponding tasks on the other tax legislation I have referred to. The heavy burden that they carried throughout the period was recognised later by the Public Service Board when, with my support, it agreed to a strengthening of the staff resources in that and other areas of the Commissioner's Head Office.

It must also be said that the investigative resources of the Taxation Office were under tremendous strain when the major company stripping activity referred to in the Report occurred, i.e., in the 1977 and 1978 financial years. During those years, the promotion of a wide variety of tax avoidance schemes occurred on a large scale and recognition of the consequent overwhelming workload led, on the Commissioner's recommendation, and with my full support, to the establishment from early 1979 of a new Compliance Division within the Head Office of the Taxation Office.

The picture can best be illustrated by some figures that have recently become available. These figures indicate that in 1975-76 there were some 729 participants in avoidance (as distinct from evasion) schemes of the blatant, artificial or contrived kind and which the Commissioner of Taxation has challenged. The next year this figure had grown to 2,787 and in 1977-78 to 10, 295. For 1978-79 it stood at 8,653 but rose to 9,018 for 1979-80.

Other areas of the Taxation Office also had to cope with substantial and increasing workloads. Appeals staff have had to cope with a large upsurge of litigation at all appellate levels and in other areas of the administrative review processes. In addition to the traditional appeals work there was a substantial growth in the volume of other litigation.

A greater public awareness of the incidence of taxation brought about largely by increased media attention has led to an increasing propensity to challenge taxation assessments. For example, in the 3 year period 1 July 1977 to 30 June 1980, the Taxation Office received 46,032 requests to refer disputed assessments to Taxation Boards of Review and 1,404 requests to refer appeals to the Supreme, Federal and High Courts. Many of these cases were settled following discussions with the taxpayers concerned or their legal representatives. The substantial increase in litigation-requests for reference to Taxation Boards of Review, for example, increased from 2,446 in 1971 to 18,758 in 1980 (and further again to 19 ,386 in 1981)-was recently recognised by the Public Service Board by way of an increase in appeals staff, an increase I supported.
E ADMINISTRATIVE PROCESSES FROM 1978 UNDER THE OLD LAW
At an administrative level, the Australian Taxation Office continued to follow matters up where avenues for action appeared.

Thus in the case of Deputy Federal Commissioner of Taxation v Corwest Management Pty Ltd and Registrar of Titles 78 ATC 4388 the Commissioner sought recovery of tax by lodging a caveat in respect of land transferred by Kierad Pty Ltd to Corwest Management Pty Ltd in the period after issue of an assessment on Kierad Pty Ltd but before the date the amount owing became due and payable. Judgment for the amount owing had been obtained and registered before lodgment of the caveat. It was argued for the Commissioner that the judgment debt gave the Commonwealth an equitable charge over the land in question which could be the subject of a caveat. The Court rejected the Commissioner's argument.

In another action involving Kierad Pty Ltd, the Commissioner, through the liquidator of the stripped company, on 13 September 1979 obtained a court order under which a private examination under the Companies Act, followed by a public examination, was held of persons having knowledge of the company's affairs.

The purpose of this exercise was to establish the facts necessary for proper and full consideration to be given to prosecution action which might be taken against those responsible for the stripping of the company, in order to recover the amount of tax owing.

This case has remained uncompleted because of the Commissioner's inability, despite the assistance of the Australian Federal Police, to ascertain the whereabouts of relevant persons. Information was sought from the McCabe/ Lafranchi Inquiry but this was refused at the time on the grounds that the information could not be disclosed except in the Inquiry's Report.

In yet another case, first reported to the Taxation Head Office in June 1979 after the Deputy Commissioner concerned had detected it in April 1979, advice was sought from a Deputy Crown Solicitor in August 1979 regarding the possibility of instituting proceedings under the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Companies Act or the Commonwealth Crimes Act against one or more of the individuals responsible for the misappropriation of funds specifically set aside for payment of tax owed by the company.
Discussions ensued in August and November of that year between the Taxation Office and the Deputy Crown Solicitor regarding this matter.

Advice was received on 12 December 1979 from the Deputy Crown Solicitor that no offences could be established under the Crimes Act or the Assessment Act. The possibility that offences may have been committed by the directors or former directors of the stripped company under a provision of the State Crimes Act or section 374A (1) (c) of the Companies Act was mooted. However, the Deputy Crown Solicitor observed that prosecution of any officer or former officer of a company pursuant to either of the two sections would not result in any money being recovered for payment of the outstanding tax debt, and concluded that in any event it was unlikely that the essential ingredients of these offences could be established.

The Deputy Crown Solicitor did suggest that winding up proceedings could be instituted against the company but doubted whether such proceedings would have any beneficial effect in relation to the recovery of tax. Moreover, he considered action under section 367B of the Companies Act not to be advisable, in view of the costs involved, unless there appeared to be some real prospect of recovering money. He also commented that income tax secrecy provisions might well preclude the divulging to the liquidator or the Corporate Affairs authorities of some of the information obtained by the Taxation Office.

Nevertheless, the Commissioner decided to join in an action to have the stripped company wound up. To the Commissioner's knowledge, the Corporate Affairs Office temporarily ceased enquiries in relation to this company, inorder to give priority to another case. It is understood that the enquiries have now resumed and following interviews with the parties responsible consideration will be given by the Corporate Affairs authorities to the possibility of instituting prosecution actions.

Because of his continuing concern about the general matter, the Commissioner of Taxation again wrote to the Crown Solicitor in May 1980 about the first of the cases that I have outlined in this statement. The Commissioner indicated in his memorandum that the particular method of avoiding or evading the payment of tax by companies was continuing to be used quite extensively and was creating serious problems for the Taxation Office. The Crown Solicitor was asked if he would further examine arrangements of this kind for the purpose of advising whether, in his opinion, there was any reasonable basis for the possible application of section 367B of the Companies Act, section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act or section 5 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act. It was indicated to the Crown Solicitor that the particular case could be taken as typical of the case with which the Taxation Office was currently concerned.

The Crown Solicitor replied to this memorandum in September 1980. In his memorandum of advice he observed that what had been seen to be the particular deficiency when the matter was last looked at was that of evidence, namely, that there was insufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case of conspiracy to defraud, and this problem still remained.

As to possible action under section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Crown Solicitor pointed out that the time limit for prosecution under the section had then expired in that particular case. But he indicated that, even had it not, it would be 'difficult to imagine a court construing the section so as to impose, in criminal proceedings, more onerous restrictions on a taxpayer's activities than are to be found in the primary provisions relating to liability to tax'.
For similar reasons he was of the view that associated action under section 5 of the Crimes Act would not be productive.

In relation to action under section 367B of the Companies Act, the Crown Solicitor thought that the only transaction that could be likely to attract the operation of that section would involve proceeding against a 'man of straw'. For that reason the Crown Solicitor observed that action by the Commissioner to persuade the liquidator of the company to make an application under section 367B of the Companies Act would be likely to result in no substantial benefit.

In short, the Crown Solicitor's final advice in this representative case was not encouraging to the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers in their efforts to pursue the persons responsible for the stripping of the companies.

Generally, the Australian Taxation Office has proceeded as fast as resources and priorities have allowed with investigation and assessment of stripped companies in order to quantify the tax debt and take whatever recovery action is left open to it.

Where the companies have attempted to wind up before assessment or payment of taxes the Taxation Office has, wherever possible, intervened to keep the companies on the books and their records intact to enable the examination of possible actions available through the liquidator.

In extreme cases, court actions have been taken to remove liquidators who had been appointed and to replace them with persons nominated by the Taxation Office . Thus, in December 1980 the Crown Solicitor was asked to engage senior counsel to represent the Commissioner in some particular actions. He was also asked at the time for advice as to any additional remedies under the Income Tax Assessment Act, Crimes Act, Bankruptcy Act and the Companies Act which might assist recovery of tax.

Following receipt of the sought-for advice the following action was taken in respect of a number of the schemes, an intrinsic part of which involved the voluntary winding up of companies, following the stripping of current year profits:
(i) the Commissioner has intervened in the voluntary winding up of proceedings and secured undertakings or court orders deferring the final creditors' meetings ;
(ii) the previously-appointed liquidators have been removed, by the vote of creditors or court order, and new liquidators apointed;
(iii) the tax liability of each company has been admitted in the winding up-see for example Commonwealth of Australia v Duncan 81 ATC 4228;

(iv) a liquidator has been examined under Section 278 of the Companies Act (Vic .) before Crockett J in the Supreme Court of Victoria. In the judgment, handed down on 7 May 1982, the actions of the liquidator were severely criticised. Crockett J directed that they be brought to the attention of-
(a) the Attorney-General for the State of Victoria
(b) the Corporate Affairs Commission
(c) the Law Society
(d) the Companies Auditors Board
(e) the Attorney-General for the Commonwealth.

In yet another case the Taxation Office decided in November 1980, on the basis of senior counsel's opinion, given in a similar case, to petition the Supreme Court of Western Australia for an order to wind up the company. Section 293 of the Companies Act, in conjunction with Section 122 of the Bankruptcy Act, could then, perhaps, be relied on to set aside the transaction stripping the company of funds on the grounds that it was a preferential distribution by the company.
The Court ordered that the company be wound up and appointed a liquidator in April 1981.

Soon after the winding up of that company the Commissioner decided to ask the Deputy Crown Solicitor to obtain an Opinion from senior counsel on the avenues open to him, including the options available under the income tax law, the Companies Act, the Crimes Act and the Property Law Act 1969-1973 (WA). Counsel's Opinion on whether the secrecy provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act would inhibit such action was also sought.

After interviewing a number of 'elusive' persons, who had participated in the stripping arrangements, in an attempt to elicit all the facts about the diminution in the company's assets, the matter was referred by the Taxation Office to the Deputy Crown Solicitor early in 1982.

The accounts in immediately preceding paragraphs concern liquidation and associated action in cases where a company strip has associated with it a tax avoidance scheme of some kind. Cases that are bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, i.e ., simple evasion of payment of company tax have not themselves yet reached the stage where action has been taken to institute liquidation proceedings. A large amount of work on representative cases having been carried out the relevant Deputy Crown Solicitor was on 2 June 1982 asked to seek legal advice from senior counsel before wide-scale action is launched. Further information was subsequently supplied to counsel. Legal and other issues relevant to the conduct of that action have, of course, been clarified by the already instituted liquidation proceedings that have been referred to.
All of these actions have been designed to make the best of a situation given legal advice that offered no encouragement that effective prosecution could be mounted.

There are, as appears from the Report, views to the effect that there are grounds for prosecution action, although the published Report does not instance under what Commonwealth provisions prosecutions should be launched.

Such views were put in relation to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill at the time of its introduction and were the subject of a response from the Government' s advisers, tabled by me in the House of Representatives. That response is attached to this statement (Attachment B), and I draw attention to the fact that its conclusions, that there were not then available effective and adequate legal sanctions, were unanimously subscribed to by the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, the Acting First Parliamentary Counsel and his officers, senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Taxation Office.

Whichever of the two groups of views be the correct one, the key point in relation to the gravamen of the charge being levelled against the Australian Taxation Office is that it acted, as it was entitled to act, on the basis of Crown Law advice and even then, as I have shown, the Taxation Office did not simply ask for advice and receive it-having received unfavourable advice it pressed the matter with its legal advisers, only to have that advice confirmed.

On a related point, but in similar vein, the Crown Law advice in the particular case taken as a representative one had much to do with what was seen to be an insufficiency of evidence. The Report (page 28) observes 'No doubt, one can rightfully assume if that Office (The Taxation Office) had ascertained all facts published in this report, a prosecution would have been instituted.' But it also goes on to observe that there may be some explanation in the fact that the power of a special investigator under the Companies Act is wider than the power of a taxation officer.
As to that, it is a fact of life that in recent years taxation investigators have found their efforts to obtain information come under increasing challenge.

The Commissioner of Taxation observed in his Annual Report to Parliament on 29 October 1981 that promoters of schemes, having increasingly surrounded them with secrecy, were strengthening their endeavours to frustrate investigative action.

The difficulties faced by taxation officers are evidenced by the facts that have been placed before the High Court during its hearing of the case, O'Reilly and Others v The Commissioners of the State Bank of Victoria and Others. In this case, investigation officers, who on previous days had been given access to documents relating to a taxpayer's affairs at a branch of the State Bank of Victoria, were on a subsequent day denied access which would have enabled them to complete their inquiries at that branch. On the latter occasion, officers of the bank refused a request to unlock a door of a storeroom in which relevant documents were thought to be and also refused to specifically state where the documents could be found.

The Report refers (page 23) to views attributed early in 1980 to the Acting Commissioner of Taxation, to the effect that the real cure of the 'company dumping' problem lay with tighter Corporate Affairs Commission regulation. The views attributed to the Acting Commissioner were apparently taken from a press report, and were not the subject of any inquiry by Messrs McCabe or Lafranchi of the persons concerned. I regard it as a very serious matter to attribute to the Taxation Office a particular administrative attitude on the basis of a press report, unsupported by any investigation as to its accuracy or the context in which it was made.
In any event, I am quite satisfied that the Australian Taxation Office at no stage refrained from action against company stripping because it thought the matter was one for company law.
The Commissioner of Taxation said in his Annual Report to Parliament, tabled on 18 September 1980, referring to the then state of company stripping activity:

'An alarming tactic much in evidence during 1979-80 is stripping companies or trusts of their available assets without making provision for payment of tax assessed or to be assessed. This makes use of legal forms and procedures but would be regarded by most as pure tax evasion not really capable of passing under the euphemism of ''avoidance''.

Companies or trusts with current year profits are denuded of assets in a way which completely disregards the rights of creditors or potential creditors. This action is the more egregious when members of the company resolve to place it in voluntary liquidation before an income tax assessment can be issued so that early destruction of records may be achieved. This tactic is used either as a primary or sole means of avoiding the payment of taxation that is due or as a back-up method of escaping from any possible liability in cases in which the company has participated in a tax avoidance scheme the efficacy of which has not been finally tested.'
F THE POSITION AFTER THE CRIMES (TAXATION OFFENCES) ACT

A matter of considerable concern to me has been the claim in the report that company stripping activity still continues after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and the inference that, again, the Australian Taxation Office has failed or omitted to respond and to follow-up the apparent breaches of the new Act.

The Report (page 28) refers in this regard to 'continuing notification' at the Victorian Corporate Affairs Office of particulars for directors and registered office addresses believed to be false or misleading.

From advice that I have from the Australian Taxation Office, and from my own contacts with legal and accounting practitioners, I believe the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act not to have been a failure, but a conspicuous success.

For example, the Commissioner has told me that a particular person, not mentioned in the Report, who had been very active prior to the Act in stripping companies (his activities were the subject of figures given by me when the legislation was introduced) was on all the evidence available immediately put out of business.

It is to be noted that the 923 companies that were the subject of the Report were stripped well before the Act commenced. An analysis of the Report shows that the shares in the stripped companies were sold by the vendor/shareholders in the following financial years:

Following the enactment of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act the Commissioner of Taxation issued instructions to his Deputy Commissioners in which taxation officers were asked to be alert to anything that might suggest that there may have been a breach of the Act. The Head Office instruction, sent on 19 December 1980, contains this paragraph:

''Legislation of this kind has, and is intended to have, a deterrent function. It is to be hoped that the mere existence of the criminal penalties that it contains will deter people from being involved in the kind of activities against which it is directed. If it does not, then early detection and vigorous and successful prosecution of offenders should have the desired effect. More than that, if people concerned remain aware of the legislation and are conscious that authorities concerned are alert to any possible breaches of it, the deterrent effect of the legislation will be maintained.''

To this date, and subject to the exceptions that follow, the Australian Taxation Office has not, despite being alert for such indications, become aware of evidence of or pointers to continued company stripping activity of the '' bottom-of-the-harbour'' type.

Plainly, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act immediately had a telling effect in curbing the kind of evasion activity against which the Act is directed. In that situation, the Australian Taxation Office effected its alert by maintaining a number of monitoring avenues that would help to bring to light any continuing stripping of untaxed company profits.

For example, Taxation Office forms notifying changes in the identity of the '' public officer'' of companies that had been paying income tax were checked. A range of documents lodged at the Office of Corporate Affairs was routinely monitored by taxation officers.

Some information, drawn to the attention of the Taxation Office only in the last few weeks and since then the subject of investigation by it, has revealed some cases of post-3 December 1980 stripping of untaxed company profits. The information comes from the Royal Commission into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters' and Dockers Union. With the aid of that information, taxation investigations have, since the Report, revealed that three New South Wales and two Queensland companies were stripped of untaxed profits after the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act 1980.
Two of the companies were stripped after the commencement of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

There were, from the same source, another nine cases that warranted further investigation. Enquiries into them have indicated that all but one of the nine companies were not stripped of untaxed profits after the enactment of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. The exception relates to a small amount of rental income which would be taxable if the particular company were denied a deduction claimed by it for prior year losses.

The identified cases are being investigated and followed up on a top priority basis by the Australian Taxation Office which will, as soon as its initial taxation work is completed, refer the cases to the Australian Federal Police for investigation with a view to the initiation of prosecutions under the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act.

There are, of course, the matters mentioned in the Report. It refers, on page 28, to continuing notifications at the Victorian Corporate Affairs Office of apparently false or misleading particulars indicative, in the view of the authors, of continuing company stripping activities. I observe that the Report was presented to the Victorian Government in November 1981, and the situation of which it speaks is thus a situation at least some 7 months old.

On the Monday following the publication of the Report (i.e., on 31 May 1982) the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Melbourne sought from the Corporate Affairs Office particulars of the matters referred to in the Report. In response , he received on 9 June 1982 a computer-prepared listing as at 31 May 1982 of the names of a number of companies, the list of addresses representing in the words of the Commissioner for Corporate Affairs in Victoria 'a list of addresses which were considered to warrant further investigation'.

Since then the Taxation Office has been engaged in the very considerable work of following up the leads provided by this list. Its enquiries, completed on 18 June, reveal that none of the 1,376 cases involves stripping of untaxed company profits after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980.

Apart from this source, the only cases identified to the Commissioner of Taxation that may have formed the basis of the observations in the Report are those of three companies in relation to which there was, in the middle of 1981, notification at Corporate Affairs of changes in the identity of company office- holders. On the best information now available none of these companies was stripped of untaxed profits after the Act.

One was stripped well before, and the August 1981 notification of changes in office-holders represents simply a 'cleaning up of paper-work' operation. The change in office-holders for the other two companies, notified in May 1980, is of a change occurring on 1 December 1980, i.e., a few days before the Act was passed.

I add that some further possible leads are currently being followed up by the Taxation Office, and appropriate action will be taken as and when necessary. However, on all the experience of the many time and resource-consuming trails that the Taxation Office has had to follow in recent weeks in investigating suggestions that there have, after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, been strips of untaxed company profits the Commissioner is most confident that very few, if any, such strips will be found as a consequence.

To summarise then, there are only five identified cases of post-3 December 1980 company strips (none of them in Victoria), with no more than a possibility that others may exist. It is of course a matter of concern that there should be any such activity after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, but it represents no sense of complacency to observe that if there are a handful of cases, such numbers are hardly indicative of a failure of the Act.
To reduce company strips from their heyday levels, which plainly has happened, is a remarkable achievement. As I have said already, the legislation has been a conspicuous success.
Nor can the existence of the handful of cases, only recently revealed, constitute any reflection on the Australian Taxation Office and its compliance activities.

I have referred already to monitoring activities that the Taxation Office employed after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, and noted that these extend to inspections at the Office of Corporate Affairs.

For quite some time, there have been very co-operative working arrangements between the office of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Melbourne and the Office of the Commissioner of Corporate Affairs. Taxation officers regularly visit the Corporate Affairs Office to scrutinize a range of documents passing through it. The range and volume of the documents does of course impose practical limitations on the extent to which taxation officers can make examinations of corporate affairs documents. But, as I have indicated, taxation officers have not in the course of that scrutiny come across anything of the kind to which Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi refer.

I do not put it at the forefront but I do observe that there were, in the context of the liaison arrangements, opportunities for corporate affairs officers to bring any matters of present relevance to the attention of the taxation liaison officers. This was not done.
In any event, there has still been nothing revealed from the Corporate Affairs Office in Melbourne that would make good the contentions on page 28 of the Report.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that it was known unofficially to some taxation officers in October 1980 that the Victorian Corporate Affairs Office had a facility to produce a computer-prepared listing of cases that, on the basis of names and addresses, might warrant follow-up action. The officers came into possession of such a list at that time-a list, I stress, that covered periods prior to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act-but, regrettably, did not see that if the Taxation Office were to obtain such lists on a continuing basis they might help to monitor the situation after the Act.

The Corporate Affairs Office itself did not, before 9 June 1982, supply any further listings to the Taxation Office. However, even if it had, either of its own initiative or on Taxation Office request, it appears in the event that the listings would not have contained actual evidence of continued stripping of untaxed company profits after the Act although, as the Commissioner of Taxation has pointed out, they would have been a source of evidence of such cases if any existed.

The preceding discussion, in responding to comments in the McCabe/Lafranchi Report, focuses on possible avenues of enquiry or information at the Office of Corporate Affairs. That focus does, however, tend to distort the overall picture , which is that corporate affairs records are not the only means, nor are they arguably the best means, of detecting any post- 3 December 1980 bottom-of-the- harbour schemes.

For example, a major promoter of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes based in another State but with operations extending throughout Australia, made it a practice not to lodge at the Office of Corporate Affairs the requisite documents indicating changes in shareholdings of companies and their officers.

In relation to the question of indicators, available in the past, of continuing bottom-of-the-harbour strips I think that the Premier of Victoria has done everyone, himself included, a disservice by referring to the advertisements for the acquisition of companies that appeared after the advent of the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act. I think that the Premier himself now realises that these advertisements did not relate to bottom-of-the-harbour strips. They concerned stripping of company profits that had already borne company tax.

Whatever views people choose to take of past events, the Australian Taxation Office is, as I have said, following up the various matters and, should its taxation enquiries reveal possible breaches of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, it will, under the guidance of Crown Law authorities, have the matter referred immediately to the Australian Federal Police for appropriate action.

It is relevant to the present situation that not only is company stripping a Commonwealth offence, under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, but any person who sells his or her shares as part of such a scheme is liable to tax under Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The Part IVA legislation, introduced by me into the Parliament on 27 May 1981 and made effective in relation to schemes entered into after that day would make a vendor shareholder liable not only to tax on his or her share of stripped company profits, but also subject to statutory penalty tax of 200 per cent of that amount of tax.

The effect of this further legislation is that the persons who stand to profit most by company stripping activities-the vendor shareholders-also stand to pay heavily for any involvement in such activities. That proposition applies both to bottom-of-the-harbour strips and strips of taxed company profits.

I add that I had earlier been informed by the Commissioner of Taxation of action by his Office to raise assessments against companies that had been stripped of pre-tax profits before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 commenced to operate. That action is continuing but, in the case of those stripped companies whose records have been destroyed, it obviously involves some very great difficulties.

The Commissioner is not optimistic that this action will result in significant collections of the tax sought to be evaded and he expects that it will ultimately be necessary to formally write off as irrecoverable the great bulk of the tax assessed to these companies.

It is the Commissioner's intention that, in pursuance of his statutory obligation to report annually to the Parliament on the working of the income tax law, he will name in his report the companies concerned.
The Commissioner expects that that action will bring to the Parliament's attention the identity of a significantly wider group of company stripping participants than has been revealed in the Report.
G CONCLUSION

I say in conclusion that there are some unfortunate things about the Report, its release and subsequent treatment. Of particular concern is the fact that as appears on page 25 of the Report, the authors sought no facts or comments from the Taxation Office and admit that for that reason the opinions they expressed were necessarily based on limited factual data.

Their reference to the secrecy provisions of the income tax law does not justify that omission. While the secrecy provisions do forbid unauthorised disclosure of taxation information the Commissioner of Taxation would readily have explained to Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi had they approached him, his general administrative approach in cases of this nature. In particular, he would have explained how he had been seeking the institution of legal action with a view to persons concerned being brought to book.

I do feel that the Report has been unfair in its treatment of the Australian Taxation Office and of the dedicated people in it. No one should overlook the difficulties and frustrations that attach to the work they do on behalf of the community. They are to be thanked for their work.
The Government, for its part, has a record of challenge and response to tax avoidance and evasion that is not open to reasonable criticism.

I repeat that it would be a very brave man or women who, in the light of this Government's Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act and Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, would now venture into any company strip.

There are, of course, some lessons to be learned from this episode. I believe that all authorities concerned will renew their vigilance. I have said already, and now repeat, that the Government does not seek to close the book on pre- December 1980 events. If on a further review of the relevant facts and law the appropriate legal authorities conclude that prosecution ought to be launched, then that will be done.
