Attachment B
CRIMES (TAXATION OFFENCES) BILL 1980
(Advice to the Treasurer, Tabled by him in the House of Representatives on 4 December 1980)
Retrospectivity

Messrs Russell and Davies suggest that the Bill could, in conjunction with legislation that is enacted to overcome particular tax avoidance arrangements but is made to apply from an earlier date (e.g., the date of the Treasurer's statement foreshadowing the anti-avoidance legislation), operate to make it a crime to undertake activity that was not a crime under the law in force when the activity was carried out.

That cannot happen under the Bill. It could only happen when such anti- avoidance legislation is enacted in the future, and only then if the other elements of the proposed offences exist and the anti-avoidance legislation is so drafted that its effect in back-dating tax liability is applicable in relation to the requirement in the Bill that the actions of the accused must relate to tax that is or becomes legally payable.

The time to consider this matter is when such anti-avoidance legislation is brought forward. At that time the choice will lie between, on the one hand, respecting the convention that statutes ought not to have retrospective penal effect and, on the other, giving weight to the fact that adherence to the convention would soon signal that, between the dates when anti-avoidance legislation is foreshadowed and when it enters into force, activity to strip a company of its capacity to pay could be freely undertaken.

The Law Institute proposes that Parliamentary consideration of the Bill be deferred until the autumn. Doing that would, as the Bill stands (i.e., entry into force on date of Assent), represent an open invitation to strip companies and trusts for the next two or three months. Any action to make the legislation, when enacted in the autumn, effective from the present time would however contravene the convention that penal statutes should not be retrospective.
Liability of professional advisers

The Law Institute and Messrs Russell and Davies represent that professional advisers will be exposed to criminal prosecution and penalty for carrying out their ordinary work as tax advisers. That is certainly not the position.

A professional adviser will be no more exposed than any other citizen who has the same involvement in an arrangement as does the professional adviser. In other words, any criticism of the Bill's likely effect on professional advisers must be a criticism of the basic elements of the proposed offences. Such criticisms are dealt with under the heading 'elements of the offences'.
Clause 6 is the relevant provision. Sub-section (1) is in the terms:
'(1) Where a person-
(a) directly or indirectly, aids, abets, counsels or procures another person ( including a company) to enter into an arrangement or transaction; or
(b) is, in any way, by act or omission, directly or indirectly concerned in, or party to, the entry by another person (including a company) into an arrangement or transaction,
knowing or believing . . .'.
This provision bears very fair comparison with section 5 of the Crimes Act 1914 -

'5. Any person who aids, abets, counsels or procures, or by act or omission is in any way directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in, or party to, the commission of any offence against any law of the Commonwealth, whether passed before or after the commencement of this Act, shall be deemed to have committed that offence and shall be punishable accordingly.'.
Certificate of Commissioner as evidence
Comments under this head relate to clause 10, which Garrick Gray & Co describe as 'the most undesirable feature of the Bill'. The comments are misconceived.

The essence of the point of criticism is that, against the background that it is an element of each offence that tax be or becomes payable, a certificate by the Commissioner (or a Second Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner) may be tendered and made conclusive evidence that tax is payable, when it has not been finally determined that tax is payable. The Law Institute of Victoria says that 'the Commissioner' can, by such a certificate, secure a conviction even though it is subsequently held by the courts that no tax was in fact payable.

The purpose of clause 10 is set out on page 16 of the explanatory memorandum and is, in brief, to ensure that questions of tax liability are to be determined only in the conventional processes of objection, review by a Taxation Board of Review and/or appeal to a court. Tax liability alleged by the Commssioner to exist may be challenged by the taxpayer concerned, but only in that conventional way.

The key answer to the criticism is clause 11. If a prosecution is brought while relevant tax liability has not been finally determined then the magistrate in committal proceedings, or the court at the trial, must stay the proceedings. The courts are thus given a clear direction by the legislation not to allow a prosecution to go ahead if tax liability has not been finally determined.

Mr Forsyth Q.C. suggests (in effect) that 'it is probable' that the mandatory stay of proceedings provided for by clause 11 would be overridden by section 177 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which makes production of a copy of a notice of assessment conclusive evidence of the assessment.

This is just not so. Clause 11 clearly makes a stay of proceedings mandatory if it appears to the court that tax liability has not been finally determined. Section 177 has no application in these circumstances.
The Commissioner as prosecutor

Against the background of allegations about reactions by the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers to recent tax avoidance practices it is suggested that the Commissioner may be overbearing in use or purported use of the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Bill.
The offences proposed by the Bill are indictable offences. Section 69 (1) of the Judiciary Act 1903 provides:

'(1) Indictable offences against the laws of the Commonwealth shall be prosecuted by indictment in the name of the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of such other person as the Governor-General appoints in that behalf.'.

No taxation officer holds an appointment under section 69. The officers who do hold such appointments by the Governor-General are the Crown Solicitor, Deputy Crown Solicitors and certain other senior legal officers of the Attorney-General 's Department.

The institution of committal proceedings before a magistrate is not similarly restricted. However, it has never been contemplated that a magistrate would be asked to commit a person for trial under the legislation except by an information laid by those legal officers of the Attorney-General's Department who have the responsibility of instituting proceedings for alleged breaches of Commonwealth laws and who had come to the conclusion that, on the evidence available, a prima facie case existed.
Adequacy of existing laws

Both sets of legal opinions seek to dispute that there is a need for further legislation to deal with straw company tax evasion and suggest that adequate remedies are already available under existing criminal law, taxation law and laws applying generally to companies in both the State and Commonwealth jurisdictions.

This advice is very firmly contradicted by the views of the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, the acting First Parliamentary Counsel and his officers, senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department, and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Taxation Office. Those officers, who have carefully examined what might be the scope of existing law to overcome these practices, are unanimous that no effective and adequate legal sanction is currently available. Persons known to be operating the schemes do so quite openly and must be taken to share this view. It can be safely assumed that their apparent confidence is founded on the basis of legal opinions.
Offences under company law

The opinions supplied by the Law Institute cite sections 67, 114, 124, 367B, 374C and 374G of the uniform companies Acts as being relevant. As a general observation, it may be noted that State company law is not in any event the appropriate vehicle for countering frauds against the Commonwealth. State authorities responsible for following up apparent breaches of company law have their own policies and priorities and the plain fact is that they have not launched prosecutions against people known by the Commissioner of Taxation to be involved. Secrecy provisions of the taxation law are an obstacle to the Commissioner providing relevant information to State authorities.
There is also the very important drawback that company law is limited to actions in relation to companies, whereas 'straw' arrangements also operate in relation to trusts.
That difficulty aside, each of the sections referred to by counsel can be seen to have shortcomings such as to render it, at best, of only marginal assistance-

Section 67-This is a comparatively minor offence and forbids a company to finance the purchase of its own shares. It would not apply to the major straw company operator who does not need to rely on the funds of victim companies when acquiring their shareholdings. Courts rarely register convictions under the section and when they do the penalties imposed are nominal (maximum penalty is 3 months gaol or $1,000 fine-invariably a small fine results).

Section 114-Although referred to by Messrs Russell and Davies this section appears to be irrelevant to the subject. It merely imposes a maximum $200 fine on a company that does not have the requisite number of directors.

Section 124-This imposes a duty on directors to act honestly and with reasonable diligence. Being applicable only to directors the section is of little use; in particular it is of no avail against promoters who keep themselves detached from formal participation in the company's affairs. It is also useless where the installed directors are men of straw. In any event, it carries a maximum penalty of a $2,000 fine which is of no deterrent effect when compared with the large sums at stake in straw company operations.

Section 367B-This section deals with misfeasance by officers of a company and allows a court to assess damages against delinquent officers. Again, this provision cannot be used against entrepreneurs who do not take a direct hand in the management of a company nor, effectively, against ''straw'' directors. There is the further limitation that the section is generally restricted to situations where a company is in liquidation or under an official manager or receiver. Applications to a court for an order against a delinquent officer are ordinarily made by liquidators who can be expected to be unwilling to make application unless a substantial benefit to creditors is likely to result.

Section 374C (1) provides for it to be an offence for an officer of a company to be knowingly a party to the contracting of a debt where there are no reasonable grounds of expectation that the debt will be paid. This suffers the obvious flaw of being restricted to the 'contracting of a debt', which is not apt to include incurring of a tax liability (3 months imprisonment or $500 fine) .

Section 374C (2) covers the offence of carrying on the business of a company with intent to defraud creditors or for any fraudulent purpose. It is not clear whether the offence would be committed in circumstances where the business of a company has been brought to an end. Again it is unavailable against scheme operators who formally stand aside from active participation in the company's affairs. The maximum penalties are 1 year's imprisonment or a $2,500 fine.

Section 374G-This is the nearest comparable company law provision which makes it an offence for an officer of a company, with intent to defraud creditors, to be a party to a reduction (by gift, transfer or charge) in the property of a company. It is also an offence to sell or remove company property, with intent to defraud creditors after or within 2 months before an unsatisfied judgment for payment of money owed by the company.
Section 374G does not in practice, however, meet the situations that the tax measures necessarily deal with:

Like section 374G the tax offence will apply to officers of a company (broadly directors, secretaries and employees) but the tax offence will apply also to other parties to the arrangement who have the proscribed purpose.
Section 374G is limited to officers of companies while the tax provision applies also to trustees and their employees and agents.

Paragraph (b) of section 374G is limited to diminution of assets by gift, transfer or charge. However, in straw company tax evasion the most common arrangements are those under which the assets of a company are stripped by way of loan to an associate or are 'invested' in things such as over-priced redeemable shares.

Paragraph (c) of section 374G, being limited to concealment or removal of assets, could not deal with the 'lending' and 'investing' arrangements mentioned above. The fact that the section is limited to acts after, or within two months before, a court judgment would also rule out its effective use in relation to income tax debts where the stripping arrangements are likely to occur well before the tax is even assessed.
The penalty on conviction for an offence under section 374G is two years or $5, 000.
Offences under the Crimes Act

The only provision of the Commonwealth Crimes Act mentioned specifically in either of the opinions is section 86 which declares that it is an offence to conspire with another person (or persons) to defraud the Commonwealth. (There is also a common law offence of conspiracy, which generally encompasses the agreement of 2 or more persons to do an unlawful act.)

Section 86 is obviously very much in the mind of scheme operators who have organised their arrangements to minimise any risk of prosecution. They do this by ensuring that parties to straw company schemes know as little as possible of the overall arrangements. Vendor shareholders who take part in the overall arrangements take pains to not even know what happens to their company after it is sold. This renders difficult, to the point of impossibility, the prosecution' s task of showing that any alleged conspirators had the necessary 'common design '.

Conspiracy is an offence notoriously difficult to prove, even in blatant cases. In the area of 'white collar' crime it is difficult enough to show a guilty intention or knowledge in one person, but this difficulty is compounded when conspiracy must be proved.

Section 5 of the Crimes Act provides that aiding and abetting a person to commit an offence against the Commonwealth renders a person guilty of the same offence as the person aided and abetted commits, and subject to the same penalty .

The offence provisions of the Bill contain aiding and abetting offences in language that closely parallels section 5. The technical reason for having separate provisions in the Bill is because the principal straw company offences apply to behaviour of individuals and not companies.

Where a company is aided and abetted in a 'straw' arrangement section 5 could not operate in conjunction with the basic offence provisions of the Bill, because the company does not itself commit the basic offence.

There is also advantage in having the aiding and abetting offences contained in the same Act as the principal offences to which they relate. There is implied acceptance in the opinions now under discussion of the concept that legal and accounting advisers should be subject to criminal law aiding and abetting provisions. The Bill does not go beyond that concept.
Offences under State criminal law

Counsel have also mentioned State criminal law as an avenue for redress, but have not referred specifically to any particular provisions as being the ones they had in mind. Officers are unaware of any State criminal law measures that provide any real assistance. (So, it can be certain, are the promoters and others involved.) Certainly, the State laws contain aiding and abetting provisions in relation to offences against State law. But again it is first necessary to show that the person aided, etc., commits an offence against the State law. The difficulties in meeting that prerequisite have already been demonstrated.
Income Tax Assessment Act provisions
The only provision in point is section 231 which makes it an offence to avoid or attempt to avoid assessment or taxation.

This provisions has the fatal defect that it is framed so as to render the company itself subject to a pecuniary penalty-quite pointless when the company is devoid of assets. In any event, it is very doubtful whether the section applies to schemes to prevent collection of tax, being expressed in terms that strongly suggest it is limited to evasion of tax liability.
General

The opinions also refer to existing support for prosecution being available under other general laws, e.g., bankruptcy and common law. No particular offences were mentioned apart from conspiracy which has been discussed earlier. It is difficult to see how the Bankruptcy Act which deals only with cases of individual insolvency can assist in relation to straw company matters.

The foregoing brief analysis makes it plain that the existing remedies are inadequate to deal with the situation. That is hardly surprising since the provisions discussed were drafted before the emergence of the sophisticated straw company and straw trust arrangements now being encountered.

Even with the enactment of the present Bill, which is addressed directly to countering these activities, it can be expected that the evidentiary burdens on the prosecution in proving its case beyond reasonable doubt will prove to be very substantial indeed.
Elements of the offences

At the heart of each proposed offence are two related elements. For a person to be guilty of an offence he must run foul of at least one of these plus, of course, the other ingredients of each offence.
The two related elements are-
(i) reducing a company's or trustee's capacity to pay tax and
(ii) securing a company's or trustee's inability to pay.

The element of securing inability to pay does not seem to need explanation, but the criticisms now under response have attached the concept of 'reducing capacity to pay'. That concept is a necessary complement to the 'securing inability to pay' concept because if securing inability to pay were the only element there is at least a risk that the provisions would only reach cases where from the outset there was a lack of capacity (as happens in some of the sales tax schemes). To cover the cases-and these are in the majority-where a company could have paid its tax but for what followed, the second element of reducing capacity is required. Its presence in the legislation also facilitates coverage of situations where the stripping leaves some residual amount of funds sufficient to pay a part of the tax.

Parliamentary Counsel are satisfied that the expression 'reducing capacity to pay' must be interpreted as meaning a real reduction in capacity-it will not be the case, as has been implied, that every payment out of the assets of a company will fall into this description. There is not thought to be any doubt that the courts will read and apply the provisions that way.

In the company law area, in relation to the company law offence of contracting a debt where there is no reasonable or probable expectation that the company will be able to satisfy the debt (section 374C), the courts have had to come to grips with what is meant by ability to pay. It appears from relevant decisions that the courts approach that task in a flexible and realistic way and will take into account not merely the company's asset position but such factors as its ability to borrow or obtain other financial assistance.

In other words, reducing capacity to pay is not, as the Law Institute seems to put it, a mere matter of reducing assets. Far from it. A company officer who writes a company cheque for $10,000 thereby may reduce company assets but he does nothing to the company's capacity to pay its tax if the company overall remains in funds to pay the tax. And even if the company were in financial stress the payment of $10,000 would not reduce capacity to pay if it related to acquisition of assets of equivalent value. Payment of an ordinary creditor's debt would not reduce capacity to pay-capacity to pay would have been affected ( if at all) by the incurring of the debt in the first place. As the company law authorities suggest, the question of whether an arrangement or transaction does involve reduction in capacity to pay must be judged on the basis of an overall view of the company's ability to discharge its debts.

In all of what counsel have written the impression is conveyed that the new provisions carry a real risk of injustices being done, with people being convicted and gaoled in circumstances where no criminal activity had been carried out. The truth lies in quite the opposite direction.

The Crown Solicitor and other legal officers emphasise that before a prosecution can succeed the Crown will have to discharge very substantial evidentiary burdens in proving every element of an offence beyond reasonable doubt. This task includes the proving of the necessary subjective elements related to the mental state of a person charged.

Under clause 5, for example, it will be necessary to prove beyond reasonable doubt that a person had a purpose of reducing a company's capacity to pay tax or of securing its inability to pay tax. Alternatively, under clause 7, it will be necessary to prove the proscribed knowledge or belief of a person in entering into an arrangement.

From the outset of this exercise senior legal officers of the Commonwealth have been pointing to the very real evidentiary difficulties that prosecutors face in proving the mental element in 'white collar' crimes. Given the complexity and sophistication of the latest arrangements to strip companies and trusts those difficulties will be no less troublesome for prosecutors in relation to these new provisions. To the extent that arrangements are aimed at defeating collection of 'future' tax, i.e., tax that might reasonably be expected to become payable, the problems of proving the subjective elements of the offence are compounded-in favour of the accused-by the complex nature of the taxation law itself.

Far from working against accused persons as the opinions imply, the complexity of the general tax law gives opportunities for straw company promoters to colour their real intentions. A number of schemes have come under notice where a tax avoidance scheme is superimposed on stripping arrangements that ensure that tax cannot be paid if the avoidance scheme is ineffective. In such situations the task of showing beyond reasonable doubt that the parties did not expect the avoidance scheme to work would be added to the prosecutor's difficulties.

These considerations are also relevant in relation to the position of professional advisers under the aiding and abetting provisions. Contrary to the opinion of Messrs Russell & Davies, the Crown Solicitor is firmly of the view that courts would not register a conviction on anything less than proof beyond reasonable doubt of the requisite subjective knowledge or belief of what was being sought to be achieved by the client.

Similarly, the suggestion that a person might be convicted because of a tax liability stemming from a subsequent change in the taxation law made by a court decision is untenable. The fact that the requisite purpose, knowledge or belief must be demonstrated as at the time of entry into an arrangement becomes more difficult rather than less difficult. It would be only in an exceptional case that it could be expected to be shown that the outcome of the court decision on the tax liability question had been anticipated by the parties to a company stripping operation if, but for the decision, no tax liabiity would have arisen.

Finally, it is being said that the legislation could, if interpreted widely, impinge on quite ordinary business transactions. This is an allegation frequently made about tax legislation but history is not on its side. Look at section 260, for instance.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for its refusal to remove Ministers who have failed to accept responsibility in their administrations when fraud, corruption and negligence have been found to exist.

I move this motion because the Standing Orders of the House limit the initiatives which the Opposition can take in any effort designed to bring properly to account a government seeking to evade responsibility. This Government, the most scandal-ridden government in the history of this nation, is now beset by a scandal that far exceeds anything in either its term of office or in the history of Australian national government.

The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) today sought to reduce Question Time to a low farce. Three questions were directed to the Prime Minister. They concerned matters central to an issue of great concern leaving the community alarmed at the level of administration by the Fraser Government. In all respects the Prime Minister sought to evade any responsibility in these matters, responding that in some time in the hereafter-God alone knows when that might be-there may be access to relevant documents under the Freedom of Information Act when and if-I stress if-it is proclaimed. That is no resolution to the problems that beset this Government and disturb the Australian community. Ordinary Australians cherish standards of decency in the conduct of their daily affairs. They are appalled at the standards this Fraser Government is seeking to establish because of the way in which it has behaved in the past.

Look at the questions which were asked. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) had made a declaration in a Press statement in late June-a quite compendious Press statement-which was at diametrical odds with what the Prime Minister was seeking to assert today. The Prime Minister and more recently the Treasurer in this Parliament sought to evade real responsibility and accountability for matters relating to tax evasion-which I repeat is a criminal offence and, I add, rampant within the higher echelons of the Liberal Party-by invoking section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Later, in late June, the Treasurer, as I indicated today in my question to the Prime Minister, made it abundantly clear that those secrecy provisions-or privacy provisions as they should be more accurately defined-were nowhere near as strict as he is now interpreting them. In fact, he sought to claim then, when seeking to pour scorn and contumely on the McCabe- Lafranchi report, that if McCabe and Lafranchi had approached him or the Taxation Office they would have had access in general terms to matters related to tax evasion.

Now as a matter of convenience, when their hides are on fire, they are declaring that section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act will now allow no such thing. That is sheer nonsense. It is a deceit. It is designed quite dishonestly to mislead this Parliament. The same applies to the joint management review report. That ought to be tabled. I have here before me, on the centre table, extracts from that report. It does not glibly brush aside the deficiencies of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office as the Prime Minister sought to do. More pertinently, the Prime Minister sought to slide around what is a crucial issue of conflict between, on the one hand, what the Treasurer claimed in late June in his Press statement in relation to the attitude of the Government and various departments, including the Australian Taxation Office, and, on the other hand, the view put by Royal Commissioner Costigan in relation to the attitude of the legal section of the Taxation Office.

The Commissioner declared in his published report that the legal section of the Taxation Office for a long time, measured not in days, weeks or months but in years, had been confused and could not understand why existing provisions of company law, the Crimes Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act and other related Acts were not applied in connection with tax evasion practices. He declared that he believed, as did a wide range of independent opinions of senior counsel which were made available to government departments, that those provisions could adequately be invoked for prosecution purposes against tax evaders. He said quite explicitly in his report that the legal section of the Taxation Office believed that this could be done. In late June the Treasurer-there can be only one construction of what he did-sought to mislead the Australian public and serving members of parliament by declaring to the contrary, by declaring that the legal section of the Taxation Office accepted the view of the Crown Solicitor's Office that existing provisions could not apply.

We are talking about the grimmest scandal that has confronted this Government in the period in which it has been in office since 1975. It is quite a scandal. No government has been confronted and wracked by more scandals that has this Government. Let me give honourable members its dimensions. Let us not brush away what we are talking about. We are not just talking about errant behaviour; we are talking about a dereliction of duty on the part of Ministers-the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) as the first law officer of the land and the culpability of the Treasurer, who is responsible for tax collections, for amounts which are estimated conservatively at between $10,000m and $15,000m. Let us look at what that money could have done for Australia. The total amount of payments and loan approvals to the States for this year is $15,000m. The whole of Australia at the State level could have had its affairs paid for by the accumulated losses through tax evasion which this Government and its two culpable Ministers presided over.

It is not just a matter of errant behaviour or shuffling of ministerial responsibility, a central principle to our system of government; it is a matter of the indolence of these Ministers giving accommodation to criminal activity. The criminal activity is organised crime. We are talking about organised crime by white collar masterminds, many of whom are members of the Liberal Party and many of whom have been identified as senior officials of the Liberal Party. Sure , the mercenary hoodlums and thugs provided by the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union were put out front to do the dirty work. But as Commissioner Costigan points out in his report-not the published one-they were regularly brought to account for their criminal behaviour. The white collar masterminds consistently evade their responsibilities. The white collar masterminds include, I repeat, some of the brightest and best that the Liberal Party has been able to produce.

The report talks about only one promoter. What happens when we come to Sydney and Melbourne which are the main focuses of the organisation of this sort of tax evasion? What happens when we discover the identity of the three eminent ' gentlemen'-I use the word 'gentlemen' rather loosely-who, as their reward for services to society, have been elevated to the peerage of the realm, who are well known as being involved in organised crime and who are making huge fortunes in this country? I do not have to identify them. They are well known to the Press Gallery. They are well known to the police, who have conveyed their identities to me.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is stung to retort. Let it retort on this: When the two unpublished volumes of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union are produced there will be some very embarrassed people very near the Premier of Queensland-people who have been elevated and who have waxed profitably as a result of the favour from the State Government in Queensland are some of the names we will hear about . It is a fortnight since the Costigan report was produced in this Parliament and the Government sinks deeper and deeper in the mud of scandal and dissension within its own ranks.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I thought I ought to inform you, Mr Speaker, that I will later be seeking to have incorporated in Hansard a letter from Mr Costigan, Royal Commissioner. —That point of contention between us can easily be cleared up. All the Prime Minister has to do is to give me authority to quote the names and I will give the House the background of those people. Let me continue. This Government sinks deeper and deeper in the mud of scandal and dissension which it heaps upon itself. Look at the past week. The Federal Executive of the Liberal Party, sullen in its resentment, merely noted what the Government intended to do in relation to retrospectivity in legislation affecting tax avoidance. Look at this quotation from the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: One source close to delegates from West Australia said: 'There's a long way between noting and approving what this Government is trying to do'.

Of course they do not approve it. The Liberal Party administration, at least extra-parliamentary, is absolutely corrupted by this sort of behaviour which the Prime Minister, by his description of it, has defined as criminal behaviour. Look at the events of last week. There was the extraordinary situation of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) declaring that an unnamed Minister had been cleared of unspecified charges; and he asked us to take the Government on trust in this matter. This Government is the least trustworthy government in the history of the Parliament. Scarcely a day went by last week when there was not a demand from the ranks of the Government that the Attorney- General resign. Senator Withers said: 'You should not start at the bottom with a few sacrifices aimed at taking the pressure off. You sack senior Ministers and senior public servants'. He said: 'Do you want poor Australian standards?' Read for 'poor Australian standards' 'Malcolm Fraser's standards'.

The honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey), who is enjoying his last days in this Parliament as it draws to a close, said that the Attorney-General had failed in his commission to administer his office and made it clear that the Attorney-General ought to resign. The honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr), also in the closing period of his parliamentary service, said quite bluntly that Senator Durack ought to resign. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said with a sort of vanity wave gush that there is only one conclusion under the Westminster system. We all know what that is-sack him, get rid of him. Where is the Treasurer while all this is going on? He has been shipped overseas like an unwanted remittance man. These are the standards of the Government at present. To top it off, the Age newspaper this morning on its front page had the latest episode of this shoddy behaviour. It outlined how even more companies involved in tax evasion had been organised by Mr Horgan. Who is Mr Horgan? He has been chief fund raiser for the Liberal Party in Western Australia, amongst his other duties.

I repeat that we are not talking about just some minor aberration of people who are perhaps misdirected but are not criminally intending to devise schemes to avoid their tax liability; we are talking about exercises which have been embarked upon quite consciously by people who have contrived them for the purpose of evading their clearly identifiable tax liability at law. That is a criminal offence. But honourable members need not take my word for it. On 30 August in South Australia, the Prime Minister had this to say:
In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.

Why did it take so many years for the Government to get active on this matter? What these people, these senior officials of standing in the Liberal Party, did was to make Ronald Biggs's audacious efforts pale into the modesty of gathering pocket money. In its own way this is a serious criminal offence. If a person blew a safe with the aim of picking up $10,000 or $20,000, the full and unrelenting force of the law would pursue him through the courts. He would go to gaol, and very properly. If someone broke into a house and stole the contents of the house, the full and unremitting force of the law would fall there too. That person would end up in gaol, again, very properly. But the proceeds from the offences that we are discussing today make those offences look like the gathering of spending money for a paper boy. These offences must be measured in thousands of millions of accumulated dollars which have made individual members of the Liberal Party multi-millionaires.

Let us look at the sorts of people who are involved. We have had them addressed to us before but let us look at them again. They include Bill Mitchell, special adviser to the Western Australian Liberal Party Premier-I wonder on what he advises-Ian Warner, Western Australian State President of the Liberal Party; Denis Byrne Horgan, chairman of the finance committee, who was drawn in for his special qualifications, I presume; Sid Corser, immediate past President of the Western Australian Liberal Party; and His Honour, the Australian High Commissioner in London, Sir Victor Garland-his activities were described in some detail by my colleague the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) in the last parliamentary sitting week so I shall not go through them. Andrew Tilt, Tasmanian Premier Gray's head of office, is involved in a little tickling of the petty cash can in this area. We discover in the newspapers today that the Government members in South Australia and a senior former member of the Liberal Party in New South Wales have also been involved. I am starting to wonder whether there is anybody in the Liberal Party who has not been drawn in.

What are the principles that guide these people? I think they were startlingly divulged a few weeks ago at Question Time in the Parliament when the Treasurer declared, I thought rather unwisely given all the information around to the contrary, that tax evasion was dead. He invoked for his authority Coopers and Lybrand. It so happened that I recalled that Coopers and Lybrand were cited in the McCabe-Lafranchi report as being the fiscal advisers to some group that was involved very heavily in tax evasion. When I pointed this out to the Treasurer, he said:

I was perfectly aware, when I gave the answer that I did, that Coopers and Lybrand were referred to in the McCabe report. I would have thought that the authority of people to speak on this subject had something to do with their practical knowledge and understanding of what has gone on in the tax avoidance industry. If one wants to understand what has happened in this area one should not confine one's examination to a reliance on the views of people who have absolutely no practical understanding of what goes on.

So now we understand the principle behind any announcement from the Government, should we hear it in the near future, that the new chairman of the national crimes commission will be Harry M. Miller. The facts are that this situation is out of the Prime Minister's control. Sure, the Prime Minister can declare that a special prosecutor's office will be set up, but that is trying to shut the door after the horse has bolted. He can talk about a crimes commission if he wishes and seek to infer that that is the preferred view of the Costigan Royal Commission. If that is so, he must have a different edition from both the published and non-published volumes of that report. My reading of the unpublished volume referring to this matter leads me to the understanding that Commissioner Costigan sees very serious defects and very real threats to people' s fundamental liberties in the American approach, as practised, to the crimes commission.

Let us look at some of the problems the Prime Minister has, and honourable members will understand why this matter is out of his control. One fundamental fact is that he cannot sack these Ministers as he ought to, and as he did when a miserable 200 bucks was involved in a television set. They were small beer; they were the minnows. He cannot sack these Ministers, much as he may want to if he has a grain of moral decency in him, for the basic reason that there are two National Country Party Ministers who presided over the greatest food scandal in the history of this country-the substitution of rotten donkey meat for first grade export beef. It may call for special skills to do that, skills over which only the National Country Party has a monopoly. The rest of Australia is not diverted and, even more certainly, it is not impressed. Those Ministers do not intend to stand down when their incompetence, glaring as it is, is finally established by an inquiry into this matter, a royal commission. How many royal commissions will this country be burdened with in the course of this parliamentary term investigating the grave deficiencies and gross incompetences of Ministers of the Fraser Government?

Another reason why this matter is out of the control of the Prime Minister is that his national Executive has declared solemnly that, while it notes his intentions, it will not support them in relation to retrospectivity of legislation in this area. What it is really saying by implication is: 'All the speculation in the newspapers may be right. Maybe you do want an early election. We can understand why, given the mess you have made of the Australian economy, given the dissatisfaction. Okay, get the election out of the way, and we will remind you that we just noted your intentions, we did not support them, and you will not be doing much about it'. Let us see the Horgans and the Corsers and the rest of them from the Liberal Party in the courts on criminal charges and going to gaol as they ought to.

The other question is this: What have Durack and Howard got on the Prime Minister and the Liberal Party that has made them frightened to act? Everyone knows why this sham fight has gone on for so many years in relation to tax avoidance and tax evasion. Everyone knows, but it has been made dramatically clear now, with the evidence publicly produced. They have been sham fighting because Liberals have been making money out of it. We have the curious situation where the Prime Minister will not sack the Attorney-General, but he will not defend him either. He does not want to talk about the Treasurer. That is why he has got him overseas. This is how committed he is to his Ministers in this mess of incompetence and bumbling which has been exposed. I quote from a report in last Saturday's Australian of a Press conference in which the Prime Minister was involved. He was asked:
Do you agree with Mr Peacock and Senator Withers that Senator Durack should resign?
The Prime Minister replied:
I'm not going to comment on that.
Then he added rather sourly:
I thought we weren't going to talk about this.
For good measure, he went on and clearly nailed his colours to the mast by saying:
If we are, this ends now.

What sort of Prime Minister is this who says his Ministers should not resign when ordinary Australians have been ripped off on this massive scale while the Government has been sitting on its hands like a dummy-a zombie government for the first time in the history of the nation. The Prime Minister refuses to give any explanation or defence. Who will be convinced by that sort of thing?

The issue is one of ministerial responsibility. If nothing else invoked moves our case-hardened colleagues opposite on the Government benches-we can understand why they would be case-hardened after being involved in so many scandals in this country which would have humiliated any person of decent morality-let me quote what the late Sir Robert Menzies had to say about this:

To put this matter in another way, in our system a political minister must face the music in Parliament; that is his duty and his privilege. He must take responsibility for his department and its administration. When I was Attorney- General-
Attorney-General, mind you:

I had a fixed rule that advice given to me by the Solicitor-General (who, in Australia, is an official and not a politician) was given to me for my consideration and if adopted by me became my advice for which I must accept responsibility. If his views were rejected by me, I would, of course, substitute my own opinion and the Solicitor-General's advice would find a resting-place in the files. This practice indeed represents the whole principle in action of ministerial responsibility; ministerial responsibility is of the essence of responsible government.

We therefore have irresponsible government, on this Government's record. Let us be clear about it. The Attorney-General is, on paper at least, highly qualified in the practice of law. He would know from both his studies and his practical involvement as a lawyer, as a politician and as a Minister the responsibilities that fall upon his shoulders. He does not mutely and thoughtlessly accept propositions put to him by his Department as interpretations of the law; he has to be satisfied, drawing on his experience and knowledge, that the interpretations are correct. What he is trying to put to us though, by implication, is that Ministers such as he sit behind padlocked office doors like big dummies shuffling papers which have been pushed under the door. They are time servers; they are mute ciphers.

The Attorney-General is given a commission by the Governor-General to administer his Department and to accept certain responsibilities. It is clear that the Attorney-General is not accepting those responsibilities. He is not just seeking not to accept them. I invite the House to look at the transcript-I regret I do not have time to go through it-of the television program Sunday of 5 September 1982 when with some rather clumsy footwork he sought to put all the responsibility onto the shoulders of the Treasurer. What we need to do in this House is to see the documents we referred to today: The long list of independent senior counsel opinions, the reports of the Australian Federal Police, the very detailed, exacting and highly skilled report of tax investigator Todman and the opinions of the legal section of the Taxation Office-all of which are quite contrary to the practices of the Government, its declarations and its decisions. It is pretty clear from the long list of comments made by the Treasurer in his statement on 27 June 1982 that he had considerable detail available to him about these matters dealt with by Costigan in relation to these subjects which were discussed in this Parliament last week and are being aired again today and will continue to be aired because the smell of this incompetence-indeed this corruption-will not go away by stalling and holding actions on the part of the Government.

Mr Speaker, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard certain sections of observations I have made in relation to the statement of the Treasurer on 27 June. Those statements clearly evidence that the Treasurer had information available to him.

The Treasurer has sought to conceal his responsibility in these matters by aiming at invoking the cover of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. SPEECH.PARA: The case is prima facie that both Ministers knew of their ministerial responsibilities in this matter-that is, they should have more carefully and critically addressed themselves to the matters before them-and certainly no one sensibly or fairly could argue that they ought not to have known. To argue that would be to argue the case of dereliction of duty in public office and that is what the Attorney-General seeks to establish. The Government, through these matters, has become the focus of public scorn and contempt. In their fashion the Liberals are faithful to public morality but they act like a cut rate street corner strumpet who is opposed to pornographic publications in her off-duty hours. No one believes them. This is a government which is deeply steeped in incompetence in administration and corruption-if not in its parliamentary administration, in its extra-parliamentary administration. Therein rests the explanation why no effective action, until quite recently, has been contemplated by the Government against organised, criminal tax evasion. The reason is that so many Liberals stood to gain profit from it.

This clearly establishes beyond any doubt-from his own statement-that there was full access without any serious impediment from section 16 of the taxation Act to the sort of information that this House should now have available to it. I quote from Senator Durack's statement made on Nationwide on 24 August. He stated :

Now, the Treasurer's indicated already, and it's clear the Government was given information in broad terms about the problem that was arising with straw companies, what have now become known as bottom of the harbour companies. And that was advised to the Treasurer in 1978 and it led to the special legislation, the Crimes Taxation Offences Act, which was passed in the end of 1980.

On the Government's own declaration, on the record of the quite lengthy Press statement of the Treasurer in June and on the statement of the Attorney-General, made on a perhaps not terribly popular current affairs television program quite recently, quite extensive information was made available to the Government on these matters. The conclusion is clear. When it suits the Government the confidentiality or privacy provisions of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act are no impediment to adequate information being provided; they merely become a disability for the Parliament when the Government finds it not just inconvenient but downright embarrassing should that information be made available.

Let us understand what this is all about. It is about the provision of information in this Parliament so that members of the Parliament can make a properly tempered and carefully considered judgment not just about whether the principle of ministerial responsibility was seriously infringed-it clearly was- but about the nature and the extent of that infringement, and go beyond that to establish to what extent the Prime Minister himself is involved in these matters . It is incomprehensible that, in that period from 1978 to 1980, and of course subsequently, when debate on these issues-tax avoidance and tax evasion-reached a fever pitch to the disadvantage of the Government, there was not, first of all , detailed analysis by the responsible Ministers, both lawyers-the Attorney- General and the Treasurer -of legal opinion available. It is incomprehensible that these Ministers did not note that the legal section of the Taxation Office disputed the indolent conclusions of the Crown law office that existing provisions were defective-it believed that they were effective-and the information provided by the Commonwealth Police Force and by the taxation investigator Todman. I wish to quote another view which was expressed by Herbert Morrison, a former member of the Labour Government in Britain who said:

If a mistake is made in a Government Department the Minister is responsible even if he knew nothing about it . . . even if he has no real responsibility whatsoever, the Minister is still held responsible . . . It is, however, legitimate for him to explain that something went wrong in the department, that he accepts responsibility and apologises for it, and that he has taken steps to see that such a thing will not happen again.

He has been personally responsible for offering advice to the British Government on the conduct of foreign policy, and that advice had proved to be in error. Let me go to the facts of the matter as far as they concern the Australian people. If the evasion of tax is as big as it is and can be shown to be, every pay-as-you-earn taxpayer in this nation has been subsidising these crooks to the extent of about $2,000 a head. Can honourable members imagine that? They are not able to be identified by the Department of the Treasury or by the Treasurer? I make this point. When we then get these Ministers in the recess talking about the situation what do we find? We find the Attorney-General saying on a radio program on 3 September: 'Look, I know there have been a number of opinions. I understand that the Queen's Counsel are saying that the existing law can be utilised'. I emphasise that to the Prime Minister: The Queen's Counsel's opinion says that existing laws can be utilised. The Attorney-General says: 'I am not challenging that view'. That is rather remarkable because he challenged it when he made a statement to the House, through the Minister who represents him in this chamber, only the previous week. He is not challenging the view. Of course he cannot because over 20 opinions have been given that the law should be applied.

It is counter-productive from the point of view of giving effective leadership to this nation for the Prime Minister to walk in here today and say: 'Well, we are relying on some new laws'. Let me make this very clear. Mr Costigan said that the real failure of this Government was its failure to apply the existing law. That is the position. The real failure of this Government was that crooks have got away with billions of dollars. The Prime Minister was anxious to talk about what happened under the Labor Government in 1973. At least the Australian Labor Party recommended a prosecution. When the Labor Party was sacked from office in 1975 that prosecution was pending. It was made on the legal advice of Mr Brinsden, Q.C. What happened to it? The honourable gentleman might want the words thrown back in his teeth. In 1979, four years after we were sacked, it was decided that there was no evidence to warrant the prosecution. Mr Costigan has identified that in the report as a lie, a falsehood. Mr Gleedman, the man responsible, certainly had no right to put that forward as an excuse. When Mr Costigan questioned Mr Gleedman about that matter he said that he had no knowledge about how he could possibly give that advice in law.

Let us have a look at this from the point of view of the Treasurer. In the second last Costigan report, of December last year, Mr Costigan talked about a case involving the examination of certain people in Victoria. He gave notice of the proposed examination to the Commissioner of Taxation and also to the Treasurer. He was hoping that the Commissioner of Taxation would be present in court when the examination took place. I make the point that Mr Costigan told the Treasurer about the matter. Mr Costigan made the point that when the examination took place in the court no representative of the Taxation Office was there. He made a further point that because of that examination some $200,000 in cash was removed, so obviously the Taxation Office could not get at it. He adverts later on to the fact that he discussed this matter with the Taxation Office and it said it was concerned about its officers' physical safety. That we can understand. But what about the fact that Mr Costigan, in an earlier report in 1981, alerted the Treasurer? He asked why through his Department, he did not come along and listen to some of the evidence as to what was wrong and where the crimes were. Mr Costigan says in this earlier report last year:

I have had discussions with the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation for New South Wales in Sydney and with the Commissioner of Taxation and two First Assistant Commissioners of Taxation in Canberra. I was informed by the Commissioner in Canberra that his office had been aware for a considerable time that promoters of the schemes of the kind I have outlined have been using criminals in the way suggested.

The Commissioner has been aware for a considerable time that criminals have been used. The Treasurer knows nothing about it. The Attorney-General knows nothing about it. The unfortunate taxpayers of this nation are having to foot the bill. We get a mealy-mouthed explanation here today that something will be all right because the Government is fixing up a few procedures or extending the commission .

Let us get this very clear. Anybody running a business like this would be made bankrupt or sent to gaol. That is the position. But we have Ministers here saying: 'Well it will be all right'. 'I really can't afford,' says the Prime Minister, 'to sack any more of my Ministers because I would be about the only one left'. We should look at the way this matter developed. It did not come out in the open through the Prime Minister. There was no mention of the Costigan report in the first week of this parliamentary sitting. It was not until the Prime Minister was asked a question in Question Time on the Thursday of the first week as to what happened to the Costigan report, which he had had since 27 July, that he volunteered to table it the next week. Why has he worried about it ? Why did he not at least table it? It was a matter of the utmost importance to this nation.

We have had some suggestion here that the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia is to blame. What utter nonsense. Most of the people referred to in the report are used car salesmen and many of them are in the Liberal Party . Let me make it very clear: We can identify in Perth particularly the presidents of the Liberal Party taking an active interest in running the party while being the recipients of benefits of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. We named them. Mr Horgan is the current chairman of the Liberal Party finance committee. Mr Corser was his predecessor. Both of them were clearly identified in the McCabe-Lafranchi report as getting millions of dollars. They are still in one way running the Liberal Party. But we get some oblique reference to the painters and dockers.

Why does the Government not face up to the fact that this motion says that the Government is an incompetent government. It deserves to be censured by this Parliament. It certainly will be censured by the electorate whenever it goes before it. What are the facts on which the electorate will be judging the Government? The Treasurer's statement in June last was again in error. I have referred to page 24 of his statement when he said that in about 1979-80 about 9, 000 companies were involved in tax avoidance. Does he know that the statistics of his own Department-he should have know this when he made his statement in June this year-clearly show that the number of individuals and companies in 1979 engaged in tax avoidance was 11,253, over 2,000 more than his statement says? Does he know that this has escalated now, according to the Taxation Commissioner 's report, to 22,366? What other direct evidence does the Government want to establish the fact that there has been a massive escalation in tax avoidance and that it is still going on? I make this point: The number of companies and individuals engaged in tax avoidance has doubled since 1979.

If one looks at the number of companies incorporated in Victoria as against the number of companies lodging returns, what better evidence could one find of tax evasion and avoidance than this? In 1979 there were 116,000 companies and only 52,000 lodged taxation returns in Victoria. There were 64,000 which did not account for anything. In 1978 there were 109,000 companies in Victoria and only 53,000 lodged taxation returns. In 1978, 56,000 companies in Victoria did not lodge any returns. When one looks at it from the point of view of the total figures one will see that there has been a massive reduction in the number of taxable companies compared with a massive increase in the number of non-taxable companies. As honourable members know from other statistics, the PAYE taxpayer is now being obliged to pay another 6 per cent or 7 per cent of total taxation. If one looks at New South Wales one will see that in 1979 122,000 companies were incorporated and only 100,000 lodged taxation returns. In other words, another 22,000 returns were missing. When one looks at the facts one sees that there was a proliferation of incorporated companies which were not lodging any taxation returns. Would that not give one notice that something was wrong? Figures will be produced in New South Wales which will clearly show that if Perth thought it was in any way leading in the tax avoidance field New South Wales will go right past it. It will leave Perth standing because of the massive tax avoidance that has taken place.

The Treasurer lives in Sydney. He is a lawyer. He is able to discuss these matters with his counterparts in that profession or in the accountancy field. Was he going around blinkered and unable to see what was happening? How to avoid tax was on everybody's lips in Sydney. So, do not give us any more of this nonsense that the Government has nothing to worry about now because, according to the Durack formula, if one does not have any personal failing one need not worry about the matter. We want to make the point to the nation that the Cabinet has failed miserably. It is afraid of finding out how much money is owing. It is really afraid of that. It is afraid because it is going to affect its own party supporters. It affects our nation as well. There is another report which, with the McCabe-Lafranchi examination and the Costigan examination, clearly shows that the rottenness and corruption in this country has seeped into the highest level. It has gone into every aspect of government. Criminals are really active. This lot are not painters and dockers either.

The Asian Wall Street Journal talks about Nugan Hand and about the massive amount of money that has gone. It talks about the possibility of money being laundered through the Reserve Bank of Australia. Would the Reserve Bank not have known of the amount of money that might have been laundered through Australia when it ran into billions of dollars? Would it not have known if it was related to arms dealing? On what basis can one say that simply because some former members of an intelligence agency were involved there is no need to ask questions? The Asian Wall Street Journal named the people concerned and they said it was just a normal bank. Nugan-Hand is well known now to have been associated with crime. We now find from Victoria that merchant banks such as Ward, Knight and Dunn have been associated with this area. They have been associated with phoney companies being formed. If honourable members want further explanation of the matter they will find the directors of those people come right back to Maher in Queensland and are also associated with John Wynyard and others in Sydney. In other words, there is a massive interlocking of crime not only domestically but also internationally. This is on record. This Government did not know anything about it and could not understand what was happening. There have been murders in this country. Commissioners have been trying to find out how it happened. If honourable members look through the reports they will see the rottenness and corruption that has occurred. What we want to see is not just more inquiries; we want to see prosecutions. That is the only way to bring the people involved to book. The sooner it is done, the better . If this Government is to survive on the question of integrity and honesty, what better example can it set than to sack the Ministers responsible? That is the only thing to do. This is what the censure motion is about. No Opposition worthy of its name is going to take any notice of these Ministers or a government which is so rife with corruption and so oblivious to crime that we even get objections to the fact that we raised the matter. There could not be a more serious matter. Let us get serious about it. People have died. People have lost their fortunes because of these crooks. Now we find the taxpayer having to make up the deficit because of what has happened. The excuse of the Prime Minister was abysmal. He made no reference in this debate to what had happened.
