SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the allegations about the Ministers concerned, let me refer to the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act because the Leader of the Opposition himself did so several times without quoting them. I want to quote the relevant section. Section 16 (2) states:

Subject to this section, an officer shall not either directly or indirectly, except in the performance of any duty as an officer, and either while he is, or after he ceases to be an officer, make a record of, or divulge or communicate to any person such information so acquired by him.
Sub-section (5A) of the same section states:

For the purposes of sub-sections (2) and (5), an officer or person shall be deemed to have communicated such information to another person in contravention of those sub-sections if he communicates that information to any Minister or any Minister of the Crown of a State.
The secrecy provisions of the Act are very relevant to the performance of the Ministers concerned. The Royal Commissioner reflected this in paragraphs 3.10 and 3.11 of the report.
Paragraph 3.10 states:

It is necessary, before I proceed further, to draw the attention of those who may read this Report to the circumstance that the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act apply with equal force to the Ministers who have charge of the enforcement of the law in this area. I refer in particular to persons holding the office of Treasurer, and of Attorney-General. The events to which I am referring took place over a period of 10 years. It will be recalled that during that time there had been a number of incumbents of both those high offices of the State. All of them have been denied access to the detailed information which has now been provided to me, and which has identified the situation described in this Report.
Paragraph 3.11 states:

I will have more to say about the desirability of a secrecy provision that has this effect at a later stage in my Report. It is sufficient to say, at this stage, that the secrecy provision has been an effective bar to proper ministerial supervision of the discharge of duty by both the Australian Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Office.

It is against that background that this motion is launched. The fact is, as I said, that nothing has been added by the Opposition today which was not said on 25 August. Indeed, one of the attachments to the statement of the Treasurer of 27 June, which was incorporated today in Hansard sets out an impressive and unrivalled record of achievement by this Government and this Treasurer in particular in respect of the elimination of tax avoidance and tax evasion. Any fair debate-too much to expect in this Parliament from the Opposition-would certainly identify that to be so. It would take account of all of the tax avoidance schemes which have been identified in recent years and the action which has been taken in respect of them. The Prime Minister when he was speaking sought to table a short chronology of a very detailed and lengthy series of those measures. It cannot be overlooked that the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were up and running as schemes at the same time as a series of other schemes were. Many of those were probably more damaging from a revenue point of view than those of which the Opposition is now complaining. In any event it ought not to be thought that that tax revenue is irrevocably lost. The Treasurer will no doubt say something on that matter when he introduces his Bill next week .

Honourable members should remember the Curran scheme about which much was said. It was this Government which acted in respect of the Curran scheme. One might ask, and it has been asked by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister before: What action was taken by Treasurers Crean, Cairns and Hayden in respect of that serious loss of revenue to the Commonwealth? The picture has to be taken as a whole. When that is done it would be generally agreed by any fair minded person that no one, in respect of legislative action in the area of taxation reform, has done more than the present Treasurer has to try to crack down upon, and he has been successful in his diligence in cracking down upon, the-

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been a complete and utter failure.

—Let me refer the honourable member to another matter in the Royal Commission report. I refer to paragraph 3.120 on page 89 of the report. The Royal Commissioner lists the record of the number of companies which were identified as taking advantage of one of the schemes against which this Government legislated in 1980. As honourable members will see, the figure was at its height in 1980 when there were 1,412 companies throughout Australia benefiting from that method of tax avoidance. In 1981 there were 121 companies. I have a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation addressed to the parliamentary secretary of the Treasurer. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your discussions early today-
That is of 26 August-

with Mr McDermott concerning the statistical information relating to pre-tax profit stripping operations set out in paragraph 3.120 of Volume 1 of Interim Report No. 4 of the Costigan Commission. This information was provided to the Royal Commission by the Australian Taxation Office and relates to companies that had been identified as at 30 June 1982. As pointed out in paragraph 3.125 of the Report there have been a further 1,678 stripped company cases which had not at that time been identified as to the year or type of strip.

I confirm that the table relates to pre-tax profit stripping cases identified as having been stripped of assets in the financial years ended 30 June 1973 to 1981. With the exception of some 5 cases, the companies identified as having been stripped during the year ended 30 June 1981 relate to the period between 1 July 1980 and 3 December 1980, i.e., they pre-date the Crimes (Taxation Offences ) Act.

Altogether we have now identified 7 cases in which companies appear to have been stripped of assets after the enactment of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. No prosecution proceedings have been instituted as yet. Assessments have only recently been raised following an investigation of the facts of each case. We have judged it to be appropriate to await the expiry of the due date for payment before referring the cases to the appropriate law enforcement authorities.
A postscript to the letter adds:
We have prepared a brief for the police which will go forward immediately the due date expires if payment is not made by then.

That illustrates the great success of the legislation of 1980-the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act. It has virtually eliminated that form of tax avoidance and evasion which was a very great cost to the Australian revenue. In the course of preparing that legislation the Treasurer, recognising that it was a criminal offence and that this was a major and radical piece of taxation law reform, took great pains to seek advice from his Taxation Advisory Committee-from specialist persons who were not themselves involved in tax avoidance and evasion programs. As well there were matters concerning the onus of proof and the gravity of the legislation. It was a new and quite radical set of reforms affecting individual rights and the practices of the law under which people arranged their affairs. The legislation needed to be prepared with care and was prepared with care. Indeed, when it came to this Parliament, despite all that care, there were still amendments that had to be made. Undue haste would have been ground for condemnation of the Treasurer, but not the ground of great care. The legislation has been highly successful. It has eliminated the practice. The Treasurer should be commended, not condemned, for his approach to the question of taxation law reform. I repeat that no one individual and no one government have done more in that area than the present Treasurer and the present Government.

The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes referred to in this debate are only one aspect of a very large problem. After receiving the report of Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi, the Treasurer in a statement of 27 June, which appears in Hansard, described in some detail the actions which he, the Government and the Australian Taxation Office had taken on that matter. Despite the efforts that are now being made by the Opposition to misrepresent the contents of that document, it remains a good explanation. Each of the actions when considered in their own context would be seen-by any fair-minded person-to add up to a remarkable degree of diligence and effective action by the Treasurer and certainly do not represent any dereliction of duty as is alleged.

Much is being made of the fact that the Treasurer accepted advice which came from internal advisers on legal matters. It is said that he was wrong or unwise to do that and that he disregarded some external advice. I make it perfectly clear that the Treasurer was not entitled to know that the Commissioner of Taxation had sought external legal advice. He was not told. He need not have been told that that advice had been sought. If the Commissioner had chosen to tell him in general terms he could have but he would have had to do so being well aware of section 16 of the Act, to which I have referred. The responsibility for the administration of the income tax law rests with the Commissioner. The Commissioner himself is responsible for the administrative arrangements. Therefore even with hindsight the assertion that the Treasurer ignored external advice has not been substantiated.

Much has been made of the fact that the Treasurer did not know that certain external opinions had been obtained by the Crown law authorities at the behest of the Commissioner of Taxation. Again, he could not have known and should not have known that that was so. Whether those external opinions prove to be sound opinions remains to be seen. Certainly the Treasurer did not know about them. He need not and should not have known of their specific terms. In all the circumstances and even with the benefit of hindsight, but in particular taking account of the context in which the opinions were given, it is not surprising that they were never placed in the Treasurer's hands, especially having regard to those secrecy provisions. When the Commissioner put to the Treasurer in May 1978 that the time had come when specific criminal offences ought to be assigned to bottom-of-the-harbour operations the Commissioner of Taxation perceived then no reason why he should detail an external opinion when in the Commissioner's experiences and in accordance with the established administrative arrangements it was the view of the Government lawyers which would have to prevail. In fact, it was the assessment of the Taxation Commissioner that the Government lawyers would be almost certainly averse to any sort of proceedings under the current law. Hence it was thought that the law had to be changed with reference to the legislation I have cited. Its effectiveness has been demonstrated by the letter from the Commissioner. Certainly, it was not absolutely confirmed until some months later that the ultimate decision of the Crown law officers was as the Comissioner expected it to be.

There have been complaints that other external legal opinions did not support the advice given to the Commissioner by Crown law officers and that the existence of these was, because of some alleged ulterior motive, concealed. It should not be overlooked that at least two of these external opinions were given on the particular facts of cases which did not possess any familiar characteristics of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Those characteristics have been described in this House. Of course, they refer to the sale, for an unrealistically high price, of the shares of a company with an impending tax liability to a promoter of the scheme, the ultimate transfer of the control of that company to sham directors along with the adoption of false addresses and in some cases the consignment of relevant records to the bottom-of-the-harbour or some other place of oblivion. These two cases in question where external advice was obtained, had none of these characteristics. They did, however, bring into question one arguably common feature: The possible negligence of directors in carrying out an operation. It seems that it is on this basis that they have become bracketed with bottom-of-the-harbour cases. The fact remains that they were obtained in the ordinary course of tax administration by the Commissioner in accordance with his responsibilities; they were in relation to different kinds of cases altogether and there is no reason why the Treasurer need have had knowledge of them.

I mention that in passing because it has been suggested that one of the opinions was acted upon, and indeed it was. It was acted upon very effectively and resulted in company tax being paid in accordance with the law. The point I am making is that counsel in each of these cases was dealing with a particular factual situation and it cannot possibly be asserted with certainty that they would have reached the same view if the facts had instead been those views typical of bottom-of-the-harbour cases. The Treasurer has said in a number of places that a conspicuously successful piece of legislation, the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act, which I referred to earlier, dealt a mortal blow to this activity. However, it took rather a long time to germinate because of its radical nature and the care which had to be taken in effecting the rights of people who had acted under the law as it was. The Treasurer gave a perfectly satisfactory explanation of that in his statement on 27 June. The Royal Commission itself acknowledges that the Treasurer's statement, which is, as I said, now in Hansard, assisted it. Far from being incompatible with the findings of the Royal Commission, it assisted it to come to the findings to which the Treasurer referred.

When it is taken into account that the Royal Commission had access to the records of the Australian Taxation Office, the statement by the Treasurer in relation to the performance of the Australian Taxation Office is vindicated by the Royal Commission in its report. When it is also taken into account that the Royal Commission in its recent report made no finding against either the Treasurer or the Australian Taxation Office in relation to their respective performances in the main matter of inquiry, it can be deduced only that the Royal Commission found the Treasurer's statement to be factually acceptable and to tally with what was ascertainable from the official records to which it had access but the Treasurer did not.

In summary, there is no basis whatever for a censure against the Treasurer on this or any other matter involving tax avoidance. In fact, he ought to be receiving the praise of the Parliament for the tremendous amount of work he has done in this area in the period from late 1977 when he first became Treasurer. He has a very distinguished record. If honourable members opposite were really concerned with tax avoidance and evasion they would have made sure that their three Treasurers took action in this area because the schemes of which they are complaining were then apparent.

—The Opposition has abused and wasted the time of this House today by repeating the same insubstantial allegations and ignoring those parts of the Royal Commission's report which make it abundantly clear that a succession of Treasurers and Attorneys have been denied the opportunity of administrative surveillance and knowledge of the matters revealed in the report. SPEECH.PARA: The Government talks about a fair debate, and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) attacked us for requiring the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to come home. Mr Connor was in bed with pneumonia when he was interviewed over an attack by the then Opposition rabble about loan raisings. It was not until 1979 or 1980 that the full extent of the schemes really became apparent to the Australian Taxation Office and the Government.
Let us get that clear. He said:
It was not until 1979 or 1980 that the full extent of the schemes really became apparent to the Australian Taxation Office and the Government.
I say that is a lie. Let me give the House another quote. He said:
The Australian Taxation Office and the Government developed detailed knowledge of the extent of the arrangements in the last couple of years of the 1970's.

It was apparent that in the investigation sections, in particular those in Western Australia, Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria, officers were aware throughout the relevant time period-

that companies were being dumped.

On 25 August-the last sitting week-when talking about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) the Treasurer said:

He is saying that we knew all the time what was going on, yet one of the major findings in the Costigan report is that the Income Tax Assessment Act is so structured that we cannot find out what is going on.

He relied again on section 16 of the Act. He said that the Government did not know what was going on. It is true that under section 16 information about individual taxpayers cannot be given to the Treasurer, but it is to some extent immaterial whether Joe Bloggs or Billy Bunter is involved in the case. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that information was given to the Treasurer. He said as early as 1978 that he knew about it. He became Treasurer at the end of 1977. In early 1978 at the latest he must have known of these schemes and their import even if he did not know the names of the individuals involved. It is a sham argument to suggest to the Parliament that he needed to know the names of individual companies and taxpayers to be able to take action against the nature of the scheme, bearing in mind that he would have been apprised of the nature of the scheme and a likely defence against it. But he said that he did not know. The McCabe-Lafranchi report says that the contrary is so. He said that the report was:

. . . used to create the false impression that this was new information, on new schemes, with dramatic new revenue losses. This was clearly not the case. Neither details of the schemes nor the revenue losses involved came as a surprise to us.

Either he knew or he did not know. He cannot say here that he did not know and a month before that he did know and that McCabe-Lafranchi was a stunt, because the whole tone of the Treasurer's statement in respect of McCabe-Lafranchi was that McCabe-Lafranchi was a political stunt and that there was no new information about the cost to revenue of the operation of the schemes. Yet he told us the contrary in the Parliament two weeks ago when he said: 'We knew what was going on, yet one of the major findings of the Costigan report was that the Income Tax Assessment Act is structured so that we cannot find out'. In other words, he denied knowing. Two or three months earlier he said he knew the lot and that there was no new information in this stunt report. This is the man we are supposed to hold up as a paragon of fiscal virtue who is out there catching the tax cheats. I do not suggest for a moment that the Treasurer is corrupt in any personal sense, but he has been corrupted by the ambience of Liberal Party attitudes. His ministerial responsibilities have been corrupted by attitudes prevailing in the Liberal Party-that John Howard had a good future in the Liberal Party as a prospective leader and to go soft on tax avoidance. The Government turned its back away from it in the way that the Taxation Office has. The Taxation Office got the signal that the Government did not want to go on with it so it did not. It knew from 1973. What must someone like Todman think after he went through 50 companies and put together a report of such quality? Then there is the high quality of the police report of 1976. Costigan applauded the quality of the work put together by those police officers in 1976. We have Todman in 1973; the Brinsden decision in 1974; the police report of 1976; and then the Treasurer says that it was not until 1979 or 1980 that the full extent of the schemes really became apparent. What a bloody lie that is! What a lie that is! What a disgraceful, despicable parliamentary lie that is!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will contain himself .

—What a parliamentary lie that is! We are supposed to say: 'Oh, no, don't call him home from the International Monetary Fund'. He has run for cover; he got out of here. I do not doubt that he had an attack of influenza the day he spoke here, but if one of us has an attack of influenza we have to stand here propped up on sticks to defend ourselves-the way that Connor was dragged out of his bed with pneumonia and hunted to his grave over the loans affair. We all know that. He was hunted to his grave, and for what? He was trying to borrow $4 billion. For what? To put in a few more coal harbours and ports and railways lines, for which we have seen a great and pressing urgency in the years since. SPEECH.PARA: This Government is corrupt. If it is not corrupt in a personal sense, if the Ministry is not corrupt, then the attitudes are corrupt. They go right through the Liberal Party. It is a disgrace that we have to stand here and call for Durack's resignation. The Prime Minister should have insisted on it. He insisted on it with Moore and with others. Yet the Treasurer is abroad trying to do this number. Wait until I get on to this little part in the statement of the Treasurer. He said:

It is important to recall the nature of the environment at the time the practices were entered into, especially the prevailing public attitudes and the priorities of the Government, the Australian Taxation Office and others at that time.
In the same statement he said:

Strong public attitudes towards tax avoidance were not yet evident at that time . . . Without wanting to downplay the significance of the schemes, it was clearly important to recognise the considerably different state of public opinion towards avoidance at that time.

As if the barometer of public opinion should be in any way relevant to the obligations that the Treasurer took upon himself when he took the oath of Executive office to uphold his responsibilities and to administer the Department of the Treasury and the Taxation Office! That is his responsibility-not to be some bell-wether about what the public thinks of tax avoidance but to stamp it out. That is his responsibility. What did he do with his responsibilty? He reminded us that members of the public were soft on it. Of course, they were soft on it. They did not realise that it was anything so audacious or outrageous , that approaching 10 per cent of budgetary revenue was being defrauded. Why would they not be soft on it? Yet we read those three disgraceful and disgusting quotations in a chapter in that statement which is the perspective and the environment of these things. Who wants to know about the environment? What he is saying is: 'I should be excused for not taking this matter on'. The environment was created by the corruption within the ranks of the Liberal Party machine. It was created by the shonky business people around the Liberal Party structure, and they have permeated now right to the very core of the Fraser Ministry. That is what we are facing here.

We are facing the most outrageous scandal in Australian federal history. We are not going to let up. We are going to hound this Treasurer out of office and we are going to hound the Attorney-General out of office, because they are unfit to hold office. The Prime Minister has protected and presided over them while making fish of one Minister and flesh of another. He has dismissed Ministers. He has protected National Country Party Ministers. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) saw the Australian meat trade with the United States of America at risk when the dogs were barking the fact that crook meat was leaving Australia. The Prime Minister let him stay in his job. He cannot afford to lose the Treasurer because he is the linchpin of his economic policy and the one person who has been defending the Government's indefensible policies. If he loses him, the Government is gone. Now the Government is gone. The public are not going to take this sort of fraud. They are not going to accept that the Government can do these things and get away with them. We on this side of the House are not going to sit back and see this happen with the Treasurer getting away with glib statements by relying on the facts that we will not compare one month's statement with the next.

I just go over the ground: If the Treasurer did not know, he should have known. My contention is that he knew about it all the time. It is clear from the early investigations in 1973 and 1974 that the Taxation Office knew of the bottom-of- the-harbour schemes.That is clear from the police report in 1976. It is clear from the opinions. Let us consider the opinions that we have seen: The Brinsden opinion of 1974-75; the opinion from the unamed Sydney barrister in early 1976; the police report of 1976; the Ormiston and Spry opinion to the Commissioner of Taxation in 1978; and the Traill opinion of 1978-a litany of opinions and investigations over five years. Yet he has the hide to tell this outrageous, audacious lie--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member--
—No, I will not desist, Mr Deputy Speaker.

He is responsible for that office. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) today have quoted the Prime Minister extensively on ministerial responsibility. There is no case whatsoever for the Attorney-General remaining in office. Members of the Liberal Party have said so. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey) walked out in disgust as the debate went on today. —It is our further contention that the Treasurer should also resign. The Treasurer spoke for 16 minutes--
—Defend your own fellows.

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will remain silent or I will deal with him.

For a Treasurer, a Minister, to make such a speech, to go through a litany of attack on the Labor Party about the Curran scheme and other things which of course bear no resemblance to the nature of the matter of public importance before us today, is a disgrace. If the Government thinks that this matter will be dropped-it has put up an attempt to chloroform the debate by bringing on the Prime Minister with a read speech and the honourable member for Balaclava, who would put one to sleep at the best of times-it is mistaken. DEBATE.TITLE: ENERGY USE, DISTRIBUTION AND CONSERVATION IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement in response to the report by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on energy use, distribution and conservation in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The report by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory dealing with energy use, distribution and conservation in the Australian Capital Territory was tabled on both Houses on 24 September 1981. The former Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, referred the matter to the Committee in November 1979. I congratulate the Committee on its report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises the need to pursue actively policies designed to encourage the efficient use and conservation of energy on a national basis. The Government supports the thrust of the Committee's report, which gives special emphasis towards energy conservation and to the better handling of emergency situations where supplies of energy are threatened. I am pleased to advise in this regard that several of the Committee's recommendations have been implemented by the Government. Of the Committee's 11 recommendations only three are not accepted by the Governemnt, while another two need to be considered further. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of the recommendations and the Government's proposals in relation to them.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Recommendation 1: The Committee notes that drafting instructions have been prepared to amend the Fuels Control Ordinance as proposed by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee and recommends that urgent action be undertaken to put these into effect.
Comment: This recommendation has been accepted and the necessary amendments to the Fuels Control Ordinance 1979 implementing the changes requested by the Senate Committee were made on 4 March 1982.

Recommendation 2: The Committee is concerned about the delay in the formal establishment of the Fuels Use Advisory Committee and recommends that it be established without further delay. The membership of the Committee should comprise four representatives of the oil companies operating in the A.C.T., plus four service station representatives, the Fuels Controller and perhaps a representative from the House of Assembly or the community.

Comment: It is not considered feasible to establish the Committee as a statutory body. There are considerable legal and practical problems in specifying, in legislation, which areas of the fuel industry should be represented and in maintaining membership given the ever changing nature of the industry.

A Fuels Use Advisory Committee has been operating on an informal basis for some time. The current membership comprises a representative of each of the nine major oil companies operating in the A.C.T. and of the A.C.T. Automotive Services Association. The Controller of Fuels (appointed by the Minister under the Fuels Control Ordinance 1979) acts as Chairman of this voluntary committee.

It is proposed to administer any future fuel shortages with the assistance and advice of the Committee. Meetings of the Committee can be initiated by any member to ensure that any problems which may arise can be considered at the earliest possible time.

Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that in any emergency declared under the Fuels Control Ordinance priority be given to providing fuel for the public transport system and emergency services. Private vehicles should be rationed on an 'odds and evens' system and a maximum limit able to be purchased at any one time should be set.
Comment: These recommendations are accepted. A two month storage capacity has been developed for Canberra's public transport system to enable its operations to withstand fuel shortages.
Priority for the maintenance of essential and emergency services is accepted. Detailed arrangements need to be determined having regard to the nature and extent of specific emergencies.

The Fuels Control (Amendment) Ordinance 1932 which has recently been made enables the Controller of Fuels to ration fuel sales during a declared emergency on an ''odds'' and ''evens'' basis. The amending Ordinance also allows controls over trading hours during a declared emergency.

The principal Ordinance provides that the Controller, during a declared emergency, may by an instrument in writing, require that a person not sell, to any person, at one time, a quantity of fuel exceeding the quantity specified in the notice.

Recommendation 4: The Committee recommends that the A.C.T.E.A. conduct a survey of the generating equipment within the A.C.T. with a view to establishing whether or not there are adequate emergency facilities within the A.C.T.

Comment: The A.C.T.E.A. has information about the capacity of generating equipment within the A.C.T. However, the adequacy of these facilities in an emergency situation is largely a matter for the management of individual organisations to determine. The Electricity Supply Amendment Act 1982 which provides for rationing of electricity supplies has now come into operation. This law enables the A.C.T.E.A. to restrict usage to provide for continuity of supplies during emergencies.
Recommendation 5: The Committee recommends that the Department of the Capital Territory investigate the possibility of providing funds to allow for the further development of electric vehicles.

Comment: The Department's operational role in transportation matters makes it inappropriate for it to engage in, or sponsor, vehicle research projects. The Department of National Development and Energy provides funds for electric vehicle research through the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Programme.

There are a number of Australian firms with an interest in the conversion and marketing of electrical vehicles and it is considered that funding through the Department of the Capital Territory would not be appropriate.
Recommendation 6: The Committee recommends that the Minister for the Capital Territory take immediate measures to eliminate the petrol pricing differential between the A.C.T. and N.S.W.

Comment: The price differential between N.S.W. and the A.C.T. has been the result of the price control system operated by the N.S.W. Government which (i) prior to 7 May 1982, determines a lower maximum wholesale price than that recommended (and operating in the A.C.T.) by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority (P.P.P.A.) and (ii) also determines maximum retail prices. Since the Committee's report was made the N.S.W. Government reinstated on 7 May 1982 the two cents per litre margin deducted from the P.P.P.A. price for N.S.W. in June 1980. The N.S.W. Government also introduced a 3cpl petrol tax effective from 1 August 1982. It is expected that these actions will reduce the differential between N.S.W. and A.C.T. wholesale prices. In addition, the wholesale price in the A.C.T. is affected by a freight component not reflected in Sydney prices.

Independent determination of wholesale prices by an A.C.T. prices body would mean duplication of activity undertaken by the P.P.P.A. and, on this basis, cannot be supported. Furthermore price control would be inconsistent with the Government's policies. As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions the A .C.T. Prices Regulation Ordinance was repealed on 18 August 1981.

Recommendation 7: The Committee recommends that the D.C.T. in association with the N.C.D.C. and the major energy suppliers establish an A.C.T. Energy Information Centre to provide information to energy consumers. The centre should become the focal point in the event of a fuel emergency being declared. The work of the centre should be incorporated under the responsibilities of the Controller of Fuels.

Comment: An integrated energy information centre could have a desirable influence on consumer attitudes and behaviour by providing information and advice on how to conserve energy in homes, commercial buildings, and industry. Proposals to combine the existing sources of customer information into an integrated centre providing a range of information and advisory services are currently being considered. The Government considers it appropriate to encourage private enterprise groups and semigovernment authorities to develop such a centre before considering direct Government sponsorship.

The Department of the Capital Territory has received several applications for leases for energy conservation demonstration projects. These will receive the fullest support possible consistent with land release and planning policies.

Recommendation 8: The Committee recommends that the Government give priority to the feasibility study being undertaken on a possible railway link from Canberra to Gunning and further recommends that the Government expedite the provision of an XPT rail service between Canberra and Sydney.
Comment: The whole question of rail access to Canberra will be covered in the context of general proposals for upgrading transport links to the A.C.T.

Recommendation 9: To make the public more aware of energy conservation in housing the Committee suggests that the Housing Industry Association and the A.C .T. Chapter of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects consider awarding annual prizes for energy conservation conscious design in housing. The Committee further recommends that the DCT and NCDC jointly prepare and promote a pamphlet on energy efficiency in housing and ways householders can achieve greater energy economies in their own homes.

Comment: Whilst action on the Committee's suggestion is for both bodies to pursue independently of Government I am advised that the Housing Industry Association is committed to energy conservation for housing and presents awards for energy conscious design in housing. I also understand that the Royal Australian Institute of Architects has proposed to introduce, in 1983 a conservation award to be presented on a biennial basis. A number of authorities (NCDC, CSIRO, ACTEA and the Department of Transport and Construction) presently provide publications which canvass different aspects of energy conservation in buildings. The Department of the Capital Territory is updating its Building Note No. 24 'Energy Conservation in Buildings'. In its updated form it will be of assistance to the public by providing comparative information on the thermal insulation characteristics between the commonly used forms of construction. The Building Note is available without charge from the Building Section, Department of the Capital Territory, and reaches a wide cross-section of the community.

Recommendation 10: The Committee recommends that the terms of reference for the IDC on conversion of government buildings from oil to natural gas be extended to that of energy conservation in government buildings and that it be made a standing committee.

Comment: The Government has established an IDC on Energy Conservation in Commonwealth Buildings as a standing committee to co-ordinate the implementation of the Government's programme of energy conservation in all Commonwealth-owned and occupied buildings.

Recommendation 11: The Committee is concerned at the lack of attention given to energy conservation and efficiency in school design and recommends that higher priority be given to maximising energy conservation in new designs for school buildings.

Comment: The A.C.T. Schools Authority advises that energy conservation has been a design criterion for schools constructed since 1976. Energy audits of six schools, conducted by the NCDC, indicated that irrespective of the school's design, by far the largest potential for energy savings related to the operation and management of the school, for example, through the more efficient use of lighting, heating and air conditioning, and school equipment.

In the second school term of 1982, a 'Saving Energy in School' competition is being conducted for all primary and high schools and secondary colleges in the A .C.T. This competition is being sponsored by the Department of National Development and Energy, the Curriculum Development Section of the A.C.T. Schools Authority and the Science Teachers' Association as part of the National Energy Conservation Programme. ACT schools have also been issued with wall posters which present twelve ideas for saving energy in schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I should like to make a short statement in relation to some of the recommendations outlined a few moments ago by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). My main concern about the Government's response to the recommendations is that in many of those recommendations it has not been specific enough and taken action where there was an identified need for direct action by the Government. Let me give some examples. There is a recommendation for a fuels use advisory committee which, on the recommendation of the Committee, was to be set up with the appropriate statutory responsibilities and with proper legal procedures. The Government has responded by saying that that is not necessary any more and that there is a tribunal which operates quite well on a voluntary basis. I have had some discussions with people in the industry in the Australian Capital Territory who are concerned about a number of issues relating to the oil industry in the Australian Capital Territory, especially marketing problems, depot trading problems and pricing differentials. These are the sorts of issues which members of the Committee felt could be dealt with by a fuels use advisory committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also brings up the issue of price control over petrol. The Government dismisses this matter by saying that it is ideologically opposed to imposing price control on petrol, and that that is currently being undertaken by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. However, what is happening is that the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority has no effect at all on retail petrol prices in the Australian Capital Territory. That body is under considerable question as a controlling body for the whole of Australia for considering even the wholesale price of petrol. I understand the Australian Automobile Chamber of Commerce recently withdrew from hearings when price rises were granted without sufficient evidence, simply on the request of the oil companies.

In Canberra we have a situation where the New South Wales Government, because it has imposed certain taxes on prices, has now identified the areas around Canberra as needing to be given special consideration, with the price of petrol in areas surrounding Canberra being kept at the same level as the price of petrol in the Australian Capital Territory. Yet for years we had the reverse of that situation. Petrol was at least 2 cents a litre cheaper in New South Wales than in the Australian Capital Territory, and no consideration at all was given to the disadvantage that that caused consumers, business people and retailers in Canberra. So at least the New South Wales Government has given recognition to the fact that there was a price differential between New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. I think it is appalling that for years we had a situation in Canberra in which consumers were considerably disadvantaged vis-a- vis the price of petrol in New South Wales.

As usual, the Minister has said: 'Leave the energy information centre to the private sector'. I do not think that is good enough. The Government needs to show leadership. If it believes that such a centre is important it cannot just leave it to the private sector and say: 'Go ahead and set up a centre'. Such a centre needs not only encouragement but also some cash from the Government. The Committee also recommended that the train service between Canberra and Sydney should be upgraded. In the Government's response it dismissed that recommendation in a few lines. It simply said that the whole question of rail access to Canberra will be covered in the context of general proposals for upgrading transport links to the Australian Capital Territory. I do not think that that is good enough. What it means is that the whole issue will be glossed over; it will be forgotten. Upgrading the rail link between Canberra and Sydney would change Canberra overnight. It would open it up for tourists from all over-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why I will support it. If it will change Canberra, it has my support.

—I have support for that from the honourable member for Port Adelaide. It is not good enough to dismiss the matter by leaving it to some vague statement about general policy on rail transport. The positive aspects of the Committee's report with which the Minister has dealt are welcome. However, I do think that the Government has glossed over several issues, has not come up with specifics and, I am afraid, too frequently it has left it to other people to try to do what is basically the Government's job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the current rates of personal income tax are onerous and destructive of personal incentive, particularly since the cessation of income tax indexation. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call upon the Parliament assembled to legislate such changes to the current taxation law as will-
raise the minimum level at which income tax is first payable to at least $4,500 .00,
proportionately increase the figures at which the higher rates of tax attract,
allow taxpayers to claim the full amount for each item within the Concessional Expenditure Rebate, and
adjust the rates of tax payable so that no higher rate of tax is payable than fifty percent of income earned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Dobie and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Jose Ramos Horta
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth our concern that Australia is the only country to have refused a visa to Jose Ramos Horta and our desire that he be permitted to enter the country to testify before the Senate Inquiry on East Timor and to address Australian audiences.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Jose Ramos Horta be granted a standard visitors visa.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Robert Brown and Mr Campbell.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the taxes of all Australians will be used to finance a dam that would flood the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers in South-West Tasmania. Your petitioners declare that the intrinsic values of this area, and the provision of funds from the taxes of all Australians, for the destruction of this area of the National Estate and of world heritage value, does make this a national issue. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government take all possible steps, including financial and legal steps and fulfil its responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Act to prevent the destruction of this area of the National Estate, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Kelly,Mr Lusher and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately. Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les Johnson and Mr Charles Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N .H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Exchange, Taree
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to close the Manual Assistance Telephone Exchange at Taree will place in jeopardy the existing services to telephone subscribers in the district by:
1. The loss of a local emergency ''000'' service being given to non- metropolitan telephone users in emergency conditions
2. The loss of any local knowledge of the town and district being available to telephone users if this service is moved to a distant centre
3. The loss of a local and personalised service provided especially to elderly and handicapped people.

We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia should be instructed to seek the views of country telephone subscribers before proceeding with the closure of the manual assistance telephone exchange.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to halt the closure pending a full and open Parliamentary inquiry into the needs and desires of affected subscribers and the full economic and social effects of the closure on this district, rural telephone subscribers and Telecom Australia employees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:

1. Restrict access to education People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.

2. Undermine the tertiary education assistance scheme TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38 per cent of full-time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.67. Government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.

3. Disadvantage Women Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.

4. Disadvantage mature-age students Usually mature age students forego income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort educational choices Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.

6. Result in massive attrition rates Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to 'drop-out' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.

7. Cause administrative and financial difficulties Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The Government will also bear the administrative burden of pursuing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disastrous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That record high interest rates are:
(a) Destroying the prospects of most young families seeking to purchase a home.
(b) Destroying the chances of national economic recovery.
(c) Contributing to the record number of business bankruptcies.
(d) Contributing to the highest unemployment since the great Depression.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia immediately reverse its policy of high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South-West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Wine
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that any sales tax or excise on Australian wine would adversely affect employment in the wine industry, place a disproportionate burden on grapegrowers and ensure a larger future surplus of grapes;
the reduction in the demand for wine will also threaten the existence of many wine producers and reduce the range, quality and variety of wines offered in the market.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will reject any proposal for a sales tax or excise on Australian wine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
''That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the Government's failure to act to relieve the plight of many Australians who are being financially crippled by high mortgage repayments.
''That we protest on behalf of all those seriously affected by the current crisis in rising mortgage repayments and those facing the near impossibility of obtaining housing loans.
''That your Government's policies are forcing a downward trend in the percentage of Australians striving to achieve the ''Great Australian Dream'' of home ownership.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should: Resolve to demand immediate Government action to institute policies which recognise our grave problem and will preserve and maintain the ''Great Australian Dream'' of home ownership rather than continue to destroy that dream.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining on Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will: (a) accept the wishes of the petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whaling Protection Act 1980, provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. The Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the International Banning of Whaling,
3. Then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. Through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products , and support an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals for Slaughter
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas, and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electricity Generating Industry: Salaries
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that salaries of technical and supervisory employees of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority should be aligned with salaries of counterpart employees in the electricity generating industry in the State of New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aircraft Manufacturing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Australian Aircraft Manufacturing Industry has suffered serious setbacks since its creation, because of the lack of coherent Australian Government policy for the industry, as illustrated by: (a) reduction in RAAF flying hours; (b) cut backs in the Grumman Tracker; (c) delay in the introduction of new tactical fighter; (d) delay in the introduction of the trainer project; (e) cut back on the production of the Nomad aircraft from 200 to 170.
This will further destabilise the industry and many jobs and vital skills will be lost.
Decisions have been made without proper consultation with management, employees and unions in the industry.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Government will reverse its decision and allow the 30 additional Nomad aircraft to be built, while an inquiry is held into the vital role of the future Australian Aircraft Manufacturing Industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communications.
2. That the Australian postal service truly meets the needs of all Australians.
3. That any proposal that Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward be diminished will destroy the concept of the national postal service.

Your petitioners therefore pray: That the powers of the postal commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Northern Highway, Kimberley Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned residents of the Kimberley humbly petition the House of Representatives to urgently allocate funds for the immediate upgrading of the Great Northern Highway in the Kimberley to an all weather sealed highway and pray that the following matters might be considered in relation thereto:

1. The grave hardship caused to the many residents of the Kimberley due to the Great Northern Highway annually being impassable by road transport resulting in the towns of Kununurra, Wyndham, Halls Creek and Fitzroy Crossing and the community of Turkey Creek being without adequate food supplies for periods of sometimes in excess of one month.

2. That this portion of the Great Northern Highway is the last portion which is unsealed and which does not provide an all weather link and we are, therefore, the only residents of Australia who are on a major highway system which is regularly inundated.
3. Current allocations and plans do not provide for the upgrading of this highway to be completed in under six years.
4. There is great defence and strategic importance in having an all weather highway system into the North of Western Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the tyre dealers and retreaders in Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Due to the critical shortage of suitable used tyre casings in Australia, local retreading companies have been forced to import tyre casings from overseas countries, and
2. Whilst the sale of retreaded tyres using Australian-made used tyre casings is exempt from sales tax, retreaded tyres using imported casings are made subject to this tax, and

3. The imposition of this sales tax, added to the import duty which must also be paid on the tyre casing, is making the retreading of imported tyre casings no longer competitive with importation of new tyres from foreign countries, and

4. The continued importation of new tyres at a cost lower than that involved in retreading imported used casings must result in eventual close of businesses and the 8,000 to 10,000 jobs in the Australian tyre industry, and
5. The retreading of tyres can be shown to conserve a significant amount of oil and energy compared with the manufacture of new tyres.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the necessary amendments to the legislation be made to exempt all retreaded tyre casings from sales tax, and that pending implementation of this, import duty on used tyre casings be reduced from 15 per cent to 2 per cent to provide immediate relief.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth: That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia. Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sturt Street Post Office, Adelaide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain electors of the Division of Adelaide shows: that the Sturt Street Post Office is due to be closed on 24 October 1982.
Your petitioners therefore pray that: Australia Post reconsider its decision to close the Sturt Street Post Office, Adelaide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals for Slaughter
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the exportation of live animals for slaughter to overseas:
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to ban the export of live animals for slaughter overseas.
2. That the export of live horses to Japan for slaughter for human consumption be banned on the grounds that it is cruel and unnecessary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—On 26 August 1982 at the end of the last two-weeks sitting in the Parliament the Sydney Morning Herald reported a statement made by Mr Tony Staley , a former Minister in the Government. The headline reads: 'Staley rejects MP's charge on plane sale.' I wish to take the opportunity of refuting this report that has been put out, through the Sydney Morning Herald, in the name of Mr Staley. Mr Staley claims that I was wrong in what I said. —The honourable member is debating the issue.

—The Staley report is totally incorrect. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: ''Jet Corporation did not take over the other company. Jet Corporation bought from the previous company business assets including distributorship and agencies .

Jet Corporation was most deliberately established in this fashion in order to ensure that if there were any liabilities of which Jet Corporation was not aware then they were not inherited by Jet Corporation.
The man who was involved, Mr Wilson, is back from overseas and has been reported in the Age of 3 September 1982. This is the correct statement:

Yesterday, in the office of his city solicitor, Mr Wilson told 'The Age' he had been involved in selling the aircraft, but not buying it. That had been negotiated by the then managing director of Petres Pty Ltd, Mr Edward Sent.
Mr Wilson said: ''Although at the time it was finally delivered into the country--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I cannot see how the reporting of what Mr Wilson said has anything to do with the honourable member being misquoted in the Sydney Morning Herald.

—The story in the Sydney Morning Herald completely misquotes what I said in the Parliament. It gave a completely different interpretation from that of every other newspaper in the country, including the Age which looked the story up. TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 21 (1982).
