TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Government has now decided that the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill is not now the great election winner that it was supposed to be when the Bill was first mooted. Therefore the debate on the Bill is to be restricted. The Bill legislates on matters which already exist and which are understood to exist within the powers of the Commonwealth relating to defence. It arises from a little political grandstanding and election preparation by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) during the parliamentary recess-probably the longest in the history of this Parliament-when he sought to exploit the clear concern of the Victorian Government in respect of nuclear activities in that State and a letter which he received from the Premier of that State asking whether the Prime Minister would pass on to the United States of America the Victorian Government's opposition to visits of nuclear warships to that State.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be made clear that the Prime Minister decided to go public on that and make statements at the time alleging that the Victorian Government's position could jeopardise our international relations and the defence of Australia. That is plain rubbish. Nevertheless it is in line with what the Prime Minister says on many occasions when he is seeking issues which he can utilise for election purposes. The Prime Minister has also decided that the ANZUS alliance is not as important to him as a foreign policy or defence alliance as it is for exploitation for domestic policial purposes even if that creates conflict and division in Australia-this has been part of his policy over his whole period of tenure of office and was prior to his coming to office-about our American alliance.

The Prime Minister would see it as a plus if he could create a situation that would allow us to fight an election on a pro-American or anti-American basis. That is not likely to happen, because the alliance is important to all parties in this parliament. This is despite the attempts at divisiveness and to use foreign policy as a screen for lack of commitment, lack of success and failure of successive administrative and policy initiatives by this Government. As a result this matter falls into much the same category as the debate we had in this Parliament a fortnight ago about North West Cape. The Bill is a device which makes the law clear and quite unambiguous. It does not in any way change the existing law. It brings into law what the defence powers have always made available to Ministers for Defence and to Prime Ministers since Federation.

This Bill is about something quite different. It is part of the grand strategy which has permeated Australian politics for the last 40 years, the strategy of talking up defence, talking up foreign affairs and seeking to bring about a situation of divisiveness. What price has Australia paid for this type of policy ? The Victorian Government is entitled to have a concern about the safety of its citizens. It is entitled to express its opinion. There is no reason why it should not request the Prime Minister to pass on that information to the United States. Clearly, the Victorian Government cannot, and would not-the Premier acknowledges this in his letter to the Prime Minister-interfere in any way with the defence powers or any matters related to the defence of Australia. It is a Commonwealth function; it always has been. Because this Bill makes that absolutely clear in respect of not only the matter at issue but also a number of other matters, the Opposition does not oppose it. Some powers in this Bill could be misused by a Minister but one hopes that the good sense of Ministers for defence over a long period will be repeated in the future and those powers will not be misused for political purposes in this country.

Another concern is that in the Bill there seems to be a lack of any requirement in peacetime that safety provisions and other provisions which are related to the normal running of a port and the management of the flow of port traffic should be necessarily taken into consideration by a visiting warship. That is a concern which I think should be cleared up. In peacetime a warship coming into a port should be required to meet the normal safety and traffic requirements. No Commonwealth law should be able to override the basic safety requirements of ports. This Bill would probably allow that overriding on a direction from a Minister of the Parliament.

The Government brought this Bill forward as a political stunt-no more and no less. It did the same thing with the debate on the North West Cape Communications Station about two weeks ago. During the period it has been in office it has regularly tried to build up some form of phony issue in order to cover up its lack of administration. As I said in an earlier debate a few moments ago, its economic management of this country leaves a lot to be desired. If we read the statements of Prime Ministers, Treasurers and other Government spokesmen we will find that every year we have different predictions, different sets of circumstances and statements that the recovery will come from a different line. On one occasion the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) told us that the uranium industry, which is the heart of this Bill, would provide 500, 000 jobs in Australia. It probably provided $500,000 in contributions to a particular political party but it never provided 500,000 jobs. The other day an honourable member produced a letter in this Parliament which had been written on parliamentary stationery by Senator Walsh. It was not said that in the same year every company in Australia was written to on parliamentary paper by a leader of a political party in this House asking for funds. In one instance it was a matter of 27c; in the other it was a matter of $1,000. In one case it was an alleged misuse of a member's facilities; the other was a normal activity accepted by conservative parties in the Parliament. Mr Speaker-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I used the term because it is all inclusive and the person in the chair exercises the total authority of the Speaker, with some minor reservations . The Government over a period has tried to create hysteria about the American alliance, defence and foreign policy. The other night in this House we heard a statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) relating to the defence of this country. This Bill, which has been portrayed by the Government as critical to Australia's defence, allows warships to sail into and out of harbours in peacetime. The law is to be restated merely to meet a political requirement of the government of the day. Where are the big statements that have been made in the past? Why does this Government feel that it cannot stand on its record, that it has to have hysteria, distortion and overstatement?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will mention a few things that have happended in this Parliament while we have been members. I clearly remember at the time of the Czechoslovakian crisis the then Prime Minister, Mr Gorton, a person who placed Australia's interest above his political interests and was thrown out of the Liberal Party leadership for doing so, going to the Opposition to discuss the devising of a resolution that could be unanimously agreed to by members of this Parliament. All honourable members voted for the resolution. No one opposed it. A resolution was unanimously passed expressing, I think, the opinion of the great majority of Australians. Afghanistan, of course, was quite different. A new Prime Minister had come into office, whose politics were the politics of division and derision, opportunism and the use of our allies and international situations, no matter how tragic. He was a Prime Minister who saw an opportunity to score a political point and use it to the maximum. We have had no consultation about a joint resolution, no discussion about an expression of view by this Parliament which expresses the views of all Australian people.

There has been no expression by the Prime Minister of the need for a unified Parliament on what he described as the most serious threat to this nation since the Second World War. One sentance was asked to be taken out of the resolution and the Opposition said it would support it. The sentence had nothing to do with the substance of the resolution. It had to do with the stage management of political issues by a Prime Minister who saw an opportunity to exploit the tragedy of others for his own domestic purposes and to divide the Australian nation while he was doing so. It was all about one sentence. So there was no bipartisan attitude, no discussion and no resolution of this Parliament was passed unanimously, not because all members of parliament did not agree that a resolution should be passed but because the Prime Minister saw it as more important to serve his narrow political ends of division in this country than to have an expression on behalf of Australia. What has happened to the war in two years? It is the same as the Menzies war of three years in the 1950s. The defence vote has been cut in every year since that statement was made. None of the statements on defence has been honoured. This year we have less money to spend on the non-wages part of defence in real terms than in any year since this Governemnt came to office. There has been a real cut in the money available for facilities and equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be accurate.

—I am being accurate. There is an actual increase from last year's Estimates from 49 per cent to 55 per cent in the proportion of the Budget allocated for defence which will be absorbed by wages, leaving 45 per cent for non-wages expenditure. That is a cut of 6.5 per cent in real terms on the non- wages content of the defence vote and the Minister knows it. That is why he is running around the country making stupid statements about 35,000 tonne aircraft carriers and giving the F18s to the Royal Australian Navy to fly. If he put a tender behind the carrier, he could put the Army on it and we would have a great defence policy in line with what the Government has actually achieved over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to what this Government does and says about war in two years. I said in my speech the other night that the Minister had not mentioned Afghanistan. He said he had mentioned it. I read his speech and the greatest crisis in 40 years rated one word. It rated one word two and a half years later and the word was 'Afghanistan'. There was not one word about what had happened in the meantime, about the miscalculation or about what had been done about the intelligence services which led the Prime Minister to make in this Parliament statements that were patently inaccurate and misleading and which caused the Prime Minister to bring about a division on a matter on which the Parliament should have been unanimous.

Whilst the Bill is not opposed by the Opposition, it is in the Parliament because the Prime Minister thought he had the opportunity to create division on foreign and defence policy in this country. He could not do so. He has always believed that the most important element of any matter which comes before the Australian Parliament is the degree to which it can be exploited for his narrow, short term political benefits. The unfortunate thing is that at a time when Australia is in crisis, a time when we need leadership which can unite the nation, we have small, petty-minded leaders who see themselves as political survivors at the cost of the nation. We do not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I never cease to wonder how honourable members on that side of the House can possibly take the slightest risk of upsetting our understanding and agreements with the United States of America. SPEECH.PARA: The proposed visit of the US nuclear armed ship the USS Goldsborough to Melbourne is an extreme provocation. The United States Government is fully aware of Victoria's nuclear free policy.

But Mr Pain-well, he has caused enough pain in Victoria so I would be forgiven for making that sort of mistake-Mr Cain has seen the way the wind is blowing and had pressures brought to bear on him by more responsible members of the Labor Party. If we have any sense of responsibility at all for the security of this country, would we deliberately set up a barrier which would impose an inhibition of the worst possible kind between ourselves and the United States?

People who live in Tasmania and Melbourne can make their own arrangements, but I live in Queensland and am concerned with the northern frontiers of this nation . We are probably the most vulnerable. We have often thought that, come the next war, we will have a Brisbane line and will give away everything south of it if those who live there do not behave themselves. We are much more conscious of the vulnerability of northern parts of this nation. Hence we are deeply concerned with retaining and maintaining the sort of friendship, the sort of understanding and the sorts of agreements with the United States which would not be impeded by a policy which says: 'If you have a nuclear ship we do not want you in port'.

The purpose of the proposed legislation obviously is to formulate existing Commonwealth powers and responsibilities in respect of visiting foreign warships -fancy having to formalise this!-and specifically to clarify that that sole authority for granting approval for such visits resides with the Commonwealth. In other words, we have to substantiate our powers. We are to come out and say to these irresponsible States, and thank God there are only one or two of them: 'Okay; if you are going to make it difficult, without one ally on whom we can depend, we will have to step in and superimpose our Commonwealth powers on you'. TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill. It believes that the Commonwealth should have the power to control entry to Australian ports by foreign warships. This Bill clarifies a power for the Commonwealth that we believe it already has. However, the way in which the Bill has been presented; the electoral advantage that was sought with it and the craven manipulation of a visiting American diplomat, Walter Stoessel, to produce the statement in the last ANZUS ministerial communique to which the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) referred in his second reading speech, are to us matters of grave concern. This Government remains determined, for political purposes, to turn the American alliance into a weapon against a proportion of its citizens rather than see it evolve and develop in the context of a mature relationship in national security policy. The route by which this legislation has been brought before us is perhaps one of the worst examples of this process. Rather than address the concern that some of our citizens have that visits by nuclear powered and armed warships pose environmental dangers, strategic dangers and problems for the independence of our foreign policy, the Government produces crude and exaggerated argument that any inhibition on where and when the ships visit will negate the American alliance. If it were a genuine consideration, why did the United States of America alliance not collapse when the McMahon Liberal Government in 1971 banned visits by United States nuclear-powered warships?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. What the Government hoped to achieve was a situation in which, were any stabilisation agreed to at prevailing levels of activity, those prevailing levels would include substantial usage of Western Australian ports. Likewise it has been the Australian Government which has urged the United States to homeport warships in Western Australia, as it was the Australian Government which urged the United States to intervene in Australian domestic politics on this matter early in the year. After all, one can hardly expect the United States Government, which benefits greatly from the presence of intelligence gathering and communications facilities in Australia which are important to its strategic deterrent and arms control agreements, which benefits from the Australian Orion P3C surveillance of the eastern Indian Ocean, which has permission to transit Darwin with reconnaissance B52 aircraft, and which has the co-operation of the Australian intelligence community with the utterly vital naval ocean surveillance and information system of the United States, to take quite the same frenetic view of the value of occasional rest and recreation visits by warships as those on the other side of the House who in defence matters live in a state of suspended adolescence.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that port visits by United States warships are useful but not vital to the American relationship. As such the question of the frequency of the visits, their location and the numbers involved can be viewed in a calm environment and with care to ensure that no environmental or strategic dangers emerge for the Australian community from their presence. The Government has a number of questions to answer on both these points, to which I wish now to turn. I have before me the report produced in 1976 by the Department of Defence and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission on Environmental Considerations of Visits of Nuclear Powered Warships to Australia. This report justified the Fraser Government's rescinding of the McMahon Liberal Government's ban on visits by nuclear powered warships. For example, point 13 in chapter one reads:

However, the acceptance of nuclear warships under the proposed conditions is limited to those with reactor power levels less than 100MW (thermal) i.e., the current designs of nuclear powered submarines and the early surface vessels. Much larger reactor units are used in the latest nuclear-powered aircraft carrier USS Nimitz and are planned for use in future United States nuclear surface warships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was quoting from the report entitled 'Environmental Considerations on Visits by Nuclear Powered Warships to Australia', produced in 1976, which compared reactor units in nuclear powered submarines with those in larger units. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The acceptance of these vessels would need to be assessed separately in the light of available technical information of guarantees on their safety.

This means that of the 29 nuclear powered warships that visited in the period from 1976 to 1981 and the 11 or so since, the 30-odd submarines have been cleared by this report but not necessarily the cruisers and the carriers. Has the Government new information which has not been released to the public which clears them? If so, where is it? The Governments of Victoria, Western Australia and New South Wales are entitled to have that information as those ships must berth near population centres and the public is entitled to assurance and not abuse on this matter. In the report consideration is given to the unlikely event of a reactor melt down. This is identified as 'the principal risk from a nuclear warship visiting an Australian port'. It must be said that the prognosis on that possibility is encouraging. The risk is not seen by the authors of the report as being very high. Given however the fact that the Government's advisers see the risks as finite the public is now entitled to know in what ways, if any, these assessments have been altered by the experience with the Harrisburg disaster. We do not know if the British and American bodies which monitor naval reactors-on whose advice we rely-have assessed that accident.

Other risks were identified and defined in the report in the following way: Firstly, a catastrophic failure of the reactor pressure vessel causing a coincidental breach of the reactor containment direct to the atmosphere; secondly, from a high speed collision breaching both the containment and the primary circuit; and, thirdly, from sabotage. All three possibilities require the co-operation of those State authorities which control ship movements in port , berthing, evacuation procedures for population and police. Their co-operation is recognised by those who compiled the report on the safety of nuclear vessel visits to the Government and is not dismissed by them with the same slighting reference as that which has been made by Government spokesmen in public and by the Minister for Defence in his second reading speech. They recommend detailed plans, for implementation in each State, relying on co-operation with the State authorities, not the abuse of them.

I would like to know how effectively all those plans have been developed in the last five years and in what ports appropriate procedures have been achieved. One would have thought that in any second reading speech on this matter produced in this House that would have been a minimal requirement upon which a Minister would make statements. It is understandable that when confronted with the fact that in 1980-81, under the Liberal Government, only 10 port visits were made, none involving nuclear powered vessels, and that of the 331 port visits which occurred between 1974 and 1981 only 43 were made by nuclear powered vessels-35 of them to Western Australian ports-the Government of Victoria should not perceive quite the same extreme urgency to the alliance subsequently discovered by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for port visits by nuclear powered ships, or any type of ship for that matter. It is not surprising also that Premier Neville Wran should feel somewhat chargrined at now being berated by a Prime Minister who, for six years, aquiesced without complaint on his maintenance of the McMahon Government's ban insofar as it affected Sydney.

I turn now to some of the strategic questions involved and put aside the environmental matters as I understand some other Opposition speakers wish to deal with them. There is no doubt that the capacity to exercise with Australian ships and air and ground forces is a valuable feature for some port visits. It is much more preferable in terms of defence of Australia to have substantial experience in this regard off our coast than in distant points of the Indian and Pacific oceans. That is certainly a gain from port visits by American warships. However, it is fallacious to go beyond this to argue that the visiting warships serve a direct Australian defence purpose. They serve United States purposes and will be committed to action at the initiative of the United States Government and nobody else.

The ships which visit Western Australia do not patrol its shores to pick up smugglers, spies, terrorists or whatever. They do not police our off-shore installations and are of very marginal value to coastal surveillance. Were we to be embroiled with Indonesia over Timor or become embroiled with Indonesia in New Guinea those ships would not be committed to pulling us out of trouble. As a member of parliament representing an electorate in Western Australia I resent the way attempts have been made to con the general public in Western Australia into believing that United States port visits defend Western Australia. The Government slides into this argument whenever attention is drawn to its erratic record on the defence of Western Australia. On the southern and eastern coasts of this country there are 12 destroyers, 14 patrol boats and 6 submarines. After seven years of Liberal Government there is only one patrol boat on the west coast.

The Liberal Government began its term with the promise of a full utilisation of the capacity of HMAS Stirling-four destroyers and three submarines. In 1976 the Liberal Government promised that a patrol boat base would be built in the north- west of Western Australia by 1981. In the 1977 election the then Minister for Defence promised two destroyers and two submarines at Stirling by 1980. Of course none of these have appeared. They are a part of the continuing but non- implemented promises of this Government. I have great confidence that they will be trotted out in the very near future as we approach an election. The implications of all this is that Western Australia has forward defence and the rest of the country has defence self-reliance. This Government will go on using the smokescreen of visits by the United States Navy to conceal the utter charade it has made of its defence promises in Western Australia.

I turn now to one further matter on the strategic question which needs to be addressed and that is an aspect of the quality of our alliance relationship. The Australian people have an entitlement to a clear understanding of the significance of every aspect of our relationship, not just because this is essential in every democratic society, but because it is essential for sound political judgment in alliance relationships. Whenever this House debates an alliance-related subject it does so as though there were no other leg to the alliance and that to modify or trim the policy under discussion will bring down the whole house of the alliance. This is mindless. I concede that occasional efforts have been made by Government members to break out of it.

The influence of bad habits built up in the 1960s on the detail of our involvement in Vietnam and discussion of the role of the joint installations, however, remains. On this matter I draw attention to certain features of the port visits to Western Australia which have not been raised for proper discussion in the House. I find the notion of providing allies with rest and recreation facilities, where the allies require it, unimpeachable. Less impressive is the manipulation of an ally to achieve certain objectives which are then sold as an allied initiative. Even less impressive is the construction of a pattern of visits which suggests that an operation other than simply occasional R and R is being conducted. It may be that both activities ought to be approved. Neither should be approved without full and frank public discussion .

I have already mentioned the connection between the increasing visits to Western Australia and the efforts to subvert or modify President Carter's initiative to demilitarise the Indian Ocean. This was never discussed at the time. At that time the official position of the Australian Government was to support an Indian Ocean peace zone. In the interim it supported a balance of naval forces in the Indian Ocean at the lowest possible level. Its policy on port visits in practice subverted its objective at that time, but that was never explained. In addition, Western Australia now experiences visits by submarines with a frequency which suggests that R and R visits are associated with an operation. They appear for a week once a month at HMAS Stirling. We are not entitled to know the details of those operations. In the same way, we are not entitled to know the technical detail of how Pine Gap or one of the other installations monitors communications or performs technical functions. We are entitled to know if an operation exists and its purposes. In my view, from an assessment of the public record and from answers to ministerial questions, the regular submarine visits represent the tail and softer end of a substantial Australian contribution to an American anti-submarine warfare effort in the eastern Indian Ocean. We contribute communications through North West Cape and contribute surveillance through P3 operations from Australia, Indian Ocean islands and Malaysia. In the past we have contributed to hydrographic surveys and in other ways assisted the development of underwater sensor systems, and we participate in monitoring maritime communications.

The submarines are the business end of an anti-submarine warfare infrastructure in substantial measure provided by Australia. If this is the case it ought to be discussed in this place as it is a major contribution to our ally's security. It provides secure transit for the United States Navy between the Indian and Pacific Oceans. Nowhere in the Minister's speech on this matter is there an appreciation of this point. It is simply discussed in terms of rest and recreation visits of the warships involved. We are entitled to know the full extent of our co-operation with the United States in every area-not, as I said, the secret technical aspects of it but the purposes of it. We on this side of the House support this Bill. We deprecate, however, the divisive course that has brought it here. That course is destructive of rational foreign policy debate and it is corrosive of our national interest, and the Government should be condemned for that aspect of its activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nuclear energy is a very contentious issue throughout the world. Genuine fears are held by many people about the effect of the uranium nuclear power industry on this country. SPEECH.PARA: The Premier of NSW, Mr Neville Wran, has declared that NSW ports will be closed to nuclear warships. We wholeheartedly endorse and support his stand, believing it to be in the interests of the safety and well being of the people of NSW and the whole of Australia.

We support the fact that our American allies have chosen to arm and to power their ships by nuclear means. That is not our decision; that is their decision. We, as signatories to the ANZUS Treaty, cannot say: 'The Treaty is at an end. Go home, we are not interested in playing with those sorts of armaments'. Of course we are not. It is necessary, despite what armaments they might carry, for us to offer them our porting facilities. I think it is important to quote a joint communique issued by the representatives of the governments of the United States , New Zealand and Australia at the conclusion of the thirty-first meeting of the ANZUS Council held on 21 and 22 June 1982. That communique, quoted in the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair), states:

In particular (the Deputy Secretary and the Ministers) confirmed the high priority each partner placed upon a regular and comprehensive programme of naval visits to each other's ports, as well as to friendly ports in the Asia/Pacific region generally. They recognise the importance of access by United States naval ships to the ports of its Treaty partners as a critical factor in its efforts to maintain strategic deterrence and in order to carry out its responsibilities under the terms of the Treaty. In this regard the Australian and New Zealand members declared their continued willingness to accept visits to their ports by United States naval vessels whether conventional or nuclear powered.

I ask: What sort of ally would we be if we accepted our allies only on our terms ? We would very shortly run out of allies. I remind the House that the United States of America and some of our other allies decided to arm and power their ships with nuclear energy. It was not our decision. I remind the House that nuclear armaments had their beginnings in World War II. There is no need to remind people here that the proliferation of nuclear weapons in the last 40 years has been due to the necessity of keeping the balance of power-or terror, as some people might choose to call it-and it takes two to achieve balance on any see-saw. Too often the Western bloc countries are blamed for the proliferation of nuclear power when two are playing this deadly game.

The point of this debate is this: Do we approve of allowing Eastern bloc countries to develop nuclear weapons without attempting to counter them? If we do not approve we are obliged to support our American allies. Part of that support is to offer what help we can. If we assist in this way the time will come when they will assist us if we call them. The assistance we can offer includes porting facilities. One of the points which I believe has been missed in the debate is that this Bill came forward mainly because the issue was raised , not by the Government, but by the the Victorian premier and before him, by the New South Wales Premier. Recently Mr Cain challenged the Federal government as to its authority in this matter. That authority has been acknowledged, I am glad to say, by the other side of the House. Since that time Mr Cain has backed down, and rightly so. Before that, in a more low key way, the Premier of New South Wales also challenged the authority of the Federal Government in this matter. I believe it is unfortunate that this Bill is necessary. Again the Opposition has acknowledged that fact.

The fact is that any government's first responsibility is to protect Australia and its territories. If anybody thinks that we can do this alone he is sadly mistaken. All governments, whatever their political complexion, have sought allies since this country became a nation. Generally speaking there has been a fairly bipartisan approach to defence. The ANZUS Treaty has been part of our defence policy for many years. It has stood the test of time and I suspect it will remain for many years to come. The Government, under the Treaty, is obliged to offer assistance, including porting facilities, to our allies. If that assistance is not forthcoming America is quite entitled to question our commitment to the Treaty. Apart from some notable exceptions, members of the Australian Labor Party have supported the ANZUS Treaty. If they support that Treaty, I fail to understand how there can be any serious division about suporting the porting of American ships. Both the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) and the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) have talked tonight about the political purposes of introducing this Bill. However the fact is that the Bill was introduced simply because the Premier of Victoria sought to challenge the authority of the Federal Government which-

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Melbourne Ports I enter this debate because I represent an electorate which contains the basic port facilities for the Port of Melbourne. Any visit by a United States warship, nuclear or otherwise, is a matter of some concern to me and my constituents. What is in dispute here is not really at any stage the defence power of the Commonwealth. The defence power of the Commonwealth has been conceded by all members of this Parliament, and indeed by all those State Premiers who have been concerned to express a view on the matter of visits by nuclear warships. The Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill was not and is not necessary to strengthen the power of the Commonwealth in the exercise of its prerogatives under the defence powers in the Constitution. This legislation initially was an exercise in political grandstanding by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who was seeking to use Australia's relationship with the United States and the general view of his Government to create hysteria within the electorate, to create a situation where, faced with the declining economy, with a record of Government failure in respect of the economy, he could contrive an artificial issue to take to the Australian electorate. In so doing, of course, a number of arguments have been completely obfuscated, and the history of Australia's relationship with the United States and our perception of the problems that are occasioned by the visit of nuclear powered or nuclear armed warships has been overlooked.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) pointed out, the first Prime Minister in Australia to indicate to both Great Britain and the United States of America that we did not want visiting nuclear warships to visit Australia was McMahon. In a statement to this House the then Prime Minister, Mr McMahon, pointed out that, acting on the advice of the Department of Defence and on the basis that there were no adequate undertakings or guarantees from either Great Britain or the United States at that stage, his Government felt constrained to say to both the United States of America and Great Britain that our port facilities would not be made available. Of course, if what the Prime Minister has said is true-that the refusal by any Australian Government of those port facilities would destroy the basis of ANZUS-that leaves us with the interesting question: How is it that, despite the refusal of the McMahon Government, ANZUS seems to have survived? The answer to that is that over a period a quite formidable set of agreements and undertakings were given by the United States and other nations whose warships are nuclear powered or nuclear armed and which carry the flag of their country. They indicated that they would give certain guarantees, and some of those details have been given by the honourable member for Swan.

I say without any hesitation at all that whilst one might not be greatly concerned about a visit by a nuclear powered vessel, there are some nuclear vessels which I would be very unhappy to see visit the port of Melbourne. I refer to vessels such as the recently build United States nuclear submarines, the Tridents. Anyone who knows anything about defence knows the awesome lethal capacity of those vessels. They are a major strike component in the United States nuclear weaponry system. If those vessels were detected they would immediately become the target of any Soviet marshall responsible for targeting what he would perceive as a threat to the Soviet Union. It is one thing to act as host to a nuclear powered vessel whose sailors are going on rest and recreation leave. It is quite another thing if, as a result of the view that is being put by this Government in respect of Australia's responsibility to ANZUS, we say that we will extend that doctrine to allow the United States to say to us : 'Prime Minister, we are going to send you a Trident submarine. We know you will happily accept that whatever port in Australia it goes into automatically becomes the target of a Soviet missile'. We have no defence capacity in Australia at all and none could be provided by the United States in that situation. I do not think the United States seeks to do that but I point out that none of the existing arrangements between the Government of the United States and this Government cover that contingency.

It is glib nonsense for the Government, having decided that this matter is no longer one of major moment to this Parliament, to say: 'We will restrict Opposition speakers to 10 minutes. We will get the Bill through the Parliament because we are not really concerned to argue about it'. I am concerned to say, because I think it needs to be said, that any sensible Australian parliamentarian, whether he supports ANZUS or not, has to be concerned about the growth of the nuclear weapons systems in the major super powers. The emphasis that is now being given to a strategy of limited nuclear war and strategic nuclear weapons is a major destabilising factor between the super powers. Any person who is concerned to protest about the growth of nuclear weapons and the sophistication of those weapons held either by the Soviet Union or the United States in my view is acting rationally and sensibly.

We have just had a report from the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which has analysed, amongst other things, the nature of the threats that Australia faces. It pointed out that, in the event of superpower conflict, in all probability Australia would be a target for nuclear weapons. In that situation, as a member whose constituents could be grossly affected, I will not allow this debate to pass and simply say: 'Well, I am going to accept this Government's view that the only relationship we are allowed to have with the United States is automatic compliance with every aspect of United States policy' . What this Government does, I believe, in expressing the kinds of views that have been expressed by the Prime Minister, is to undermine continually any coherent development of a doctrine of regional defence responsibility within Australia. It says: 'In any situation we look to our great American friend'.

We also seriously and falsely raise the expectations of the Australian people in terms of the responsibilities that the United States of America has as a superpower when we say that because a piece of paper was signed in 1951, that means that whatever conflict situation we find ourselves in, be it a regional conflict or whatever, the United States will automatically come to our assistance. I point out to the House that as at 1980 the United States was involved in no less than 140 separate treaties. One only has to look at the recent conflict between Great Britain and Argentina where both Great Britain and Argentina had different expectations from the United States in terms of their existing treaty relationship with the United States. It is a glib over- simplification, and my view a dangerous over-simplification, to say that because of a piece of paper signed in 1951 we can always presume that the Americans will come to our aid in any situation, even if it is just a situation involving regional conflict. The reality is as was put by McGeorge Bundy, a former American presidential adviser, when he said:
The American commitment anywhere is only as deep as the continued conviction of Americans that their interests require.
I quote the words of a distinguished member of the Liberal Party in Australia, Senator Hamer, who, on 25 March last year, said:
The United States will come to our assistance in an emergency if it thinks it is in its interests to do so.

That is what happened in 1942 and there was no alliance then. It is time this Government ceased its practice of dragging out the United States alliance as some political ploy in which it hopes to obtain some immediate electoral favour. There are serious defence issues facing this nation. This legislation is unnecessary. It came about as a result of what seemed to me to be a complete exercise in political expediency by the Prime Minister. The very attitude that the Government takes in limiting the debate in this House and the very interest shown by Government members shows this Bill up for what it is-a fairly sordid political exercise which does the Government no credit in its so often voiced pronouncements about its very special relationship with the United States. Any visiting United States parliamentarian would be sickened by the cynicism that has been displayed by the Government on this issue. I believe the Australian electorate should be sickened by the way in which this Government has demeaned what ought to be a very important debate, not merely about Australia's defence prospects but about the very real threat that every Australian faces when we look at where the nuclear arms race is heading and where doctrines of limited nuclear strategy are leading the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a number of remarks in concluding this debate on the second reading of the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill. I venture to suggest that if there were a Labor Prime Minister faced with the same challenge by a Liberal Premier, that Labor Prime Minister would respond in exactly the same way, because the defence power and the foreign affairs powers in a very real sense are of paramount importance to not only the purpose for which the Federation was formed back at the turn of the century but also the reason why it continues to exist and thereby unite our nation.

SPEECH.PARA: That direct challenge by Mr Cain was taken up by the Labor Premier of the State of New South Wales, Mr Wran. Indeed, it was also backed up by the Western Australian Leader of the Labor Party Opposition in my own State, a Mr Bourke, who came out publicly in support of the Victorian action. He said that a Western Australian Labor Government would oppose visits by nuclear powered or nuclear armed ships. That is a statement from the leader of a political party in Western Australia which had been the host within Fremantle harbour and HMAS Stirling to numerous nuclear powered ships and numerous normally powered surface ships of the United States fleet. Is it any wonder that the Commonwealth, faced with statements of that kind by Labor Party leaders, should desire to introduce and have passed by this Parliament the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill? In introducing the Bill the Minister for Defence said:
The purpose of this Bill is to discharge the responsibilities of the Commonwealth in relation to visits by foreign warships.

That is a succinct and direct statement on the purpose of the Bill. Honourable members might wonder why the atmospherics and the heat level in the debate on this Bill displayed by honourable members of the Opposition is so remarkably different from the public debate which erupted immediately after the Cain statement and the confusion in the Labor Party ranks caused by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) . The answer is quite obvious. When the Labor Party Opposition had to face up to the fact of the constitutional authority of the Commonwealth it of course had no arguments to sustain the stand which had first been taken by Mr Cain. It must be a great deal of embarrassment to the Opposition to have to come into this House and support the Bill against the background of those earlier statements of Mr Cain, Mr Wran, Mr Burke, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and other prominent members of the Labor Party. Indeed, some would say, having listened to the debate this afternoon and tonight and having heard member after member of the Opposition say that the Opposition supports the Bill, while at the same time trying to mount some clever but unconvincing arguments, that we saw the hallmarks of hypocrisy.

I wish to direct my concluding comments to some statements made by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports and the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). I really do wonder where the honourable member for Melbourne Ports stands when he says that he supports the Bill but that he would not like a Trident nuclear powered United States submarine entering the port of Melbourne because it could lead to a Soviet missile attack on Melbourne. I suppose it is a fairly glib observation to say that if the world unfortunately was faced with another world war there is a likelihood that nuclear weapons would be used. Heaven forbid that any of us ever live to see the day when there is either another world war or nuclear arms are used. The public is entitled to ask very deliberately where the honourable member for Melbourne Ports stands when he says he supports the Bill and then says he would not like to have a Trident nuclear powered submarine entering the port of Melbourne. That is the very reason why it is necessary for this Bill to have the authority of Parliament and for the authority of the Commonwealth to be reaffirmed.

I will turn now to the remarks of the honourable member for Swan, who happens to come from my own State of Western Australia. (Quorum formed). I think it is fair enough to observe that the speech by the honourable member for Swan was clever but unconvincing. He, like the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, supported the Bill so from that we are entitled to assume that he is in favour of United States nuclear powered or nuclear armed warships entering the Port of Fremantle or Cockburn Sound. He went on to pontificate by saying that we the public are entitled to know certain things. I really wonder whether the honourable member for Swan is so naive as to think that United States warships in the Indian Ocean are there for a holiday.

It so happens that 11 United States warships will be visiting Fremantle and Cockburn Sound this month. Those 11 United States warships make up the United States carrier task group operating in the Indian Ocean. Obviously they are not there for a holiday. They are there for a strategic purpose relevant to the world-wide defensive operations of the United States, which are directly related to sustaining the overall defence of Australia. The importance of visits of ships of that kind to Australian ports was verified in the Communique issued by the ANZUS council meeting held in Australia in June. The communique stressed ' the importance of access by United States naval ships to the ports of its treaty partners as a critical factor in its efforts to maintain strategic deterence'.

That is the reason why the United States carrier task force is operating in the Indian Ocean. It is an ocean of great importance to Australia and to the Western world, particularly in view of the instability in the Middle East, the Gulf states and in Africa-indeed, right around the rim of the Indian Ocean. It is because of the sentiments expressed in that communique of the ANZUS council meeting in Australia in June that it is not only important but also vital that Australian ports, such as Fremantle, and defence facilities, such as those at HMAS Stirling, are freely open and available to United States nuclear powered or non-nuclear powered or nuclear armed or non-nuclear armed warships. Those ships are the ships of an ally of this country. I wonder whether the Australian Labor Party will ever be prepared to state its true sentiments. We hear honourable members time after time come into this House and condemn our alliance with the United States of America but how often do we ever hear them condemn the aggressive military capability and operations of the Soviet Union?

When, as a Western Australian, I sit here and listen to a fellow Western Australian, the honourable member for Swan, speak as he did today-knowing of the statements that were made in Western Australia by his political colleague Mr Burke, the Leader of the Labor Opposition in State parliament, opposing visits by nuclear powered or nuclear armed ships-I really wonder where the honourable member for Swan stands on this issue. I think it is time that he and his fellow Western Australian federal members and senators, as well as his fellow State Labor Party members, really told the public of Western Australia where they stand. Are they in fact going to oppose, for example, the visit by these 11 United States warships which are about to enter Fremantle harbour and Cockburn Sound? None of the arguments put forward by the Labor Party have been convincing , notwithstanding the fact that Opposition members get up here and rather tritely say they are going to support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Budget of a desperate government, led by a desperate, divisive Prime Minister. At a time when consensus is needed in Australia we are led by a man whose most outstanding characteristic is his divisiveness, who has no moral authority and who, after this Budget, has no economic credibility. The Government is desperate because it is running out of scapegoats to blame for its own mismanagement, maladministration and failure to live up to even the basic standards of ministerial responsibility. It is a government that still thinks it is born to rule. I must say that I am amazed when even front bench members from the other side say that something is the fault of the Whitlam years. The Government parties have governed for 30 of the past 33 years. This Government is led by a Prime Minister who is now complaining because three Bills are blocked in the Senate. Where is all the guff now about the House of review? When the Australian Labor Party was in government for three years 93 Bills were blocked in the Senate by the then Opposition, so let us have no nonsense about blocks in the Senate. The big scapegoat now for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is the world. He says that Australia's problems are caused by the world recession and that we cannot do anything about what is happening in the world economic situation. It must flow through to Australia. What did this Prime Minister say in 1975? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying we can overcome.

This Budget perfectly expresses the futility of this desperate Prime Minister and his Government. It expresses the futility of his leadership. Budgets are both economic and political documents. As a political document this Budget is a cynical response to some of the needs of groups and individuals most bludgeoned by the Government's wicked economic policies. Even where needs have been recognised, it is clear that the findings of Liberal Party opinion polls have been taken into account. This is the reason why the needs of the unemployed and the single parents have been all but ignored. The Liberals have calculated that unemployment will not be an issue.

This Budget has been framed with an early election in mind on the basis that those affected by high interest rates, record taxes, record unemployment, low social security benefits and high inflation will forgive their masters if a few lollies are handed around a few months before an election is envisaged. Of course, the benefits come after 1 November, or 1 January in some instances. The extra revenue collections and the taxes started from 17 August. This is the Government that has now broken the dollar barrier for a schooner of beer. This is the Government that has levied and loaded fuel and petrol with so many taxes that it is now the biggest taxing government in Australia's history. As an economic document the Budget is a surrender. It is a cynical reaction to the Fraser recession. It is not an appropriate economic response to the Fraser recession. It is obvious, of course, that the Prime Minister is casting around for an excuse to have another early election. He is desperate and the biggest scapegoat he was banking on has blown up in his face. That was the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union set up by the Liberals to show guilt by association. What it has shown has been guilt by direct connection with the Liberal Party on the issue of tax evasion.

This Budget reminds me of the 1977 situation. Recently, when the Prime Minister suddenly realised there was a drought on, not only did his reaction keep the November election option open but also it was a direct parallel in rural policy to the panic that produced the beef incentive payments scheme in September 1977. The Government, when in opposition, made so much of the plight of the beef industry in 1975 and did nothing about it for two years and then acted in panic. The Government has responded similarly to the drought. The Prime Minister has totally undercut the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). The basis for this Budget and the reasoning and thinking of the Government for the Budget in relation to the rural sector is that it believes that that sector can be taken for granted. The votes are locked up. It can treat the farmers and graziers, the rural sector and people in country and provincial areas with disdain if not contempt.

Let us look at the Budget and the rural sector. The Budget has done nothing to alleviate the impact of the adverse economic and seasonal conditions currently faced by the majority of Australia's producers. It totally ignored the request submitted by the National Farmers Federation. As we all know, before Budgets are framed there is a series of discussions with various interest groups, the peak organisations of this country representing the unions, the bureaucracy, the farmers and the business people. They have discussions. The peak farming organisation is the National Farmers Federation. It put to the Government a series of requests. Let us go through them. It wanted an additional 20 per cent bounty on fertilisers. This was not done. It wanted an additional $30m for rural research. This was not done. It wanted an additional $5m for wool promotion. This was not done. It wanted an increase of $32m over the 1981-82 allocation for rural adjustment. There was an additional allocation of $2m, which in real terms was less. This was in a year when the Government was getting $10m back from the States. It could simply have cancelled that out and given $10m without its even appearing as a Budget item.

The National Farmers Federation wanted the Government to waive the threshold State contributions during a continuing drought. This was not done, and has not been done in two meetings since the Budget. It wanted the Government to write off the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign debt. This was actually done, but the slaughter levy was increased from $3 to $5. The $23.5m to wipe out the debt of the BTEC simply restored the Federal Government's commitment to pay 15 per cent of the cost of the campaign. The Cattle Council of Australia quite rightly says that this is all it is. It took many representations from the Cattlemen's Union, the Cattle Council and the National Farmers Federation to get the Government to do even that.

Let us return to some of the things that the National Farmers Federation was asking for. It wanted the return of Commonwealth funding of the BTEC to the originally agreed 15 per cent level. This was not done. It wanted to increase the real level of funding for rural roads. This was not done, though we make some allowances for the additional levy on petrol for roads. It wanted some initiatives in the telecommunications area to provide better communications for people in rural areas. What the Government did there was to increase telephone charges for medium distances by 4c and 7c a call, depending on distance. It wanted an increase in the interest rates on income equalisation deposits. This was not done. It wanted the maintenance of the fuel freight subsidy. This was not done. The subsidy was reduced and now it is paid only when the differential exceeds 1c a litre. The National Farmers Federation wanted the immediate write- off of fixed capital investment in farm-based power generation. This was not done. It wanted the Government to accept ongoing responsibility for additional costs associated with increased inspection resulting from the meat substitution scandal. This was not done, but the Government did agree to hold meat inspection charges at the 1981-82 level. Finally, it wanted the Government to assume some responsibility for soil conservation. This was not done. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) as well as not fighting in Cabinet for anything in the Budget for the rural sector, bar the one or two matters I have mentioned, even sought at the meeting of the South Australian Rural Media Association on 30 August to misrepresent the Budget for Australia's agricultural and pastoral industries. He said:

. . . total outlays . . . are estimated at $310m . . . which is a very significant increase of 40 per cent on the 1981-82 level of $200m. Given our policy of continuing economic restraint, I cannot see how anyone can reasonably argue that primary industry is ever forgotten.

What he did not point out, of course, was that the additional sums arise almost entirely for anticipated payments to the wheat and sugar industries. They are existing marketing arrangements as money going into a fund and out of a fund. The sugar figure is simply an accounting function of some millions of dollars and, of course, the wheat figure is quite rubbery because of the drought situation; we do not know how much wheat we are going to get. The Minister says that he believes in ongoing policies and that it does not all need to be done in the Budget. We all agree with that. But there has been no response prior to the Budget and on the most pressing issue of the time it took the Prime Minister's intervention to get any action at all. I suppose he refers to ongoing things such as the razor gang, which is one of the greatest jokes ever perpetrated on the primary industries. Perhaps he likes to think of ongoing things such as the resolution passed by the Federal Council of the Liberal Party recently. The resolution reads:

That this Federal Council believes that Marketing Boards, with powers of compulsory acquisition, levy and monopoly marketing, are contrary to Liberal philosophy and supports the existence of Marketing Boards, private sector or Government-owned, established by statute or otherwise, provided that-
no Board has the power of compulsory purchase;
no Board has a statutory monopoly on sale;
no Board has the power to exact a compulsory levy from purchasers;
no Board has the power to determine the variety of goods produced;
the administrative and marketing expenses, in the case of statutory Boards are met from the commission on sales;
no Board should have an inspectorate with powers of entry, search or seizure of commodities without warrant.

That is one of the ongoing things that the Liberal Party and this Government adhere to. It similarly means that they are out to wreck the Australian Wheat Board, the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Dairy Corporation, existing sugar arrangements in this country and all the 11 statutory marketing boards that this Government is responsible for. If that is one of the ongoing things, it is one of the things the Labor Party will oppose.

The first signal that the interests of Australian primary producers were to be ignored by the Government was provided just weeks before the Budget when the Government announced that no action would be taken to reduce protection to manufacturing industry. The cost of this decision to primary producers would be of the order of $450m during 1982-83 or about $50 per producer per week. We on this side of the House all understand the decision relating to the protection of Australia's manufacturing industry but this is a decision that hurts our rural exporters and the rural export industries still account for 45 per cent to 50 per cent of our export earnings. This is a decision that hurts by default, and no offsets are given in the Budget. In return, the Government provided nothing for primary producers in the Budget, not even the prospect of economic recovery. Interest rates remain at record levels but still some producers find the necessary credit difficult to obtain.

In July the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated that the real net value of rural production was likely to fall by a massive 30 per cent during 1982-83. The major contributing factor was an estimated increase in farm costs of 10 per cent in real terms. The worsening drought situation is likely to cause the estimate of the value of production to fall even further, possibly to a level around 35 per cent or even 40 per cent below the 1981-82 level. At the same time , as a direct result of this Budget, farm costs will rise even further. The excise on petrol and diesel fuel has increased to 6.155c per litre. Primary producers are big fuel users, both on-farm and off-farm. In 1979-80 fuel accounted for 8.8 per cent of the total cash costs of all farming industries and that figure is likely to have increased since then. In the fishing industry fuel accounts for 30 per cent to 40 per cent of total cash costs.

If we look at the new rebate system being proposed by the Government to replace the certificate system, we find that tuna boat and prawn boat owners will have to find an extra $30,000 a year. They will have to extend their overdrafts by that amount to meet this new arrangement. The exemption from excise duty on diesel fuel for all off-road use will be abolished and replaced by a rebate system. The change is expected to yield $176m in a full year. Presumably the bulk of the $176m will come from the railways, which have lost their excise exemption and will not be eligible for the rebate. Rail charges will increase and primary producers will be among those most severely affected. One estimate, that given by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), is that freight costs for grain growers will increase by $20m to $30m a year. Other producers of bulk commodities such as sugar and wool will also experience massive hikes in freight charges. The inevitable delays in the rebate system will impose yet further costs on primary producers. Under the new system they will be forced to carry the added cost of fuel until the rebate is paid. For many producers it will necessitate extending overdrafts at a time of record high interest rates.

As I have already said, among primary producers the largest fuel users are fishermen. Increased costs of fuel will add to the considerable economic difficulties already faced by parts of Australia's fishing industry. The honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) has already pointed out the difficulties being faced by fishermen. My colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) has pointed out the problems for the tourist industry, particularly the off-shore islands in north Queensland. The honourable member for Henty points out that a simple arrangement of colouring the diesel fuel would be a far better way of getting around this problem. Of course, the scheme being proposed by the Government will not prevent abuses-they will occur with the rebate as well-and the number of Customs officers who will have to be employed in the States will be quite enormous. It is quite ill thought through. The administrative costs to the States will be quite large because the States already operate fuel exemptions. The petroleum products freight subsidy has been reduced. Previously freight costs were subsidised where the differential exceeded 0.44c a litre. Now the differential will have to exceed one cent a litre. The slaughter levy on cattle for disease eradication will be increased from $3 to $5 a head. A new series of taxes will be imposed on banking transactions. Telephone charges, as I have already said, will rise. Allowing for the effect of the drought and increased costs, the reduction in the real net value of production for 1982-83 could be as high as 40 per cent.

Overall, the Government's economic strategy in raising outlined in this Budget does nothing to reverse the declining competitiveness of Australia's export industries. Increasingly, primary producers are confronted with a situation in which their competitiveness is declining as Australia's rate of inflation exceeds that of our major trading partners and competitiors and as the managed exchange rate is unable to be adjusted to offset changes in relative rates of inflation. Inflation is unlikely to be reduced by this Budget, particularly if the drought worsens, given the contribution of food to the consumer price index. The Government has given no signs of a change in its approach to exchange rate management from one based on wishful thinking to one based on economic reality. I will not go through the Budget forecasts of 10.75 per cent inflation, no real growth in the economy, no change in the employment situation, and a rise in unemployment.

Let us consider the drought situation. All Australian States and the Northern Territory are now drought affected. New South Wales is in the worst situation, with some areas of that State experiencing their fourth year of drought. It is followed by Queensland and Victoria. Prospects for relief are rapidly diminishing in all areas. In the Budget the government made no allowance for the disastrous situation now confronting many primary producers as a result of the drought. This is a situation from which the Government has tried to extricate itself. As I have said, the Prime Minister saw a droughty sunset, suddenly realised the drought was on, on one of his recent visits to Australia, and undercut the Minister for Primary Industry. Let us look at what the Minister for Primary Industry is saying about the drought. At the Australian Agricultural Council meeting held in Rotorua in New Zealand, where the New South Wales and Victorian Governments requested a review of the drought aid packages and Commonwealth involvement, the Minister for Primary Industry rejected what they were saying. In words of single syllables, he said that they were dills for even raising the matter. The Minister for Primary Industry, in his media release of 18 August, said: that the attitude of the Victorian Premier to drought aid for farmers was utterly unbelievable. He said:
The Commonwealth does not need to make a commitment to help drought affected farmers, because its commitment is already through the natural disaster relief arrangments.

In an interview on AM on 24 August he said that there was no need to do anything more beyond the existing drought arrangments. In the same interview he said Mr O 'Brien of the drought committee of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, should be better informed as a farm leader in raising the problems of the drought. This is why the South Australian Liberal Minister for Agriculture said:

It is amazing that two people, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, being two Country Party members of the coalition, should have lost touch with the rural community to the extent to which they appear to have done, or that they should be such lightweights in the outfit at the level that they have not been able to convince the Prime Minister and his treasurer to give the rural community a fairer deal.

Those are some of the things that have been said about the drought before the Budget and after it. As I said, it was only when the Prime Minister realised that a real drought existed that any steps were taken to ameliorate the effects of the drought. The Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) highlighted a $ 10m advance to New South Wales, but this was part of established procedures under the natural disaster relief scheme and did not represent any special treatment for New South Wales. The most pertinent question to be asked here was why no advance was made to Victoria or Queensland. Are the established procedures invoked only when enough noise is made by a State? Funds for the rural adjustment scheme were increased by $2m to $18.4m. At a rough estimate, about 100,000 primary producers are severely affected by drought, spreading the total allocation by this Government-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three ways of approaching an Appropriation Bill such as the one before us. One is to concentrate on those areas where the Budget does not do everything that everybody wants, and obviously no Budget is capable of satisfying every demand that a community makes . Another is to select those parts of the Budget which deliver to elements in the community something close to everything that they want and to concentrate on them, and of course every Budget does that at least to a certain degree. It seems to me that the more sensible way is to place a Budget against the major problems facing the Australian economy at the time. The major problems facing the Australian economy now are, firstly, the stagnant world economy, which harms our export earnings; secondly, the high interest rates, which weaken investment; and thirdly, the rapid growth in wage costs, which hurts both output and employment. All of these factors together affect the standard of living and zest for living of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: There is in reality nothing an Australian Budget can really do about the world recession. There is something, although not a great deal, it can do about interest rates, which are largely internationally determined, and there is definitely something it can do about wage costs and therefore the consequence of wage costs. It goes without saying that of these great problems facing the Australian economy the most fundamental one is the world recession-the zero growth in the level of demand in industrialised countries, the falling commodity prices, and the low growth of world trade. As I have said, these factors are outside the influence of a small, open trading economy such as Australia's and therefore outside the influence of his Budget. What we can ask of a Budget and of a Government in this sort of international climate is that they avoid making the situation worse, as the Labor Government made it worse between 1973 and 1975 -of course, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) ignored all of this-by recklessly expanding Government expenditure, recklessly expanding the money supply, recklessly increasing the deficit, and recklessly encouraging a wages explosion. This Budget does avoid those errors.

We can also expect a government to take steps to maintain confidence and encourage investment so that the economy is prepared to take advantage of a resumption in world economic growth. This the Budget does, especially in its measures against the effect of high interest rates and the dangers of a further wages explosion. We can also expect a Budget to provide help to people who need it in difficult times. This the Budget certainly does for pensioners, single income parents, home buyers, students, veterans, the disabled and the handicapped, families, the unemployed, the sick, and the Aborigines in all those various measures summarised by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget Speech.

From the international recession I turn to the second major problem to which I referred earlier in my speech, that of high interest rates. These slow down business fixed investment, investment in plant, equipment and buildings, they stop people buying homes, and they make the burden worse for those already paying them off. Yet while interest rates are high overseas they will be high in Australia. They have to be high enough to cover the deficit on current account. At the same time, capital inflow is weakened while the Australian dollar is being devalued, and borrowers run an exchange risk, although this situation may change later in the financial year if devaluation is completed. The Government's ability to manipulate interest rates in these circumstances is obviously limited . It is true that it can have some influence by limiting the deficit, limiting the amount of government borrowing, but as far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned this can easily be overstated since most government borrowing is done by State governments and semi-government authorities. As Table 10 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows, State and local government borrowings for 1981-82 are almost three times larger than Commonwealth public sector borrowing-almost $3 billion as against $1 billion. A reduction of Commonwealth borrowing in these circumstances will have only a small effect. Therefore, in this context of high interest rates, the Commonwealth Government has opted for more direct methods of stimulating investment, in particular its home loan interest rates package and its new depreciation package. The home loan interest rebate will provide significant savings to the taxpayer and will be a real boost to new dwelling construction. The home buyer can claim a rebate at the standard rate on the amount of interest he pays on his housing loan from any source, over 10 per cent on a mortgage up to $60,000. For example, a taxpayer with a $30,000 building society mortgage at 15 per cent will save $450 a year. The Treasurer has also asked the Reserve Bank of Australia to release one per cent of its statutory reserve deposits for housing. This SRD release is in addition to the $400m by which the major banks agreed last week to increase their home lending.

The housing package makes a valuable attack on the problem of high interest rates as they affect both taxpayers and builders. The depreciation package announced in July will reduce the impact of high interest rates on business and will also stimulate investment. The new concessions allow manufacturing industry to write off plant over three years; the rural sector to write off plant over three years and the mining sector to write off mining equipment over 10 years or the life of the mine. The 2.5 per cent depreciation for commercial buildings is also important especially in the longer term. I said that a Budget, in an internationally integrated economy, can do only a little about high interest rates pending their fall internationally. But what can be done has been done by the housing and depreciation packages.

A Federal Budget can make a significant impact on the third of the great problems facing our economy-the rapid rise in wage costs. The gravity of this problem is plain for all to see. Average weekly earnings grew by 17 per cent in 1981-82 and real unit labour costs are now, as is shown in Table 8 on page 28 of Budget Paper No. 1, the highest since the disastrous year of 1974-75 and double the costs of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Table 15 in Budget Paper No. 1 shows that our inflation rate was 10.1 per cent at the end of 1981, far higher than the rates of our major trading partners. Japan had an inflation rate of 2.6 per cent, West Germany 5.6 per cent and United States of America 8.9 per cent. This has resulted in a sharp squeeze on profits so that company income fell by 9 per cent in 1981-82 compared with a 21 per cent rise in 1980-81. This squeeze has, in turn, caused a faltering in production, a stagnant employment situation, falling investment in plant and equipment and the erosion of international competitiveness.

Yet the Budget has taken a major step towards helping to contain wage costs in its package of tax cuts. In the recent wage offensive some unions called for a return to wage indexation. The Budget has not only indexed tax rates but also given tax cuts on top of indexation. As the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pointed out in his speech on the Budget, a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two dependent children, earning $180 a week receives a tax cut of $30 a week which would require a wage increase of $44 a week to equal it and has an effective indexation of about 180 per cent. The taxpayer on $200 a week gets a $ 22.40 tax cut which equals a wage rise of $33 and indexation of 180 per cent. The taxpayer earning $300 a week-average weekly earnings-gets a $17 to $18 tax cut or a 26 per cent wage rise equivalent, which represents over 200 per cent tax indexation. A taxpayer on $400 a week gets a cut of $22.86 or a $42 wage rise equivalent and an effective indexation of 140 per cent.
