Employees will be able to buy shares in their employer's company without being taxed on any benefits arising from the issue price gained under an approved scheme. I have already mentioned the home loan interest rebate. All these concessions will cost the Government over $1.6 billion. As I said it is indexation and more than indexation.

Incidentally, this can be contrasted with the situation under the 1972-75 Labor Government where there was no indexation and in the three Labor Budgets pay-as- you-earn taxpayers found their tax rates increased by 120 per cent, fuelling the wage explosion of those years-an explosion which is still remembered as one of the great tragedies of our time as far as the Australian economy and its management are concerned. The tax cuts in this Budget remove the need for rapid wage increases. Obviously it is the Government side of a general wages policy. The tax cuts are better than any likely wage increase and will surely be taken into account in wage claims. Despite the rhetoric from the Opposition and from some leaders of the trade union movement I think in the light of this Budget, when it is fully understood and absorbed, the reality as distinct from the rhetoric will be that the trade union movement will recognise the significance of the offer by the Government of the Government side of a general wages policy and we will see one in place. Meanwhile we will get the rhetoric but I believe that the reality will replace that rhetoric in the foreseeable future. I think we are seeing signs of that already.

The Treasurer also told us in his Budget Speech that the Government will seek to restrain the growth of financial aggregates to a degree consistent with growth in M3 within a range of 9 per cent to 11 per cent for 1982-83. In other words, the growth in money supply will be restrained so as to restrain price growth and, therefore, wage growth. Our competitive edge in world markets will also consequently be improved. Only the most demagogic rhetoricians in public life would claim that Australia can influence the world economy. However, we can take steps to minimise the harmful effects of the world recession on the Australian economy. This Budget, as I said, does that in contrast to what the Labor Government did in the 1973-75 period. But while we can take steps to minimise the harmful effects on the Australian economy, we would be most recklessly demagogic to imply that Australia can take steps to turn the international economy around. Whilst we have a Budget that recognises our inability to influence the world economy in that way, it nevertheless takes real action against the problem of high interest rates-although there is a limit to what can be done it does it-and it takes major action against the wages explosion.

It is a good, useful Budget to bridge the gap until world economic growth is resumed and to prepare Australia to take advantage of that resumed economic growth when it happens. It helps people who need help in these tough times. It is a responsible Budget, increasing expenditure by 13.9 per cent, compared, say, with the famous 1974-75 increase of 46 per cent. The deficit is confined to 1.2 per cent of gross domestic product, compared with the famous 1974-75 deficit of 4.2 per cent of GDP. The Budget stimulates investment, restrains wage growth, maintains confidence in the Australian economy and gives help to those in need in these tough times. It may well be that world economic growth will resume sooner than the Budget Papers suggest. There are signs that the international slump has bottomed out and that we are observing the beginnings of recovery in the United States, and the international recovery must begin there. I refer to the fall in the levels of inflation and interest rates, the Wall Street rallies, and the improvement in housing commencements, signs of which are also visible in Australia. It is too early to say with confidence, but if world economic recovery comes next year this Budget will have contributed significantly to positioning the Australian economy to take advantage of it. It may well turn out to be the ideal Budget for an election in Australia next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year's Budget was introduced in an atmosphere of speculation regarding an early election and its contents did nothing to dampen that speculation. However, its public and media reception has been much less than enthusiastic and must be causing the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) to have second thoughts about the course he so obviously intended, even if the recent events and debates regarding corruption in Australia arising from the Costigan report had not caused him a substantial rethink. The Budget attempts to buy votes from the middle group, the group the Government believes it has to win back to retain government. But after seven years in government, with a substantial majority in the House, the Government shows no indication of overcoming the twin malaise of the Australian economy-inflation and unemployment . Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) indicated an inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, of 10.7 per cent at June 1982, 4 per cent above the average for all major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners. His own figures on unemployment may seem less reliable than those on inflation, but by any measure the figure for unemployment will be in excess of 400,000 for the year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government talks of all sorts of financial restraint. Is it not amazing that such a government can use $12,000 of public money, through the Information Services Division of the Department of Administrative Services, to have a commercial polling organisation sample more than 1,000 people in a telephone survey to determine their attitudes to the Budget? Surely this is a straight party political survey. If not, it should, upon its receipt, be reported to the Parliament. It should be on the table already. If honesty does not exist with respect to small amounts how can we expect honesty with respect to larger amounts?

The media have been quick to point out snags in the Budget. The Treasurer has already indicated that there is a risk of the housing interest policy being abused, allowing advantage to higher income people. He claims that the Government is drafting legislation to correct this. How much confidence does that give us in this Government's Budget? Obviously the scheme is so tottery that as soon as it is introduced we hear talk about it being amended or altered. How well has the Budget been thought through? Will these snags overshadow the desired perception of an election handout Budget? While the housing policy will deal with the interest rates in the housing area, what will the predicted higher interest rates in other areas do to the cash available to the average elector?

I usually consider most legislative measures from the point of view of the constituents who elect me. Let us consider what the Treasurer sees as the principal features of the Budget and how they operate in these circumstances. The first of his principal features was some personal tax relief and other assistance specifically designed to give maximum help to Australian families, especially those on lower and middle incomes. At first view there seems to be an advantage to my electors. The change in the tax threshold and lowered rates give them some dollars. The increased family allowance for first and second children will assist a number of families. But is this advantage not illusory? The altered tax structure to some extent only rectifies the broken promises over the last seven years. If one repeatedly hits one's head against a brick wall it hurts like hell but it is such a relief when one stops. This Government has treated the electorate so badly in regard to taxation it hopes it can pull a three card trick and make these tax concessions appear to be great ones. They seem good only because such action has been missing for so long.

One wonders how long it is intended that they should continue. We have previously seen this Government give tax concessions and remove them within a six-month period. How much of the tax advantage is eroded by the Treasurer's gentle statement that there are some increases in indirect taxation and a modest broadening of the indirect tax base? Thank God he did not say there were substantial increases and a more than modest broadening because people know how these charges hit them. There are items not in the Budget but which erode-for example, the substantial increase in Telecom Australia charges. That increase is not part of the Budget but it affects the ordinary person in the community. Another item is the one cent per litre increase in the price of petrol. The increase will be two cents per litre from 1 July 1983. In an area such as mine public transport is poor and cars have to be used.

Prescriptions have increased to $4 an item. What happens to the person who needs a frequent supply of medicines and who may have to get two or three items at a time? For those depraved electors of mine who drink beer and smoke cigarettes, there has been a 15 per cent and 20 per cent increase respectively in the take out of the ordinary bloke's pocket money. Also much more erosion is caused by the new federalism. More and more responsibilities are forced on to State governments and then down to local government to carry out services. Payments to those levels of government from the Commonwealth Government are lagging far behind their responsibilities. Local government, with its wide range of welfare and other services, has to increase its rate charges. After all rates are not a particularly equitable way of taxation. Many State semi-government authorities, such as the Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works, are having to increase charges because of a lack of finance from specific programs for the deficiencies that exist in the community. Voluntary health insurance funds are forced to ever increasing premiums because hospital fees must be raised by State governments to maintain services in the face of increasing deficits.

The additional costs for public transport further erode the tax advantage. As I have mentioned, my electorate is poorly served by public transport. Many of my constituents have to use their cars to get to work and they are hit by massive fuel cost increases not because they are using their cars by choice but because they have to do it by necessity. At least there is one bright note in the electorate of Scullin. When I was a member of the State Parliament in the 1960s, the then Liberal Government talked of extending the East Preston tram line. That is all it did for years-talk! The numbers of people who needed this service soared with development in the outer suburbs. The Cain Government has announced the commencement of the first stage of this project and its continuation through the other stages during the 1980s. At least it has done something about it. But for my people, because of all these factors and others, the tax advantage is gone.

What of the feature of the Treasurer of an increase in job training opportunities and other help for the unemployed? I do not knock this feature per se. Indeed, my support for all such schemes in my area has been unstinting, and local organisations and people will acknowledge this. However one despairs at the end result of job training schemes. There are only a few jobs available for their skills amongst the young unemployed. There is another group of middle-aged unemployed with skills for engineering, furnishing trades, metal trades and so on but there are no jobs. In this House I have previously referred to a survey conducted in the municipality of Whittlesea which showed that for structural and economic reasons there would be no further jobs available for the young in that municipality. No matter how much job training there is it is useless without job creation. That survey indicated that there are many small businesses which might prove to be sources of some extra jobs, but this would mean improving conditions for small business. But nowhere has this Government showed any real initiatives in support of small business. Indeed, it has presided over the demise of more small businesses than any other government in Australian history. It has the cheek to put up small business award schemes. It is no good. What it needs to do to help is to make conditions so that these people can continue in business.

Let us look at the new bank charges. While they place a burden on many individuals and large businesses, to small businesses they are a deadly expense. Cheques already attract bank service charges, State stamp duty and now a killing Federal tax. Much of the increase in education expenditure does little to improve quality or opportunity in education or even to restore previous levels. Much of the expenditure is directed to job training, which is useless without job creation. It simply keeps young people at school longer, an aimless procedure which is destined for only a brief period to dampen down unemployment figures. The fact that unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years have been increased by a niggardly $4 from $36 to $40 a week-the first increase for 10 years-is another crude attempt to force families to keep youngsters at school . On that sort of unemployment benefit they are neither one thing nor the other.

What of the aid for the family? There are some welcome changes in the allowances, no matter how belated. What will the result be in children's services? Is innovation undertaken when, say, present pre-school programs feel at risk? They feel at risk, firstly, because of funding and, secondly, because of the breakdown of Federal, State and local government components. I have received many representations from local government authorities and groups on this matter. I think the view of the ordinary person is found in three paragraphs of a letter from the South Morang Pre-School Association, which states:

We value the service provided by the Kindergarten in our area, particularly the opportunity to be involved in our children's education in the early formative years. We feel that it is the right of every child, both now and in the future to have the opportunity to learn and develop in an environment designed for growth, such as Kindergarten provides.

Without proper funding, our fees would need to be so high that many families in our area could not afford to send their children to Kindergarten. The service would then only be available to the rich, certainly not a democratic process.

Victoria has always been in the forefront of pre-school education both in Australia and in the world. We feel that this achievement should not be downgraded, but that our system should be promoted as a successful example of co -operation between community and governments at all levels-local, State and Federal.

That letter illustrates the breakdown that has occurred and the greater pressures that have been put on local and State government in so many areas. What guarantees do they have from the Government? The Minister of Health in Victoria was forced to write to all bodies which are concerned with pre-school services, pointing out that in the last financial year the Commonwealth's contribution to the running costs of such pre-school services dropped from 60 per cent to an estimated 20 per cent. He stated:
There has been an almost total ending of capital funds from nearly $3m in 1976- 7 to a meagre $5,000 last year.

He pointed to the failure of the Commonwealth Government to index such grants and give the local and State governments a chance to continue these services. One of my local councils points to this in a letter. It states:

This Council, like many others in this State, has entered into a partnership with the State Government for the funding and provision of pre-school educational services. The partnership is based on the Council actually providing the service from funds originating from Commonwealth and State sources. The withdrawal or lessening of funds due to policy change or the effects of inflation would have a dramatic effect on this partnership arrangement.

I think the Council makes a telling point about some of the failures in this Budget to appreciate what is going on in the community. Having dealt with those issues, I would like to deal with one that is of particular concern to me. It may seem a little out of place in a general Budget debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen) for his courtesy. We hear so much about the drug problem in Australia, about illicit trade in drugs and the effect that it has in the community. We see the action directed essentially to detection. We see the punitive measures to try to prevent drug use. I am appalled at the lack of imagination that is shown in devising measures to stop this problem at its roots. We have royal commissions inquiring into where the drugs come from and who is involved. How much information do we have about what is happening on the ground? INTERJECT.PARA: It is the increase in the use of amphetamines and speed that concerns me the most. The feedback I get from my own area is that there is an increased use of the amphetamines. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Single Parent Pensions-Diesel Fuel Tax Rebate

PROCTEXT.PARA: Single Parent Pensions-Diesel Fuel Tax Rebate
Motion (by Sir James Killen) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Age of 19 August this year in an article headed 'Canberra Moves on Lone Parents' I read that single parents would have to prove that they could get maintenance before they were granted a pension. As well, maintenance payments of over $6 a week will be counted in the income test. The decision was announced in a one sentence line in the background papers attached to the Budget. The decision says:

SPEECH.PARA: Existing provisions in the Social Security Act concerning the requirement to take reasonable steps to pursue maintenance action will be reactivated.

I am not suggesting that the Department of Social Security should not check on who is or is not eligible for benefits or who should or should not be chasing maintenance claims. However, we should not lose sight of some of the difficulties that are attendant upon both applying for and collecting maintenance already granted on a continuing basis. The insecurity of payment of maintenance is a cause of great distress to single parents supporting children. A person may prove an entitlement to the money but collecting it is another matter. If the Government intends to reactivate existing provisions of the Social Services Act to make sure people make every effort to get maintenance I warn that this will create a lot of extra work for departmental officers who are already overloaded and understaffed. It will create also a lot of worry for the recipients of benefits. This Government approach concerning maintenance assumes that the men are not only willing but also able to subsidise the children whom they have fathered. Most people who work in welfare of any kind would agree that this is in direct contrast to their experience and to the experience of the mothers of the children.

I suggest to the Government that it do something more constructive than harassing single parents. It should set up a national maintenance collection agency. This would be a great help to the people trying to collect the maintenance and, incidentally, would save the taxpayers some money. In Western Australia maintenance is collected through the Family Court thus giving direct help to the people relying on that money for survival. In South Australia I understand the maintenance collection is done through the Department for Community Welfare. The point is that it is one thing to apply for maintenance but it is very difficult for the individual not acquainted with court procedure to pursue his or her maintenance claims month after month. We should set up a national maintenance agency through the family courts which are available in every State and Territory and which would have the authority that the individual lacks.

Throughout the Budget Papers there seems to be a deliberate attempt to blame the single parent for the increases in the welfare budget. This relates to the fact that there is an ever-increasing number of people whose only access to any income for survival is through the Department of Social Security. I am well aware that the number of people who are now in receipt of supporting parents benefits has increased since the benefit was first introduced in 1974. There are a number of basic reasons for this. One of the reasons, of course, includes rising unemployment which causes tremendous stress and breakdown in families. The Budget has dealt most unfairly with those receiving the supporting parents benefit. Those people, together with the base rate pensioner and the young unemployed, have been almost totally ignored in the Budget. A proper and humane government response to those problems would not be further harassment, crackdown and interference in those people's private lives; it would be the raising of the supporting parent's benefit and pensions and the relaxation of income tests so that parents could bring up their children on a decent standard of living.

Australia has, despite its general air of affluence, a growing number of families in poverty and non-functioning array. If this Government is serious about preserving the family unit-that includes the supporting parents as a family unit-it must face the fact that its current policies are failing to guarantee even minimal living standards for every citizen. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has said in his ministerial statement on social security programs that he has sought a solution which as far as possible avoids creating further financial incentives for separation and reduces the incentives for forming new relationships. Is the Minister trying to tell us that people are breaking relationships, marriages and homes so that they can go chasing after these fairly minimal benefits that are provided through the Social Security Department? I think not. I think the Government must give a second thought to the predicament in which these supporting parents find themselves. It is a very difficult thing for a supporting parent to get out and get a job when he or she has young children. What we give them to live on is really not enough to preserve that family unit which is equally as important as the family unit that we are accustomed to that, with two parents in the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Farmers are up in arms over the method of applying the diesel fuel tax which has recently been announced and the way in which rebates can be claimed. Surely, the Customs and excise people could have come up with a more simplified method. The new system will not, of course, eliminate problems where tax free distillate is made available to transport operators. Honourable members in country electorates are being bombarded with complaints as to the administration of the rebate. It is unwieldly. We all know how farmers do not like administrative work. They work on their farms during the day. They do not want to come home at night to find a lot of paperwork. The onus is on the farmer to keep records. Under the previous method a farm tractor operator made known to the Bureau of Customs the horsepower and the make of the tractor that he was operating. He was issued with a diesel licence from the Bureau of Customs . In most cases these licenses were left with the local oil distributor. When he made deliveries to the farm he left an invoice with the diesel licence noted on it. When he had diesel lorries he purchased a certain amount of fuel which was duty paid. Customs officers visited country areas and called on the distributors to check their books. In many instances legal action was taken where it was found that transport operators were using a farmer's diesel licence. This went on for some 18 months or two years and then, for some unknown reason, the inspectors ceased coming. This is one of the reasons why the system was open to fraud and no doubt is one of the reasons why the Government lost $40m revenue. Operators were found to be purchasing distillate on farm diesel licences. The new system will require policing as unscrupulous people may still claim the rebate on fuel, which could still be sold to transport operators. It will in no way stop this practice. It will cost huge sums of money to administer and police the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Another very serious aspect of this legislation is that fuel distributors will have to find another 20 per cent more capital to handle this sytem. That is, they will have to find 6.155c per litre. We know what distillate fuel big farming operators purchase, and the local oil distributor has to find this capital. The farmer then makes application for a rebate from the Bureau of Customs. The rebate will be claimed by the farmer and paid to his account. The distributor will not get it. Accounts that are now financed by the oil distributors, not the distributor himself, will get the rebate. Where an oil distributor is financing a farmer because of the farmer's lack of finance, the rebate will be paid into the farmer's bank account and the distributor will miss out. This is a very serious aspect of the legislation, and feel it has not been given full consideration.

As I have mentioned, the new system will require a huge sum of money to administer. Surely it is not too late to review the rebate situation and the whole operation of diesel fuel tax. This is a serious situation. It is causing great problems to all concerned, not only to farmers but also to the fisheries industry and oil distributors. I believe that the Bureau of Customs has let us down in this instance, and the matter should be looked at as soon as possible. The Bureau of Customs has advised the Government on this matter. The Government ought to have another look into the matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did South African surfers compete in a surf carnival held in Sydney on Saturday, 25 April 1981; if so, (a) how many took part, (b) what were their names, (c) what official Australian travel documents were they using and (d) when were those documents issued?
(2) Was the South African flag flown, along with other flags, during the surf carnival?
(3) Did the surf carnival director state to journalists that the Government's policy, following the Gleneagles Agreement, did not apply?
(4) What action is the Government taking to ensure that is policy is adhered to by all Australian sporting bodies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(a) Three members of the team were South African citizens. One other member of the team was an Irish citizen.
(b) Bruce Jackson, Shaun Tomson, David Hansen, Mark Price.
(c) Jackson, Tomson and Hansen were travelling on South African passports and Price on an Irish passport.

(d) Mr Bruce Jackson was issued a visitor's visa for entry to Australia on 29 October 1980. Mr David Hansen was issued a visitor's visa on 16 January 1981. Mr Shaun Tomson was issued a temporary resident visa on which he entered Australia on 26 February 1981. Mr Mark Price was issued a visitor's visa on 20 January 1981.

(2) I have been advised that the South African flag was flown at the event. This is a matter for regret as such action conveyed the false impression that the South Africans competed as national representatives. I emphasise that they were not here as representatives. I emphasise that they were not here as representatives of their country, but as individual competitors.
(3) I am not aware of the substance of conversations between journalists and the competition organisers.
(4) The Government's policy on sporting contracts with South Africa and its commitment to the Gleneagles Agreement is well known.

Since 1975 the Government, in common with its predecessor, has actively discouraged sporting contracts with South Africa. Such a policy has been in accordance with both United Nations General Assembly Resolution 31/6 of November 1976 and the Gleneagles Declaration agreed to at the November 1977 Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.
The main practical restriction has been on the entry of South African sportsmen into Australia. Thus, while sports in South Africa are organised on the basis of race, colour or ethnic origin

(a) sporting teams or groups of sportsmen domiciled in South Africa will not be granted entry to compete in Australia, irrespective of whether or not they intend to represent South Africa or any South African organisation;
(b) individual sportsmen domiciled in South Africa will not be granted entry to compete in Australia as representatives of South Africa or any South African organisation;

(c) individual sportsmen intending to compete in Australia as private individuals and not as representatives of South Africa or of any South African organisation will be considered for entry on a case-by-case basis;
(d) applications by officials of South African sporting organisations seeking to enter Australia as visitors will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

While the Government does not place restrictions on travel abroad by Australian citizens or seek to impose its views on sporting bodies and sportsmen, it looks to them to take into account, in making their decisions, the policies it has enunciated and its reason for them.

Following the 1977 Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the Minister for Foreign Affairs wrote to all national sporting organisations in Australia forwarding to each a copy of the Gleneagles Declaration and reiterating to them Australia's undertaking to discourage sporting contacts with South Africa or with any other country practising racial discrimination in sport.

The Government also circulated to national sporting bodies in Australia a statement of the practical application of this policy, drawing their attention to the United Nations Resolution 31/6 of November 1976.

In 1978, national sporting associations were informed that it would not be in accordance with Government policy for Government grants to be used to facilitate sporting contacts with South Africa, whether such contacts took place in Australia, South Africa or elsewhere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the findings of a study by the economic research department of the Commercial Banking Company which states that the average debt for a member of the Australian workforce was $5174 at the end of the 1979-80 financial year.
(2) Will he consider this in response to pressure on the Government from lobby groups on interest rates.
(3) Is this indebtedness a result of Government policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I thank the honourable member for drawing my attention to the study on household debt by the Commercial Banking Company of Sydney. The study, in addition to putting forward a measure of gross household sector debt per member of the labour force, makes mention of the fact that the household sector overall is a net lender to other sectors of the economy. In other words, household sector gross indebtedness is more than offset by household sector savings-though of course some people in the household sector are net debtors.

(2) The Government is well aware of the fact that there are a number of net debtors in the household sector. At the same time, as mentioned above, the household sector overall is a net lender to other sectors which means that there are also a large number of individuals in the household sector who are net savers. In framing its policies therefore the Government has to achieve a balance between the sometimes competing interests of existing and potential borrowers and those of household savers. It is in the interests of both groups that inflation be reduced and a more stable financial environment be established and this is the primary aim of the Government's economic policies.

(3) No. The study on household debt estimates that approximately two-thirds of the outstanding debt of the household sector as at June 1980 was in respect of housing loans. It therefore appears that the main reason why individuals in the household sector are incurring debt is to purchase a home.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Average Minimum Wages: Disparity between Sexes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Bureau of Statistics figures indicate a wage disparity between the sexes , based on the average minimum wages, of $12.61.
(2) Can the Bureau project a date by which any disparity will have been completely removed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Preliminary figures published by the ABS on 14 January 1982 show that in November 1981 the weighted average minimum weekly wage rate for a full week's work, as prescribed in awards, determinations and collective agreements, was $12 .61 more for adult males than for adult females.
(2) It is not part of the Bureau's functions to predict future rates of change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister release figures, published in the Australian on 22 February 1982, for animals from breeding units which indicated that 208 'other animals' were used in experiments in 1980 by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and did he release figures concerning animals in the Australian Capital Territory which indicated that 10,275 'other animals' were used in experimentation.
(2) Will the Minister specify what the 'other animals' were in each case.
(3) Did the Minister state in that article that under the prevention of cruelty to animals ordinance it was only permissible to inflict pain if it was necessary to the experiment.
(4) What are the criteria used to ascertain whether an animal is in pain.
(5) Is the prevention of cruelty to animals ordinance legal and binding.
(6) Have any organisations or individuals ever been prosecuted under the ordinance.

(7) Can the Minister give assurance that the 141,353 animals used in experiments by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the 175 used by the Institute of Health, and the 104,525 used in the A.C.T. were not subjected to any pain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The figures quoted were given by the Minister in answer to a Parliamentary Question (See H. R. Hansard of 16 February 1982, pp. 91-92, Question No. 1970).

(2) Those used by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories were sheep and chickens. Those used in the A.C.T. included chickens, ducks, eagles, galahs, geese, turkeys, sheep, cattle, pigs, wallabies, kangaroos, wallaroos, bandicoots, wombats, possums, echidnas, toads, frogs, snakes, lizards, bats, axolotls, crocodiles, crustacea, fish, northern native cats, marsupial mice and a platypus .

(3) See (1). In reply to Question No. 1970, part (3) the Minister states 'No, except that in accordance with the conditions determined by the Minister for Health under the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Ordinance 1959, with which authorised persons performing vivisections and experiments on animals must comply, it is permissible not to render an animal completely insensible to pain only in circumstances where insensibility cannot be produced without frustrating the object of the experiment'.

(4) No universally accepted definition or set of criteria for determining pain in animals exists. In practice, the judgment of levels of pain and stress in animals has to be based on the clinical experience and commonsense of the research worker. Indicators such as struggling, excessive vocalisation, convulsions or severe palpitations assist in the recognition of pain. Other measureable parameters would include dilated pupils, increased blood pressure, increased heart and respiration rates and sweating.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes.

(7) No. In some case, pain and discomfort for the animal are unavoidable but are minimised wherever possible. In some situations, the animals are painlessly killed as soon as practicable to avoid suffering. When it is known from past experience that a particular experiment or activity will cause a state of pain or it is judged that a new procedure is likely to cause pain, the animal is anaethetised to the maximum extent possible. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and all Government organisations involved in experiments on animals in the A.C.T . abide by the joint National Health and Medical Research Council/Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation 'Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals in Research in Australia').

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are any registered health insurance funds experiencing financial problems, particularly in New South Wales: If so, what action does he plan to protect the rights of their members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Some health insurance organisations can experience adverse financial circumstances from time to time. This can be due to a number of factors such as: higher utilisation of services (and payment of benefits) at certain times in the year; increases in levels of charges (and payment of benefits) before time is available to adjust contribution rates correspondingly; lags in contribution payments, Christmas/New Year holiday break. However with good management practices and planning, efficient organisations can provide for these circumstances and take corrective action. It is not unusual for different types of undertakings to experience adverse financial circumstances from time to time.
Therefore it is inappropriate to establish that at any point in time such-and- such organisations are experiencing 'financial problems'.

My Department is particularly concerned with the preservation of the interests of contributors. It regularly monitors the financial situation of registered health insurance organisations to ensure that possible financial difficulties are detected at an early stage. Corrective action can be taken to ensure their financial viability or, in particular cases where the contributor profile and drawing rates show longer term problems, to discuss amalgamation with a kindred registered organisation.
